story:
Inspired by the idea of creating a green alternative to Styrofoam packaging, a small team of entrepreneurs has designed the WooBox. Made out of wood and naturally processed wool, the WooBox is intended to be used to transport all sorts of fresh food, aiming to eventually become a key element of the food delivery industry (temperature controlled logistics). Being eco-friendly, entirely recyclable and completely safe to its users or manufacturers, the WooBox is a perfect solution to all of the problems brought by the use of Styrofoam.

 

How Can a WooBox be Used?

 

 

 

 

 

The WooBox can be a part of your daily life as well!

 

 

 

 

This is How we Repurpose Wool

 

 

 

 

The WooBox team hopes to turn the production of boxes into a pilot project that will significantly contribute to the fight against pollution. In order to make our dream a reality, we need your help. By reaching our goal of raising $50,000 through this crowdfunding campaign, we will be able to start a serial production of this innovative product and, thus, take a first step towards a more sustainable future.

 

As seen on:

 

 

 

 

 

 

The "No More Styrofoam" Project

 

No More Styrofoam is a project that aims to raise awareness about the high threat that expanded polystyrene foam poses to the environment, at the same time growing as a virtual community of people dedicated to the cause. Also, it aims to result in a small purpose-driven startup that will offer an actual alternative to the use of this harmful material in the food delivery industry.

 

 

 

 

The WooBox – A Green Alternative

Inspired by the idea of creating a pilot project that will demonstrate that the Styrofoam issues are not irremediable, a small team of entrepreneurs have designed a product that is eco-friendly in every sense of the word. The WooBox, a box created out of natural materials, presents a solution to all of the problems set by expanded polystyrene foam, specifically in the food delivery industry regarding the temperature controlled logistics.

 

 

 

 

How it Can Be Used

 

The WooBox is primarily intended to be used to transport all sorts of fresh food, aiming to become an indispensable part of the food delivery industry.

  • Due to remarkable thermal insulation properties of its materials, the WooBox ensures product quality and optimizes shelf life.
  • It is ideal for long distance transports and larger amount shipments.
  • Perfect for meal kits.
  • Due to its innovative design, WooBox can be used for anything from furniture and children game room props to pet accessories.

 

 

 

 

All Natural Materials

 

The only two materials used in the production of WooBox are wood and wool. Naturally processed wool has been used for centuries for its outstanding isolation properties. Since around 70% of wool worldwide is not being suitable for the clothing industry, we have decided to use it for the inside of our case. Purifying the air, regulating humidity, and resisting flaming, wool provides an excellent protection and isolation for the food stored inside, maintaining and not compromising its nourishment.

 

The exterior of the WooBox is made out of wood, completely securing its content. Manufacturing WooBox in a small town near Loznica, Serbia, we plan to plant a tree for the each one that has been used in our manufacture process.

 

Using eco-friendly materials that are one hundred percent recyclable, it could be said that the WooBox has the most rounded concept a box can have.

 

 

 

 

Functionality

Conceived as a transportational box for storing and packaging food and other goods, the WooBox is especially designed with functionality in mind. Interventions made on the outside and inside surfaces of the box contribute to its intended purpose, fully maximizing its possibilities.

 

Designed with counter conical rails on its wooden surface, different boxes can slide into one another, forming a compact whole that conveys a rhythm of a single box.

 

Based on a unique modular, sliding junction concept, the WooBox provides endless compositional possibilities, being perfectly suitable for a variety of packaging and storing requirements in the food industry.

 

Each box has a transport capacity of 30kg and a volume of 21l. The transport capacity of a single box remains the same no matter how many of them are joined into a single whole.

 

 

 

 

The Superiority of WooBox Over Styrofoam

When comparing all of their intended purposes and traits, the superiority of the WooBox over Styrofoam is obvious.

  • While Styrofoam is a health and environmental hazard, the WooBox is perfectly safe in both production and disposal process, bringing no danger to humans or animals.
  • While Styrofoam is not recyclable in real world scenarios, ending up as waste in landfills, the WooBox is one hundred percent recyclable, or it can even be reused to become a practical part of your lifestyle.
  • Indeed, Styrofoam is cheap, but the WooBox can be used over and over again, to a point where the initial difference in cost is balanced out by the durability of its natural materials.

Styrofoam is not a necessary evil of modern society. Now it has an actual alternative – the WooBox. A result of a purpose-driven business, it strives to be a part of the solution and make a true difference. By helping fund this project, you are not only contributing to the production of the product itself, but you are taking the first step in ridding our world of the Styrofoam problem.

 

 

 

 

Nikica Marinković – Co-Founder

Nikica Marinković has graduated from the Faculty of Agriculture at the University of Novi Sad. Throughout his rich career, he has supported the local community in building a relationship with the local authorities in municipality of Vršac (Serbia); provided education for local farmers; worked on UN FAO project, assistance development to farmers in remote areas of Balkans; worked as a project manager in helping organize farmers and entrepreneurs into modern associations; and worked for GIZ as a project manager for private sector development in Danube region, among others. He is a winner of Social Entrepreneurship Challenge awarded by the Austrian Development Agency and the winner of the Smart Living Challenge awarded by Munktell Science Park & Swedish Institute and Climate - KIC accelarator member. In 2016, Nikica founded Zelenoo.com, a web service for direct food selling, connecting local farmers and urban consumers. Since 2014, he has been working on the development of the WooBox.

 

Ivan Erkić – Co-Founder & Product Designer

Born in 1983, Ivan Erkić graduated Product Design at the Faculty of Applied Arts in Belgrade. In 2008, Ivan and his colleagues have founded the studio ICdesign in 2008, developing 3D design for the most eminent advertising agencies in the country. Since 2012, he has been working on the development of the Invisible Design concept based on the human experience psychology and the shapes that surround us. In 2013, he has collaborated with studio Brigada on the development of variety of products in the field of retail design as part of the agency B&Ž Zagreb. He is a member of the design hub Nova Iskra since its inception. Some of the most notable products Ivan has designed are the bottle packaging for Bohor, the Negative Lamp for Kubo, the Magic Spoon – Kitchen Tool, as well as the KET system of self contained units for energy collecting in traffic. Ivan has been working on the development of the WooBox since 2016.

 

Jelena Tasić – Project Assistant

Jelena Tasić is the architecture engineer and educator in psycho-dynamic organisational consulting. Currently, she is working as a manager and advertising specialist at the special hospital Lorijem Center. She is a part of the AmChamps – Young Leaders in Change program where she is working on developing her leadership skills. In 2014, Jelena has started developing the WooBox concept with Nikica. She has an entrepreneurial spirit and is always ready to learn and develop new ideas. She believes that people are not defined by their profession, but rather by the sum of their skills. This is the reason her professional career is highly diverse.

 

Petar Blagojević – Product and Process Engineer

Born in Loznica in 1992, Petar Blagojević has graduated from the Faculty of Forestry in Belgrade. Ever since his early childhood, he has been interested in making a variety of items out of wood. He has participated in a number of seminars, contests and projects in the country and abroad. For his project MUSE (Mobil Unit School Easygoing), he has been awarded by the Mikser festival and by the Chamber of Commerce in Belgrade for the best design solution for the school year 2015/2016. He has been granted the Dositej scholarship by the Fund for Young Talents of Republic of Serbia. He is currently attending his master studies and working as part of the WooBox team.

 

Have Questions?

Contact us any time at info@nomorestyrofoam.org

story:
The campaign is now closed, Canada's Great Water Adventure is AVAILABLE NOW on Waterlution's website! Thank you for your support, please follow us on social media (@waterlution) to hear about Canada's Great Water Adventure future successes!

What is Canada's Great Water Adventure about?

This book invites readers to explore Canada and its waterways through the eyes of Fernando - an exchange student from Brasil, and Brooke - a young Canadian, whose family is hosting Fernando. These two young adventurers set out to visit each province and territory from coast (east) - to coast (west) - to coast (north) across Canada, to learn about many breathtaking and unique waterways, rich with a myriad of history, landscapes and people.

This book is specifically written for children up to 11 years old (up to grade 6) to learn about water through a fictional story featuring real Canadian waterways and facts. This is a story about curiosity, a desire to learn more, a connection with nature and water, and a deep respect for cultures and traditions.

 

Who is behind this storybook?

Canada’s Great Water Adventure is being brought to you by Waterlution and was written by four of its very dedicated Youth Advisory Board volunteers- Dorothy Graham, Ellen Stitt, Jill Pelkey and Stephanie Woodworth. These youth volunteers were inspired by amazing children from across Canada who participated in the Great Waters Challenge (hence the name - Canada’s Great Water Adventure!)

What is the Great Waters Challenge?

The Great Waters Challenge is an interactive and gamified educational program, launched in 2016, and designed to immerse children and youth in water education throughout Canada, through a series of fun challenges that get them out into their watershed! From Vancouver, to Gjoa Haven, to Charlottetown and all communities in between, students and youth learned the names of the Indigenous territories on which they live, explored the history of water in their community, connected through workshops and webinars, and showcased their discoveries with us in various ways (including through blog posts, photos and videos!). Check out the interactive map here

 

What’s so special about Canada’s Great Water Adventure children’s book? It’s packed with cool features!

Interactive! All the beautiful illustrations are artfully created by a young emerging artist, who drew on her imagination and knowledge of this vast and diverse country to bring this story to life! She left a few illustrations for the imagination of our little readers to colour, and feel part of the story and book!

Ageless! Though this book is specifically written for grades 1-6 to learn about the great water bodies of Canada, we guarantee there’s something in it for you to learn too!

35 pages! (+glossary) Of imagination-triggering adventure and exploration across waterways, learning about local traditions and different water practices in Canada!

Real facts for deeper learning! Canada’s Great Water Adventure is a fictional story filled with real Canadian waterways and facts, including references to indigenous language and traditions all designed to deepen care and learning around Canada’s great waters.

Waterless! Though it is filled with water stories, the book itself is printed through a waterless printing company (most print shops use a ton of water for printing! See more below**). It makes perfect sense to raise awareness about water consumption while being an environmentally-conscious gift.

Glossary! With the focus on educating children on water, the glossary at the back highlights new and unfamiliar terms.

Bilingual! This book is available in both English and French!

Our goal with this fundraising campaign is to share this educational story with as many young learners as possible, to inspire them to connect with water, and to care for its future! Join us in making this possible!  

How will the funds be used?

Our first goal in this campaign is to distribute 400 books. To achieve this goal, we need to raise $10,000 to cover the cost of production, printing and distribution. One of the reward categories also allows contributors of the campaign to support this book in reaching libraries, schools and families in need.

Anything above our initial goal will go directly towards offering school-based workshops through the Great Waters Challenge - the program that inspired this book and campaign - in classrooms across the country!

Ready to support Canada’s Great Water Adventure?

Thank you for supporting this campaign! Please share it with your friends, family, and colleagues. For more info about the Great Waters Challenge, please take a look at www.waterlution.org/GWC and check out Waterlution’s work at www.waterlution.org
 

Want to receive your book before Christmas?

Canada’s Great Water Adventure children’s book is a perfect gift for the holiday season. If you’d like this book before Christmas, please place your order by December 13th at midnight (Eastern Standard Time)! We have gone to print. All those who place orders by the deadline will receive a campaign update by December 14 regarding the status of the shipment.

With your support we trust we will achieve our campaign goal, and all books will be shipped by mid-January.

We want to thank all those who helped us in the process of writing this book, including those who helped cross-check cultural references. Thank you to those who contributed.

**Note on waterless printing: Yes, it costs more, but it is the right - and environmentally conscious - thing to do. Many large presses can consume hundreds of thousands of litres of water per year as part of the normal printing process. Waterless printing takes advantage of modern technology to reduce these environmental impacts. It eliminates chemicals and water altogether. Waterless presses are also praised for their high-quality colour reproduction and the reduced paper set-up waste for each job.

 

Ordering multiple books for a Canadian library? Contact Olivia at olivia.allen@waterlution.org

BONUS: The first 25 people in Canada to contribute will be entered to win 1 of 5 FREE Waterlution T-Shirts! *Size and colour may be limited to what is available.

story:
As winter settles in over the North, the Unist’ot’en Clan of the Wet’suwet’en nation remain on guard protecting their territory from pipeline development for the sake of all future generations. The Unist’ot’en understand that clean rivers you can drink from, healthy forests full of berries, and habitat for moose, bears, and salmon are infinitely more valuable than any amount of financial gain. This has been their land since time immemorial. And yet government and industry are intent on creating a massive corridor of oil and gas pipelines in order to facilitate expansion of the Tar Sands gigaproject and highly-destructive Fracking fields in Northeastern BC, what environmentalists are referring to as the Carbon Corridor and a global warming time-bomb.

To ensure that these pipelines never happen, the Unist’ot’en Clan with support from grassroots Wet’suwet’en, have constructed a resistance community directly on the GPS coordinates of the proposed pipeline route. Already twice this fall, the Unist’ot’en uncovered and evicted surveyors working for the Pacific Trails Pipeline company.

Operating the camp daily requires fuel, materials, food, and resources of all sorts. Also, the camp is constantly growing and expanding. Recent additions include new outhouses, a smokehouse, sauna, rootcellar and expansion of the main cabin. Many of the costs so far have been paid for out-of-pocket by community members and allies staying at the camp. Our goal is to raise $10,000 dollars to cover operating expenses and keep the camp growing through the winter and to help prepare for an emergency mobilization if one becomes necessary.

Resistance is a collective effort and calls for the support of the entire community. The Unist’ot’en Camp is a grassroots indigenous effort led by hereditary community members and does not receive institutional funding! All contributions are greatly appreciated. Please support generously.

story:
This is our OLD campaign.  Check out the new one at:


www.igg.me/at/cpengineers2




If you believe Enbridge's numbers, the risks of a major spill are 10%

If you don't believe their numbers, the risk only goes up

 

Since when is 10% acceptable?

 

We've performed our own, independent review and found Enbridge's analysis to be lacking.  Help us get the message out so that we can start a debate about the facts and what is an acceptable level of risk.

  • Enbridge provides no justification or documentation for the 'scaling factors' they used to calculate the 10% risk of a major spill.
  • Enbridge's liability ends when the tankers leave the terminal.  Who's responsible for a spill along the narrow 300 km waterway from Kitimat to the open ocean?
  • Enbridge's risk analysis planned for 220 tankers per year through Douglas Channel.  New LNG projects will bring that number to over 600.
  • Federal scientists, testifying during the JRP hearings, say more research is needed on diluted bitumen before they can be sure a cleanup is even possible.

This is not good engineering.

 

Who we are

Concerned Professional Engineers (CPE) is a small group of professional engineers living in British Columbia, Canada.  Together we have many decades of experience in the design, construction and operation of large projects for the extraction and transportation of natural resources like coal and oil. 

We share a deep concern for the environment and the future of this coast, this country and this planet.  With our backgrounds we are keenly aware of the inherent conflict between environmental protection and resource development proposed by large projects.

We understand that we cannot end our dependence on resources tomorrow, and that it is important to propose practical, achievable solutions to these problems that strike an acceptable balance between economic development and risk to the environment.  We are not opposed to the development and export of natural resources, but we feel very strongly that these projects must be done in a safe and responsible manner, with a full accounting of the risks and visibility to the public.

(Hartley Bay, Douglas Channel)


What We Want to Do

We have spent the last two years investigating the risks posed by this project and participating in the National Energy Board's Joint Review Panel (NEB JRP) on Northern Gateway (NG).  We are now raising a small amount of money to launch an awareness campaign to help publicize our work.  This campaign will consist of:

  • One (or more) educational videos detailing our concerns in an accessible way that focuses on the core facts of the debate.
  • A website that provides easy access to the original source documents that have been submitted as part of the JRP process.  These documents contain detailed testimony in support of, and in opposition to, the project. We feel Canadians should review these source documents so that they can see for themselves what is being proposed.  We would like to make accessing this important information easier.
  • A social media campaign to engage Canadians in the debate about the marine aspects of the Northern Gateway.
  • Recruiting of other engineers who share our concerns and who wish to bring further expertise to our analysis. 

Although we have extensive experience in the engineering of large projects like the Northern Gateway, we are unfortunately lacking in experience with modern media.  We are raising $20,000, the majority of which will go towards hiring young people who are experts in videography, animation, web development and social media.  

Our goal is to create a more substantive debate about Northern Gateway.  We would like to provide Canadians with access to the facts that have been presented in support of, and in opposition to, this project so that they feel empowered to decide for themselves whether or not they support Northern Gateway.

Our Story

Dear Backer,

In the summer of 2012 I took a trip up to Douglas Channel with another professional engineer.  We spent three weeks in an open-top zodiac touring the proposed tanker routes through which Enbridge’s Northern Gateway project will ship 525,000 barrels of diluted bitumen (dilbit) and 193,000 barrels of natural gas condensate (diluent) every day for 50 years.  We wanted to see firsthand the challenges and risks posed by this project.

(Brian Gunn in Port Simpson)

I became interested in this type of work as a natural extension of my role in the Wilderness Tourism Association, a group that I helped create in order to build a common voice for the many remote tourism operations in their negotiations with industry and government, particularly in land-use planning.  Oftentimes I have found that this work pits my passion for the environment and sustainable wilderness tourism against my background as an engineer in the bulk materials handling industry.  I understand that the development and export of natural resources is central to Canada’s economic success, and to the future of this country.  I also understand, however, that our environment in its untouched state is a significant natural resource in itself, and that its proper stewardship is just as important to our future.  

Northern Gateway marine shipping

This trip left both of us with a lasting impression of the immense challenge of the undertaking.  The proposed route to the open ocean is nearly 300 km (186 miles) long through constrained channels, some of which are less than 1400 m (4600 ft) wide.  This may seem large until you realize that the proposed ships are more than 300 m (1,000 ft) in length and can take several kilometers to slow down or stop.  Furthermore, the route is on the northern BC coast, a place famous for its challenging weather, winds, waves, and heavy fog.

(Proposed marine shipping routes - Enbridge Quantitative Risk Analysis)

Our actions to date

We came away from this trip with a deep sense of concern for future generations and felt that we had to contribute to the debate.  Together with five other engineers, we formed the Concerned Professional Engineers group and participated in the National Energy Board’s Joint Review Panel as follows:

  • We submitted a 31 page letter of comment to the JRP detailing our technical arguments.  NG responded to this letter.
  • We submitted a letter to APEGBC that was published in the Sept/Oct 2012 issue of their Innovation magazine.
  • In order to respond back to NG, we were able to join C. J. Peter Associates Engineering, who had been accepted as interveners by the NEB, to question NG’s consultants about their work in the March 2013 JRP hearings in Prince Rupert and the June 2013 JRP Final Argument hearings in Terrace.

We have also been featured in numerous radio and print interviews.

Our Concerns

We have numerous concerns about the tanker aspects of the Northern Gateway, but they can be roughly summarized by the following three main arguments:

  1. The estimated risks are too high and this project enjoys a substantial ‘risk premium’ that the public is underwriting.  In other words, why would this project be allowed to proceed when the stated risks are far higher than what is considered acceptable for other large projects, like bridges, for example?
  2. The consequences of dilbit spills and the possibility of cleanup are unknown.
  3. It is unclear who is ultimately responsible for the costs of cleanup in the event of a tanker spill. For large spills it will probably be the people of Canada.

Each of these arguments is supported by considerable testimony from a variety of expert panels convened during the Joint Review Panel hearings.  It is this testimony and evidence that we feel needs to be made more accessible to Canadians.


We Need Your Help

We believe that we need to appeal to Canadians across the country to state that export of natural resources is not bad for Canadians if it is done in a safe manner. Unfortunately the Northern Gateway proposal to ship dilbit through the Port of Kitimat and Douglas Channel does not meet those requirements.

I am writing to ask you to consider making a donation to support an awareness campaign to bring our message to Canadians.  This campaign will consist of an informative video, a website, a petition, a social media campaign and recruiting of new members.  We anticipate that the costs for this campaign will be in the range of $20,000.  Please give this request for funding assistance your careful thought and consideration. 

Thanks and regards,

Brian Gunn


Incentives

To acknowledge your generous support we are offering a number of incredible vacation packages from wilderness resorts in British Columbia.  Experience firsthand the wildlife and supernatural beauty that has made this Province famous around the world.

(Courtesy of Grizzly Tours and Strathcona Park Lodge)


Our Members

Dr. Ricardo O. Foschi, P.Eng, Professor Emeritus, UBC

Dr. Ricardo O. Foschi is Emeritus Professor of Civil Engineering at the University of British Columbia. He holds graduate degrees (Master and Ph.D) in Applied Mechanics from Stanford University, California. His areas of specialization are probabilistic methods in engineering, including reliability and performance-based design under reliability constraints, particularly in earthquake engineering. He has contributed to many projects in which probabilistic applications were central. Among them: ice loadings and iceberg impacts for the Hibernia and Terranova oil platforms; ice loadings and geotechnical implications for the Confederation Bridge in Prince Edward Island; collision with bridge piers for several bridges across the Fraser River in British Columbia; and combination of earthquake loadings and vessel collisions for movable bridges in Victoria, BC.

Dr. Foschi was also responsible for the reliability calibration of the Canadian CSA Code for wood construction, and has been a member of the ISO Committee for Reliability of Arctic Structures.

Dr. Foschi is a Fellow of the Canadian Society for Civil Engineering, and has received several awards, among them: the Marcus Wallenberg International Prize for contributions to reliability and mathematical models for wood, and the Canadian Society for Civil Engineering’s Gzowsky and Leipholz medals.


Peter S. Hatfield, P.Eng

Peter Hatfield completed his B.Sc. studies in Naval Architecture at the University of Durham, U.K. Presently retired and acting as a part time consultant, he has accumulated vast experience in design office management; design project management; concept and final design of commercial, government, fishing, passenger and special purpose vessels; arctic petroleum exploration vessels; production equipment design; studies and reports regarding marine vessel and equipment operations; stability reports; vessel surveys; legal consultation, expert witness in court cases involving marine projects and operations.

Early work by Peter Hatfield included assignments with John Brandlmayr Ltd., Naval Architects, Vancouver, B.C. (1958 – 1961) and Sparkman & Stephens Inc., Naval Architects, New York, N.Y., U.S.A. (1961-63). This work was followed, in 1963, by a short term assignment with the Food & Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations, on the design and construction of fishing vessels in Thailand.

From 1969 to 1973 Peter was Partner in Cove, Hatfield and Company Ltd., North Vancouver, B.C., as Naval architect responsible for design projects such as tugs, barges, fishing vessels, special purpose craft; general marine consulting.

As President of Peter S. Hatfield Ltd. (PHL), Naval Architects, Marine Engineers & Marine Consultants, Vancouver, BC., from 1973 to 2004, he has been responsible for general administration of all consulting activities both domestic and international, new business development, joint venture management, quality of Company work and client satisfaction, direct supervision and coordination of office projects and staff.

From August 2004 to July 2006 Peter also acted as Senior Consultant, BMT Fleet Technology Limited, following their acquisition of PHL in 2004.

Peter won the Council of Marine Carriers Legacy Award in 2011 for services to the West Coast Towboat Industry.


Brian Gunn, P.Eng

Brian Gunn is a retired Professional Engineer. He graduated with a BASc (civil engineering) from UBC in 1962 and received his P.Eng in 1965.  Brian’s engineering work experience began in 1963 with construction supervision for Canadian Comstock of the CN Mt Jarvis Aerial Tram to service a trans-Canada microwave Network. From 1965 to 1985 Brian worked on small and large materials handling projects as a project manager for Swan Wooster Engineering, both in Canada and overseas. After Swan Wooster, Brian worked for 5 years with Westshore Terminals (WST) as their engineering and maintenance manager for the Roberts Bank coal handling facility in Tsawwassen, BC. He ended his full time engineering career working as WST’s project manager for the expansion phase 2b for 2.5 years as an independent consultant from 1990 – 1993.

In 1989 Brian started the Big Bar Guest Ranch in the Cariboo country of BC. During that period of time Brian became active in representing the members of the Cariboo, Chilcotin, Coast Tourism Association and the BC Guest Ranch Association on issues to do with tourism, particularly land use conflicts with other industries.

In 1998 Brian left the ranch and became the marketing manager and consultant on engineering matters for Strathcona Park Lodge and Outdoor Education Center located on Vancouver Island.

In 1999 Brian was instrumental in the formation of the BC the Wilderness Tourism Association (WTA), representing nature-based tourism operators on land and marine use concerns. Brian was elected president of WTA in 1999 and remained in that role until 2012.  He is now Past President and is still active in advocacy work.


Chris J. Peter, P.Eng

Chris’s area of expertise lies in energy efficient design for cold climates. He has been actively involved in building systems energy modelling since development of the early software programs in the 1980’s.

Upon graduation in Engineering from the University of Toronto in 1981, Chris was one of five energy conservation engineers carrying out energy retrofits to school buildings for the Government of Alberta. His territory covered the northern third of the Province and during this time he designed extensive building envelope, controls, heating system upgrades and electrical modifications for 30 schools. 

In 1985, Chris joined the Government of the N.W.T. as a mechanical engineer in Iqaluit/Frobisher Bay and was involved in a wide variety of capital and operation and maintenance projects including water storage tank and distribution systems, district heating systems, government office buildings and heating system service specifications for Arctic municipalities. 

In 1987, Chris became project engineer with Stantec Engineering in Yellowknife. He undertook heating system energy metering, recreational facility, airport site works, school and health care facility, and office building renovations and design of bulk fuel storage facilities and firehalls. 

In 1989, Chris became project engineer with Williams Engineering in Edmonton, and was responsible for the mechanical engineering design on a variety of schools, airports, office buildings, health care facilities and district heating systems, the majority of which required specialized systems due to their remote location. 

Since 1994, Chris has been principal of C.J.Peter Associates Engineering, a mechanical engineering firm in Prince George, B.C. specializing in design and modelling of energy efficient mechanical systems and facilities throughout northern B.C.

This is our OLD campaign.  Check out the new one at:
www.igg.me/at/cpengineers2
If you believe Enbridge's numbers, the risks of a major spill are 10%If you don't believe their numbers, the risk only goes up Since when is 10% acceptable? We've performed our own, independent review and found Enbridge's analysis to be lacking.  Help us get the message out so that we can start a debate about the facts and what is an acceptable level of risk.
Enbridge provides no justification or documentation for the 'scaling factors' they used to calculate the 10% risk of a major spill.
Enbridge's liability ends when the tankers leave the terminal.  Who's responsible for a spill along the narrow 300 km waterway from Kitimat to the open ocean?
Enbridge's risk analysis planned for 220 tankers per year through Douglas Channel.  New LNG projects will bring that number to over 600.
Federal scientists, testifying during the JRP hearings, say more research is needed on diluted bitumen before they can be sure a cleanup is even possible.
This is not good engineering. Who we areConcerned Professional Engineers (CPE) is a small group of professional engineers living in British Columbia, Canada.  Together we have many decades of experience in the design, construction and operation of large projects for the extraction and transportation of natural resources like coal and oil. We share a deep concern for the environment and the future of this coast, this country and this planet.  With our backgrounds we are keenly aware of the inherent conflict between environmental protection and resource development proposed by large projects.We understand that we cannot end our dependence on resources tomorrow, and that it is important to propose practical, achievable solutions to these problems that strike an acceptable balance between economic development and risk to the environment.  We are not opposed to the development and export of natural resources, but we feel very strongly that these projects must be done in a safe and responsible manner, with a full accounting of the risks and visibility to the public.(Hartley Bay, Douglas Channel)What We Want to DoWe have spent the last two years investigating the risks posed by this project and participating in the National Energy Board's Joint Review Panel (NEB JRP) on Northern Gateway (NG).  We are now raising a small amount of money to launch an awareness campaign to help publicize our work.  This campaign will consist of:

story:
Test Your Tap & Make a Huge Impact 

Presented by the Clean Water Tour, the Hope2o water testing kit started with the simple idea of helping families find your best water source while creating an online community database for clean water. Developed by Blue Ocean Sciences LLC, Hope2o is a low-cost, accurate, and robust testing solution that offers you two water tests in one box: one for tap water and another for filtered water. Once our independent lab receives your drinking water samples, we test for a broad range of contaminants including organic chemicals, heavy metals, pesticides, and pharmaceuticals in each source. The easy-to-read results are emailed to you and released visually in the first "online water map" through our secure network.

With natural disasters, aging infrastructure, and new pollutants introduced into the environment daily, can we afford to take the quality of our water for granted? In order for us to truly understand our clean water supply, to anticipate and get ahead of any problems, we need to have more accurate real-time information. Hope2o is providing you with access to reliable water data for where you live, work and play with the ongoing membership to the community-driven online water data. 

Help us map the world's water -one family at a time.


Hope2o is Simple and Robust. 

                  

                  

                  

                  

                

Contribute to Science

Blue Ocean Sciences' mission is to address the needs of the global community. We help solve large-scale ocean and fresh water challenges through advanced and innovative technologies. We are collaborating with experts and combining the latest in knowledge, technology and validated scientific information to find solutions to today's biggest environmental problems -- and water is one of our biggest issues. This is why we developed Hope2o and the first online global mapping system for water.

Help Advance your Community 

The Hope2o water testing kit is mapping the world's water while also giving you the most affordable and comprehensive water testing solution on the market today.  Most people don't realize that when your water leaves the municipality, down line pipes are rarely tested. With Hope2o, you will gain peace of mind knowing the quality of your drinking water and that your filter is working properly. You will also gain the satisfaction of knowing you are helping to solve our water problems by contributing your test results anonymously to science. 

How it works

We send you a Hope2o testing kit. Each kit allows for two samples. We want you to be able to test your tap and your filtered water. We will send you an email with your results along with access to the online water map so you can see and track your water data and others all around the globe. (All data is anonymous.) 

You will also find out first about our latest discoveries, participate in ongoing discussions and be able to ask questions and interact with our science and technology team. 

Concentration of Arsenic in water in the US

      

Concentration of Cadmium in water in the US

For International

We will send you a kit that allows for two samples as well. There will also be an additional form to be completed and submitted in returning the samples to us. Details will be included in your box. (There is an extra fee of $15-$25 for all international shipping as indicated.)

The Impact

The proceeds from this crowd funding will go towards building the infrastructure and service levels for Hope2o, to support the Hope2o community, and position the company to scale on an international level. 

Your support will help . . . 

  • Integrate the online real-time mapping system with existing data from the USGS and the EPA to establish trends both past and future
  • Improve and expand the user interface and capabilities of the Hope2o online community site
  • Develop an iPhone app for the community
  • Start testing other fresh water sources that impact our foods and other communities

For the same amount, you can also donate kits so that others can benefit from  Hope2o. Please contact us for details or questions.


Help us spread the word about Hope2o! 


If you have ideas for media, mailing lists, newsletters or people who may be interested in sponsorships or partnerships, please contact us.

story:
Short Summary

During ongoing climate and ecological research in the Peruvian Andes, a team of experts have uncovered ancient history, and with it, the means to protect one of the world's natural treasures.

Mission

With your help, I hope to join an expedition that proposes to conduct a preliminary archeological survey in the Andes mountains near Cusco, Peru (elevation 16,000-19,000+ft) in the area of our discovery. This project is a timely matter as the region is being actively threatened by mining in sensitive watershed areas that will cause damage to the fragile alpine ecosystem and to a sacred Incan ceremonial complex. By capturing this piece of history we can act to protect both a truly remarkable landscape and an important piece of history, saving it for future generations and educational opportunities.

Impact

A multidimensional project, there is a little something for everyone:

- Archeological Discoveries in Foreign Lands!
Who hasn't dreamed of being Indiana Jones for a day? Located in the mountains just outside of Cusco, Peru, we will be exploring a newly identified Incan ceremonial complex. This complex is thought to include lost temples, burial grounds, ceremonial sites, artifacts, etc. All sites and finds will be thoroughly documented, including by video, adding to the rich history of the region and our understanding of pre-existing cultures. 

                 

- Environmental Preservation
The mountains in this region are currently being threatened by new, active mining. In fact, mine prospecting is now occurring only a half mile from the watershed. The fragile alpine eco-systems of these areas cannot sustain the practice of mining, and the sensitive watershed may be destroyed if the mining advances. By documenting this incredible history (as outlined above) we will be able to submit this area for historical protection from the mining that so threatens the landscape. Don't let this natural beauty be wasted!


        


- Adventure - Mountaineering, Rock Climbing, Diving, Kayaking and more! 
Due to the nature of location, all of this work will have to be done at elevations up to ~19,500ft, many parts of which are largely unexplored. Moreover, much of the lost remains are situated under current lakes and our work will be conducted during the Winter season. Using advanced technologies, gear, and highly skilled mountaineers, climbers, divers, and more, we are more than prepared to tackle these conditions head-on. In fact, we have documented success having led scouting trips to the region in several previous years, one of which set a World Record for diving depth at altitude. (2013)


- Biomedical Research
Due to the extreme nature of these conditions, and unexplored effects of diving at altitude, with our team of physicians and medical researchers we will be able to monitor the physiological effects and responses to such conditions. Additionally, we may continue to explore biological effects at elevation.

What We Need 

This expedition is run on volunteers, and in order to join the crew as one of the mountaineers/kayakers and research assistants I need to raise funds to cover the associated costs.

- Airfare/cargo to Peru, $1400.00
- Local travel (in Peru), $350.00
- On site land costs (horses, horse/cargo handlers, food, shelter, etc.), $1850.00
- Specialized gear for high altitude, mountain and water expeditions, $750.00
- Administrative costs (covers % to Indiegogo, photography, etc.), $850.00

Total: $5200.00 

Please keep in mind 100% of my time is volunteered! 

My credentials: Medical Researcher, Former Wilderness Guide, Photographer

   


What You Get

We hope that restoring the history, educational value, and environmental preservation serve as a worthy cause, but as an additional 'Thank You!' I have put together the following:

Individual Sponsorships:
$5.00 - Email updates pre-post expedition with photos and details of the journey.
$10.00 - A special thank you acknowledgement listed in the email updates pre-post expedition with photos and details of the journey.
$20.00 - A personal thank you postcard from location in Peru, and email updates pre/post-expedition.
$25.00 - One small photo print (8x10) of your choice (selection provided) from the expedition, and email updates pre/post-expedition.
$50.00 - One medium photo print (11x14 or similar w/ varying height/width) of your choice (selection provided) from the expedition and email updates pre/post-expedition.
$75.00 - One small photo on canvas (8x10) of your choice (selection provided) from the expedition and email updates pre/post-expedition.
$100.00 - One medium photo on canvas (11x14 or similar w/ varying height/width) of your choice (selection provided) from the expedition and email updates pre/post expedition.
$250.00 - One large photo on canvas (16x20 or similar) from the expedition and email updates pre/post expedition.
$500.00 - Two large photos on canvas (16x20 or similar) from the expedition and email updates pre/post expedition.

Corporate Sponsorships: 
Sponsor, $500: Opportunity to promote your company via expedition updates.
Senior Sponsor, $1000: Opportunity to promote your company via expedition updates and via video documentary.
$1500 or more: Contact for special opportunities.

Risks & Challenges

The very nature of this project lends itself to challenges, most notably the weather and high elevation. However, with highly advanced gear, technologies, experience and physical training, we have documented success in tackling these challenges. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    While we really hope you can help support our project by funding us, we understand that sometimes you just aren't able to swing it financially. Or maybe you'd rather donate materials/goods/miles instead. Either way, here is a list of ways you can help us outside of donating monies:

    - Donate air miles.
    - Donate gear (please contact us for specific needs/sizes as req'd).
    - Most of all, PLEASE SHARE OUR FUNDRAISER LINK!!! :)

    Thank You!
    Sincerely,
    Trish Zornio & The Peruvian Expedition Team, 2014

story:
Who we are?

The Zoological Foundation of El Salvador (FUNZEL) is a nonprofit, non-governmental organization that was founded on May 18, 1992. Our purpose is to protect and conserve wildlife in El Salvador, developing research programs, rehabilitation of species, veterinary medical care, environmental education and awareness of various sectors of the population in order to avoid traffic and tenure of wild animals as pets and/or in captivity.

FUNZEL has a very wide experience in the field of wildlife conservation, it is the only NGO focused on the conservation of species and also with the great contribution of including veterinary medicine as a biology tool for conservation. As such, FUNZEL has made efforts to conserve birds, mammals, amphibians and reptiles.

In recent years, FUNZEL has specialized in the implementation of programs and projects for the conservation of wildlife and their ecosystems, focusing special efforts on coastal marine resources of the country for the conservation of the 4 species of sea turtles that nest on the Salvadoran coast: The hawksbill sea turtle (Eretmochelys imbricata), The olive Ridley sea turtle (Lepidochelys olivacea), The leatherback sea turtle (Dermochelys coriacea) and the green sea turtle (Chelonia mydas agassizzi). 

The Maculis is a beach at low tide you can find exposed rock surface, where tide pools form, which makes it an ideal spawning habitat for hawksbill turtles. In recent years we have released 2,947 hawksbill hatchlings taking a hatching success of 78%. Also, studies have recently confirmed that 70% of the eastern Pacific hawksbill turtles nest on the Salvadoran coast. Because of this we want to strengthen our efforts in that hawksbill beach this season.


How do we operate?

Hatcheries were built at different beaches along the Salvadoran coast. A staff of certified biologists leads them free technical training to coastal communities in the areas of conservation and community development. During the nesting season, eggs from collectors in the pens are received, and are recognized for their work economically, as the number of eggs supplied to the growers, and according to the rules and regulations of the authorities environment, this in order to replace the traditional marketing model of turtle eggs for human consumption, which historically meant a source of income for collectors and their families.


What do we need?

Despite the advantages of working together with coastal communities, there is always vital needs for the success of hatcheries in each nesting season and liberation. For the 2014 season is no exception, so we need the following resources:

  • Material for the construction and maintenance of hatcheries.
  • Fuel for transport construction material, technical personnel, veterinary staff and equipment, and volunteers.
  • Maintenance of vehicles of the foundation.
  • Money to pay for the eggs collected by collectors of communities.
  • Payment of salary for a nursery-man, who is responsible for receiving, planting and care of hawksbill nests in the hatchery, as well as keep track of them.


What will you get?

By helping us you can choose any of the following perks,


"De carey somos todos".

Save a hawksbill hatchling one by one. With your donation of USD$25 you will receive a special thank you by email and we will release a hatchling in your name.


"Yo soy de playa y ellas también".

Because only one is not enough for you, and you want to give a gift to the sea. With your donation of USD$50 you will receive a special thank by email, a virtual certificate, and we will release six hatchlings in your name.


"El club de amigos de las tortugas marinas"

Because you feel so attached to sea turtles that they are like your family. With your donation of USD$100 you become part of FUNZEL´s friends club, and you'll receive: a membership card, special thanks by email, a virtual certificate and we will release 12 hatchlings in your name, or you can participate in a public release (transportation not included).


"Tortuga carey, la joya del mar"

Because for you hawksbills are so beautiful and valuable as a jewels of the ocean. With your donation of USD$500 you become part of FUNZEL´s friends club and you'll receive: a membership card, special thanks by email, a virtual and printed certificate, a T-shirt with turtle design, we will name and release a hatchling nest in your name (we will send photos), and/or you can participate with your family and friends in a private release (transportation from San Salvador included).


"¡Yo, el mar, soy vida!"

Because your love for sea turtles is so deep and infinite as the ocean itself. With your donation of USD$1000 you become part of FUNZEL's club of friends and will receive: a membership card, a special thanks video from our team, a FUNZEL kit that includes: two T-shirt for adults and two for childs, two turtle stickers and two turtle buttons. We will name and release a hatchling nest in your name (we will send photos), and/or you can participate with your family and friends in a private release (transportation from San Salvador included).


Note: Virtual releases are with hawksbills, if you choose to assist and participate in a release, these will be with olive ridley or green turtles, depending on availability, on a beach of you choice where a hatchery is working.e.


Impact

In the past 3 years we have managed to achieve a change in attitude unprecedented not only in coastal communities but also in the general population. Save the sea turtle is relevant as never before. Thanks to efforts like conservation program in 2009 a total and permanent ban on the use, possession and sale of eggs, and any other product of sea turtle was declared. But the job of keeping them does not end there. Every dollar raised is used directly for the protection and conservation of sea turtles, are constant and needs more care and support can save more turtles.

Please visit us on the beaches, to learn about our work and participate in a release of sea turtle hatchlings, to experience, to know its beauty and importance in ecosystems, and to understand the urgency of preventing their extinction.


Why Should I Help?

Only about 1 in 1000 hatchlings survive their first days of life. Some deaths are from natural causes, but many are caused by humans. Throughout his life embark on journeys of thousands of miles, traveling between countries, oceans and international waters, this makes them one of the few global animal. Are exposed to many hazards, such as fishing nets, poaching and pollution of the seas. Sea turtles have lived on Earth for over 150 million years, but if we do not act soon, may disappear.


Risks and Challenges

Currently our greatest challenge is to continue the marine conservation program along the Salvadoran coast turtle. There are many organizations doing similar projects in some beaches but none achieved such a impact nationally and us. We want to go ahead and consolidate these efforts, we know that with the support of many we can make a real impact and allow hawksbill continue visiting the Salvadoran coast.

Thanks to the support of people like you, and companies that understand the importance of preserving the hawksbill, we achieved overcome many challenges, and we trust you today to continue our hard but rewarding work.


Other ways you can help

Beside donations, there are other ways to help:

  • Volunteering and donating your time for turtles.
  • Purchase our promotional turtle motif.
  • Share this campaign with your friends and family.


_______________________________________


¿Quiénes somos?

La Fundación Zoológica de El Salvador (FUNZEL), es una organización no gubernamental sin fines de lucro fundada en 1992. Nuestro propósito es el de proteger y conservar la fauna silvestre en El Salvador, desarrollando programas de investigación, rehabilitación de especies, atención médico-veterinaria, educación ambiental y sensibilización de diversos sectores de la población con el propósito de evitar el tráfico y tenencia de animales silvestres como mascotas y/o en cautiverio.

En los últimos años, FUNZEL se ha especializado en la ejecución de programas y proyectos de conservación de vida silvestre y sus ecosistemas, enfocando especiales esfuerzos en los recursos costero marino del país, orientados a la conservación de las 4 especies de tortugas marinas que anidan en las costas salvadoreñas: Carey (Eretmochelys imbricata), Golfina (Lepidochelys olivácea), Baule (Dermochelys coriácea) y Prieta (Chelonia mydas agassizii).

FUNZEL trabaja en toda la costa salvadoreña, desde la Playa El Maculis, La Unión hasta Barra de Santiago, Ahuachapán. Durante la temporada 2012-13, la cobertura alcanzó a 19 corrales con la incubación de 969,372 huevos de las cuatro especies de tortuga marina y liberando 871,698 crías, lo que significó el 90% de éxito de eclosión.

El Maculis es una playa que durante la marea baja se puede encontrar una superficie rocosa expuesta, en las cuales se forman pozas intermareales, lo cual lo vuelve un hábitat ideal para el desove de tortugas carey. En los últimos años hemos liberado 2,947 neonatos de carey, teniendo un éxito de eclosión del 78%. Así mismo, estudios realizados recientemente han confirmado que el 70% de las tortugas carey del pacifico oriental anidan en la costa salvadoreña. Debido a esto queremos reforzar nuestros esfuerzos con la tortuga carey en dicha playa durante esta temporada.


¿Cómo operamos?

Se construyen corrales de incubación en distintas playas a lo largo de la costa salvadoreña. Un staff de biólogos certificados les lleva capacitación técnica gratuita a las comunidades costeras, en las áreas de conservación y desarrollo comunitario. Durante la época de anidación, se reciben los huevos de parte de los recolectores en los corrales, y se les reconoce económicamente por el trabajo realizado, según la cantidad de huevos entregados a los viveristas, y de acuerdo a las normas y disposiciones de las autoridades de medio ambiente, esto con el objetivo de reemplazar el tradicional modelo de comercialización de huevos de tortuga para consumo humano, el cual históricamente significaba una fuente de ingresos para los recolectores y sus familias.


¿Que necesitamos?

A pesar de las ventajas que supone trabajar en conjunto con las comunidades costeras, siempre hay necesidades vitales para el éxito de los corrales de incubación en cada temporada de anidación y liberación. Para la temporada 2014 no es la excepción, por lo cual necesitamos los recursos siguientes:

  • Material para la construcción y mantenimiento del corral de incubación.
  • Combustible para transporte del material de construcción, personal técnico; personal y equipo veterinario; y voluntarios.
  • Mantenimiento de los vehículos de la fundación.
  • Dinero para la remuneración por los huevos recolectados por los recolectores de las comunidades.
  • Pago del sueldo para un viverista, quien es el encargado de la recepción, siembra y cuidados de los nidos de carey en el corral, así como de llevar un registro de los mismos.


¿Qué obtendrás?

Al ayudarnos en nuestra campaña, podrás optar a alguna de las siguientes recompensas, aunque sabemos que para ti proteger las tortugas marinas es en si mismo una recompensa.

  • “Carey somos todos”

Ayúdanos a salvar un neonato a la vez, con tu donación de USD$25 recibirás un especial agradecimiento por correo, y liberaremos un neonato en tu nombre.

  • “Yo soy de playa y ellas también”

Porque para ti no es suficiente una, y quieres darle un regalo al mar. Con tu donación de USD$50 recibirás un especial agradecimiento por correo, un diploma que podrás imprimir, y liberaremos 6 neonatos en tu nombre.

  • “El club de amigos de las tortugas marinas”

Te sientes tan unido a las tortugas que son como tu familia. Con tu donación de USD$100 formarás parte del club de amigos de FUNZEL y recibirás: un carnet acreditando tu membresía, un especial agradecimiento por correo, un diploma que podrás imprimir y liberaremos 12 neonatos en tu nombre, o podrás participar en una liberación (transporte no incluido).

  •  “Tortuga carey, la joya del mar”

Porque para ti las tortugas carey son bellas y valiosas como una joya adornando el océano. Con tu donación de USD$500 formarás parte del club de amigos de FUNZEL y recibirás: un carnet acreditando tu membresía, un especial agradecimiento por correo, un diploma que podrás imprimir, una camisa con diseño de tortuga, nombraremos y liberaremos un nido completo en tu nombre (te enviaremos fotos), o podrás participar junto a tu familia o amigos de una liberación privada* (transporte no incluido).

  •  “¡Yo, el mar, soy vida!”

Tu amor por las tortugas es tan profundo he infinito como el mismo océano. Con tu donación de USD$1000 formarás parte del club de amigos de FUNZEL y recibirás: un carnet acreditando tu membresía, un video agradecimiento especial de parte del equipo de la fundación, un kit FUNZEL que incluye: una camisa para adulto y otra de niño, un sticker de tortuga y un botón. Nombraremos y liberaremos un nido completo en tu nombre (te enviaremos fotos), o podrás participar junto a tu familia o amigos de una liberación privada* (transporte no incluido).


*Nota: Las liberaciones virtuales serán de tortugas carey y las presenciales serán con tortuga golfina y/o prieta, según disponibilidad, en una playa de El Salvador de tú elección donde se encuentre un corral de incubación funcionando.


El impacto

En los últimos 3 años hemos logrado alcanzar un cambio de actitud sin precedentes, no solo en las comunidades costeras sino también en la población en general. Conservar la tortuga marina tiene relevancia como nunca antes. Gracias a esfuerzos como el programa de conservación en 2009 se declaró una veda total y permanente al consumo, tenencia y comercialización de huevos, y cualquier otro subproducto de tortuga marina. Pero el trabajo de conservarlas no termina ahí. Cada dólar recaudado es usado directamente para la protección y conservación de las tortugas marinas, las necesidades son constantes y con más apoyo podemos cuidar y salvar más tortugas.

Les invitamos a visitarnos en las playas, para poder conocer de cerca nuestro trabajo y participar en una liberación de neonatos de tortuga marina, para vivir la experiencia, conocer su belleza e importancia en los ecosistemas, y para entender la urgencia de prevenir su extinción.


¿Por Que Ayudar?

Aproximadamente sólo 1 de cada 1000 neonatos sobreviven sus primeros días de vida. Algunas muertes son por causas naturales, pero muchos son causados ​​por los seres humanos. A lo largo de su vida se embarcan en viajes de miles de kilómetros, viajando entre países, océanos y aguas internacionales, esto las vuelve uno de los pocos animales globales. Están expuestas a  muchos peligros, como las redes de pesca, el saqueo de nidos y la contaminación de los mares. Las tortugas marinas han vivido en nuestro planeta por más de 150 millones de años, pero si no actuamos pronto, pueden llegar a desaparecer.


Riesgos y desafíos

Actualmente nuestro mayor desafío es darle continuidad al programa de conservación de tortuga marina a lo largo de la costa salvadoreña. Existen muchas organizaciones realizando proyectos similares en algunas playas pero ninguna a logrado tal impacto a escala nacional como nosotros. Queremos seguir adelante y consolidar estos esfuerzos, sabemos que con el apoyo de muchos podremos lograr un impacto real y permitirle a las carey seguir visitando las costas salvadoreñas.

Gracias al apoyo de personas como tú, y de empresas que entienden la importancia de conservar a las carey, hemos logrado sobrepasar muchos desafíos, y hoy confiamos en ti para poder continuar nuestra ardua pero gratificante labor.


Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

A parte de las donaciones, existen otras formas de ayudarnos:

  • Siendo voluntario y donando tu tiempo para las tortugas.
  • Compra de nuestros promocionales con motivos de tortuga marina.
  • Compartir esta campaña con sus amistades y su familia.

With your donation of USD$500 you become part of FUNZEL´s friends club and you'll receive: a membership card, special thanks by email, a virtual and printed certificate, a T-shirt with turtle design, we will name and release a hatchling nest in your name (we will send photos), and/or you can participate with your family and friends in a private release (transportation from San Salvador included)."¡Yo, el mar, soy vida!"Because your love for sea turtles is so deep and infinite as the ocean itself. With your donation of USD$1000 you become part of FUNZEL's club of friends and will receive: a membership card, a special thanks video from our team, a FUNZEL kit that includes: two T-shirt for adults and two for childs, two turtle stickers and two turtle buttons. We will name and release a hatchling nest in your name (we will send photos), and/or you can participate with your family and friends in a private release (transportation from San Salvador included).Note: Virtual releases are with hawksbills, if you choose to assist and participate in a release, these will be with olive ridley or green turtles, depending on availability, on a beach of you choice where a hatchery is working.e.
ImpactIn the past 3 years we have managed to achieve a change in attitude unprecedented not only in coastal communities but also in the general population. Save the sea turtle is relevant as never before. Thanks to efforts like conservation program in 2009 a total and permanent ban on the use, possession and sale of eggs, and any other product of sea turtle was declared. But the job of keeping them does not end there. Every dollar raised is used directly for the protection and conservation of sea turtles, are constant and needs more care and support can save more turtles.Please visit us on the beaches, to learn about our work and participate in a release of sea turtle hatchlings, to experience, to know its beauty and importance in ecosystems, and to understand the urgency of preventing their extinction.Why Should I Help?Only about 1 in 1000 hatchlings survive their first days of life. Some deaths are from natural causes, but many are caused by humans. Throughout his life embark on journeys of thousands of miles, traveling between countries, oceans and international waters, this makes them one of the few global animal. Are exposed to many hazards, such as fishing nets, poaching and pollution of the seas. Sea turtles have lived on Earth for over 150 million years, but if we do not act soon, may disappear.Risks and ChallengesCurrently our greatest challenge is to continue the marine conservation program along the Salvadoran coast turtle. There are many organizations doing similar projects in some beaches but none achieved such a impact nationally and us. We want to go ahead and consolidate these efforts, we know that with the support of many we can make a real impact and allow hawksbill continue visiting the Salvadoran coast.Thanks to the support of people like you, and companies that understand the importance of preserving the hawksbill, we achieved overcome many challenges, and we trust you today to continue our hard but rewarding work.Other ways you can helpBeside donations, there are other ways to help:

Volunteering and donating your time for turtles.


Purchase our promotional turtle motif.


Share this campaign with your friends and family.

_______________________________________¿Quiénes
somos?
La Fundación Zoológica de El Salvador (FUNZEL), es una
organización no gubernamental sin fines de lucro fundada en 1992. Nuestro
propósito es el de proteger y conservar la fauna silvestre en El Salvador,
desarrollando programas de investigación, rehabilitación de especies, atención
médico-veterinaria, educación ambiental y sensibilización de diversos sectores
de la población con el propósito de evitar el tráfico y tenencia de animales
silvestres como mascotas y/o en cautiverio.
En los últimos años, FUNZEL se ha especializado en la
ejecución de programas y proyectos de conservación de vida silvestre y sus
ecosistemas, enfocando especiales esfuerzos en los recursos costero marino del
país, orientados a la conservación de las 4 especies de tortugas marinas que
anidan en las costas salvadoreñas: Carey (Eretmochelys
imbricata), Golfina (Lepidochelys
olivácea), Baule (Dermochelys
coriácea) y Prieta (Chelonia mydas
agassizii).
FUNZEL trabaja en toda la costa salvadoreña, desde la Playa
El Maculis, La Unión hasta Barra de Santiago, Ahuachapán. Durante la temporada
2012-13, la cobertura alcanzó a 19 corrales con la incubación de 969,372 huevos
de las cuatro especies de tortuga marina y liberando 871,698 crías, lo que
significó el 90% de éxito de eclosión.
El Maculis es una playa que durante la marea baja se puede
encontrar una superficie rocosa expuesta, en las cuales se forman pozas
intermareales, lo cual lo vuelve un hábitat ideal para el desove de tortugas
carey. En los últimos años hemos liberado 2,947 neonatos de carey, teniendo un
éxito de eclosión del 78%. Así mismo, estudios realizados recientemente han
confirmado que el 70% de las tortugas carey del pacifico oriental anidan en la
costa salvadoreña. Debido a esto queremos reforzar nuestros esfuerzos con la
tortuga carey en dicha playa durante esta temporada.¿Cómo
operamos?
Se construyen corrales de incubación en distintas playas a
lo largo de la costa salvadoreña. Un staff de biólogos certificados les lleva
capacitación técnica gratuita a las comunidades costeras, en las áreas de
conservación y desarrollo comunitario. Durante la época de anidación, se
reciben los huevos de parte de los recolectores en los corrales, y se les
reconoce económicamente por el trabajo realizado, según la cantidad de huevos
entregados a los viveristas, y de acuerdo a las normas y disposiciones de las
autoridades de medio ambiente, esto con el objetivo de reemplazar el
tradicional modelo de comercialización de huevos de tortuga para consumo
humano, el cual históricamente significaba una fuente de ingresos para los recolectores
y sus familias.¿Que necesitamos?A pesar de las ventajas que supone trabajar en conjunto con
las comunidades costeras, siempre hay necesidades vitales para el éxito de los
corrales de incubación en cada temporada de anidación y liberación. Para la
temporada 2014 no es la excepción, por lo cual necesitamos los recursos
siguientes:


Material para la construcción y mantenimiento
del corral de incubación.


Combustible para transporte del material de
construcción, personal técnico; personal y equipo veterinario; y voluntarios.


Mantenimiento de los vehículos de la fundación.


Dinero para la remuneración por los huevos
recolectados por los recolectores de las comunidades.

Pago del sueldo para un viverista, quien es el
encargado de la recepción, siembra y cuidados de los nidos de carey en el
corral, así como de llevar un registro de los mismos.
¿Qué obtendrás?Al ayudarnos en nuestra campaña, podrás optar a alguna de las siguientes recompensas, aunque sabemos que para ti proteger las tortugas marinas es en si mismo una recompensa.
“Carey
somos todos”
Ayúdanos a salvar un neonato a la
vez, con tu donación de USD$25 recibirás un especial agradecimiento por correo, y liberaremos
un neonato en tu nombre.


“Yo soy
de playa y ellas también”


Porque para ti no es suficiente
una, y quieres darle un regalo al mar. Con tu donación de USD$50 recibirás un especial
agradecimiento por correo, un diploma que podrás imprimir, y liberaremos 6
neonatos en tu nombre.


“El club
de amigos de las tortugas marinas”


Te sientes tan unido a las tortugas
que son como tu familia. Con tu donación de USD$100 formarás parte del club de amigos de
FUNZEL y recibirás: un carnet acreditando tu membresía, un especial
agradecimiento por correo, un diploma que podrás imprimir y liberaremos 12
neonatos en tu nombre, o podrás participar en una liberación (transporte no
incluido).


 “Tortuga
carey, la joya del mar”


Porque para ti las tortugas carey son bellas
y valiosas como una joya adornando el océano. Con tu donación de USD$500 formarás parte
del club de amigos de FUNZEL y recibirás: un carnet acreditando tu membresía,
un especial agradecimiento por correo, un diploma que podrás imprimir, una
camisa con diseño de tortuga, nombraremos y liberaremos un nido completo en tu
nombre (te enviaremos fotos), o podrás participar junto a tu familia o
amigos de una liberación privada* (transporte no incluido).


 “¡Yo, el
mar, soy vida!”


Tu amor por las tortugas es tan
profundo he infinito como el mismo océano. Con tu donación de USD$1000 formarás parte del
club de amigos de FUNZEL y recibirás: un carnet acreditando tu membresía, un video
agradecimiento especial de parte del equipo de la fundación, un kit FUNZEL que
incluye: una camisa para adulto y otra de niño, un sticker de tortuga y un botón. Nombraremos y liberaremos un nido completo en tu nombre (te enviaremos fotos), o podrás participar junto a tu familia o amigos de una liberación privada* (transporte no incluido).

*Nota:
Las liberaciones virtuales serán de tortugas carey y las presenciales serán con
tortuga golfina y/o prieta, según disponibilidad, en una playa de El Salvador de
tú elección donde se encuentre un corral de incubación funcionando.

El impacto En los últimos 3 años hemos logrado alcanzar un cambio de
actitud sin precedentes, no solo en las comunidades costeras sino también en la
población en general. Conservar la tortuga marina tiene relevancia como nunca
antes. Gracias a esfuerzos como el programa de conservación en 2009 se declaró
una veda total y permanente al consumo, tenencia y comercialización de huevos,
y cualquier otro subproducto de tortuga marina. Pero el trabajo de conservarlas
no termina ahí. Cada dólar recaudado es usado directamente para la protección y
conservación de las tortugas marinas, las necesidades son constantes y con más
apoyo podemos cuidar y salvar más tortugas. 

Les invitamos a visitarnos en las playas, para
poder conocer de cerca nuestro trabajo y participar en una liberación de
neonatos de tortuga marina, para vivir la experiencia, conocer su belleza e importancia
en los ecosistemas, y para entender la urgencia de prevenir su extinción.¿Por Que
Ayudar?
Aproximadamente sólo 1 de cada 1000 neonatos sobreviven sus
primeros días de vida. Algunas muertes son por causas naturales, pero muchos
son causados ​​por los seres humanos. A lo largo de su vida se embarcan en
viajes de miles de kilómetros, viajando entre países, océanos y aguas
internacionales, esto las vuelve uno de los pocos animales globales. Están
expuestas a  muchos peligros, como las
redes de pesca, el saqueo de nidos y la contaminación de los mares. Las tortugas
marinas han vivido en nuestro planeta por más de 150 millones de años, pero si
no actuamos pronto, pueden llegar a desaparecer.Riesgos y desafíos  Actualmente nuestro mayor desafío es darle continuidad al programa de conservación de tortuga marina a lo largo de la costa salvadoreña. Existen muchas organizaciones realizando proyectos similares en algunas playas pero ninguna a logrado tal impacto a escala nacional como nosotros. Queremos seguir adelante y consolidar estos esfuerzos, sabemos que con el apoyo de muchos podremos lograr un impacto real y permitirle a las carey seguir visitando las costas salvadoreñas.Gracias al apoyo de personas como tú, y de empresas que entienden la importancia de conservar a las carey, hemos logrado sobrepasar muchos desafíos, y hoy confiamos en ti para poder continuar nuestra ardua pero gratificante labor.   Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar  A parte de las donaciones, existen otras formas de
ayudarnos:


Siendo voluntario y donando tu tiempo para las
tortugas.


Compra de nuestros promocionales con motivos de
tortuga marina.


Compartir esta campaña con sus amistades y su
familia.

story:
Black Mamba Environmental Education Officer, Lewyn Maefala requires a driving licence in order for her to expand the Bush Babies Environmental Education program throughout the communities bordering Kruger National Park. We need your help to fund her driving lesson's to enable her to take and pass her driving test.
In the 2 months that the Bush Babies Environmental Education Program has been running, Lewyn has established agreements to conduct weekly classes in three local schools. Enabling Lewyn to obtain her driving licence, she will then be able to expand the program further, visiting more schools, to teaching more lessons to the new generation of local conservationist every week.
Lewyn requires $300 to cover the cost of all lessons and driving test. Unfortunately we are unable to set a goal lower than $500 through this campaign and hope to reach are actual goal in the next 14 days. Any extra funds that we might receive will be put towards the Bush Babies Environmental Education Program. Below you can find more information about the Bush Babies Environmental Education Program and learn why it is imperative to the program that Lewyn is able to conduct the program in as many community based schools as possible, which can not be achieved without the ability to drive to the schools.

The Lesser bushbaby (Galago moholi) symbolises and defines the external environmental education awareness program, where learners are regarded as babies learning about the bush or environment. The name outlines the characteristics of the learners, such as big eyes that shine when caught in the light, similar to when the children gasp information their eyes widens when they learn about their surrounding environment. The habitat of the bushbaby also focuses on the different biomes that the children will be learning about and the components of these biomes. The Bushbabies Environmental Education Awareness Program is interlinked into the school curriculum which should build on the children’s interests and should explore the subject matter in a multi-disciplinary manner; therefore we should enhance a child’s skills and build on their present ideas through a program that provides for a multitude of opportunities for the child’s growth and development. 

Objectives of the Bushbabies Environmental Education Program:

  • Bringing knowledge to life

  • Raise awareness of their surrounding environment

  • Better understanding of conservation 

  • Behavioural change

  • Sustainable use of resources

  • Environmental problem- solving skills

  • Active participation in environment improvement

How to achieve these objectives:

  • Through hands on activities that allows them to interact with the environment

  • Through visual aids and other forms of communication

  • Through environmental  based videos

  • Being more practical with the learners by bringing things such as feathers, nests, animal skulls into the classroom based on the theme of the day.

  • Allowing the interaction amongst the learners to ensure the circulation of ideas and understanding.

  • Allowing the learners to explore and actively participate in the activities given to them.
