story:
The IUCN Annual Lake Swim 2011

The IUCN Annual Lake Swim began in 2006 when Jane Smart of IUCN swam across the lake together with Liz Radford of Plantlife, in memory of environmentalist and former IUCN Council Member Richard Sandbrook in aid of WaterAid. With the arrival of Julia Marton Lefèvre as Director General in 2007, the event was enthusiastically adopted as an annual one, with a team of swimmers from IUCN crossing the lake each year in aid of a good cause and in celebration of the beauties of nature. 

This year the swim will be held on Wednesday 3 August (or Thursday 4 August - depending on the weather). We will swim from Nernier in France to Prangins, near Nyon in Switzerland. The distance is 4.24 km - although in reality the distance will be nearer 6 km - because it is never possible to swim in a completely straight line!

In 2011 we will raising funds in aid of The People of Japan following the tragic events which took place in March of this year. Specifically, we will raise funds for the Red Cross Society of Japan. All the funds raised through this website will go directly to the people affected on the ground. IUCN has a strong friendship with Japan - not least in admiration for the leadership shown by Japanese colleagues during the 10th meeting of the Biodiversity Convention's Conference of the Parties (CBD COP10). We have a fundraising aim of $3000; we hope that our colleagues and friends in the IUCN family of Members, Commissions and Secretariat will give generously to this important cause.  

 IUCN (www.iucn.org) promotes 'nature-based solutions' to disaster risk reduction; for the future IUCN urges all countries to consider the role of nature in relation to minimising the damage from natural disasters; we hope that by swimming across the Lake we will be highlighting both the unique role of nature and the joy of interacting with nature.
story_txt:
The IUCN Annual Lake Swim 2011
The IUCN Annual Lake Swim began in 2006 when Jane Smart of IUCN swam across the lake together with Liz Radford of Plantlife, in memory of environmentalist and former IUCN Council Member Richard Sandbrook in aid of WaterAid. With the arrival of Julia Marton Lefèvre as Director General in 2007, the event was enthusiastically adopted as an annual one, with a team of swimmers from IUCN crossing the lake each year in aid of a good cause and in celebration of the beauties of nature. 
This year the swim will be held on Wednesday 3 August (or Thursday 4 August - depending on the weather). We will swim from Nernier in France to Prangins, near Nyon in Switzerland. The distance is 4.24 km - although in reality the distance will be nearer 6 km - because it is never possible to swim in a completely straight line!
In 2011 we will raising funds in aid of The People of Japan following the tragic events which took place in March of this year. Specifically, we will raise funds for the Red Cross Society of Japan. All the funds raised through this website will go directly to the people affected on the ground. IUCN has a strong friendship with Japan - not least in admiration for the leadership shown by Japanese colleagues during the 10th meeting of the Biodiversity Convention's Conference of the Parties (CBD COP10). We have a fundraising aim of $3000; we hope that our colleagues and friends in the IUCN family of Members, Commissions and Secretariat will give generously to this important cause.  
 IUCN (www.iucn.org) promotes 'nature-based solutions' to disaster risk reduction; for the future IUCN urges all countries to consider the role of nature in relation to minimising the damage from natural disasters; we hope that by swimming across the Lake we will be highlighting both the unique role of nature and the joy of interacting with nature.

story:
300 New trees for Streatham!

Because of the current economic climate no funds have been available to plant new trees in Streatham for more than four years. So in August 2013 a coalition of 11 community groups led by the Streatham Bridge Business Association's Lane & Vale campaign was formed to make an application to the Mayor of London's Street Tree Initiative. 

We were successful in our bid, and have been offered £67,500 of the £135,000 we need to plant 300 trees across Streatham by the end of February 2013. 

Lambeth Council is working to find the lions share of the match funding we require, but we have been asked to raise as much money as we can to cover any shortfall in funding, hence this campaign.

Where will we plant trees?

38 members of the public identified 68 streets and 61 historically empty tree bays, each street is marked on this map http://batchgeo.com/map/LaneAndValeTrees. 
We will aim to fill empty tree bays and soft ground first while the streets are surveyed to see if the underground utilities will afford us enough space to plant trees.
If you'd like to submit your street for consideration email contact@laneandvale.org.uk.

What we need

We are looking for £3150 or more, which, because of the 50% match funding is enough to plant sixteen trees, each additional £225 buys Streatham another tree. 

Because the streets have not been surveyed yet, we cannot guarantee that your donation will get your street a tree. What we can guarantee is that Streatham will get more trees - which can only be a good thing!

  • Even if we don't raise £3150 each £225 will get Streatham a new tree.
  • Anyone who makes a donation will get their name on an honour roll, and be invited to the first tree planting ceremony.

Want to know more?

Visit http://laneandvale.org.uk/trees for more complete information on the funding and plan.

story:
My name is Polina and I am a 10th grader in the Bay Area, California. I travelled to Costa Rica in 8th grade with my school and while there, I met a coffee plantation owner who built clean-burning stoves on the side. He told us why there is a need for clean-burning stoves in developing countries in the world: the leading cause of death in children under 5 in many Latin-American countries is respiratory diseases because of the deadly fumes from cooking over an open fire. 

I was very moved by this fact, and I had also previously gone to Guatemala with an organization and interacted directly with the wonderful families of the highlands. This summer I will return to Guatemala but this time to volunteer with the Mayan Families organization to build clean burning stoves for families living in the rural highlands. These stoves not only save children and their families from carbon monoxide, but they also prevent children from getting burned on an open fire in their home, save women time and money because of its high fuel-efficiency, but also reduces wood use by 60-70% which means less deforestation! 

The materials for each stove cost $186 and my goal is to build at least 5 -- but I can’t do this without your help. Each dollar will go towards helping poor families save money, raising the life expectancy, reducing deforestation and air pollution, and saving the lives of children in the Guatemala highlands. 

If you are interested in helping more Guatemalan families and in more ways (education programs, shelter programs, medical care, etc..) visit www.mayanfamilies.org 

( images from https://helpsintl.org/)

story:
What's At Stake

Hawaiian rain forests are globally unique: 90% of our plants and animals are found nowhere else on the planet. For that same reason, the threat to our native ecosystems from invasive species is greater than anywhere else in the world. We need your help to protect our precious forests by "firing up" our local fight against one of the worst forest threats, an alien weed called kahili ginger.

Who We Are

On Kohala Mountain, on the north end of Hawaii Island (AKA the "Big Island"), the Kohala Watershed Partnership (KWP) is working to protect 50,000 acres of tropical rain forest, perpetuate Hawaiian biodiversity, and ensure the water supply for native ecosystems and human populations. Our nine partners represent a diverse coalition of land managers, including 5th-generation ranching families, land trusts from the Hawaiian nobility, as well as conservation organizations and State Natural Area Reserves. This partnership works together to address common threats to the forest of Kohala Mountain. 

What's a Ginger Ninja?

Here's the story behind our name: A group of local middle school students were volunteering with KWP to control invasive ginger in our forest this year. As you might imagine, it's pretty fun to swing a machete and hack down weeds. However, this group realized that the "samurai" approach was probably more destructive to the forest than it needed to be, so they coined the term "Ginger Ninja" to describe their stealthy but deadly assault on ginger, one of the most invasive weeds in our forests. The name stuck!

The Culprit

Native Hawaiian forests don't fit typical expectations of tropical rain forests elsewhere in the world; we have no monkeys, mice, panthers, or pythons. Here in Hawaii we have colorful tree snails, carnivorous caterpillars, curvy-beaked honeycreeper birds, and flowering plants of every size and shape. Native species in Hawaii evolved from plants and animals that made their way to our distant shores during the life time of our volcanic islands. Due to our remote location in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, the rate of new species introductions was about one new plant or animal every couple thousand years. In the 21st century, our ecosystems are being flooded with invaders from all parts of the globe, and we now measure the rate of introduction in weeks or months rather than millenia.

Kahili ginger is one of the worst invaders of all. It is a colorful, robust, sweet-scented flowering relative of that yummy stuff we put in stir-fry and cookies. It was originally brought here from northern India 100 years ago as a garden flower, but it spread into our forests, out-competing native species, and changing the flow of water through the ecosystem. It needs to be controlled, or we may lose our unique forests forever.

What's Being Done

KWP has a field crew of six, built over the years from people who have a passion for our native forests. Our funding comes from private foundations, government grants, and donations. We also have a corps of almost 300 volunteers, who come from all over the island and the world to help us with our work. Students from seven local schools also contribute their enthusiasm, time and sweat to protect Kohala's forests.

The Plan and The Imperative

We are seeking funding through this campaign to accelerate our kahili ginger control efforts. There are more than 50,000 acres of forest that have already been invaded by ginger, and we are a crew of six, spread across the mountain building fences, controlling feral animals, killing weeds, and planting trees. If we are to make a difference in this war on ginger, we need to deploy a team of ginger ninjas, to fight one battle at a time, to whittle away at the invasion, and protect the forest before it's too late.

Our goal is to raise at $20,000, which is half of what we need to win the first battle: to remove the ginger from at least 100 acres of native rain forest.If we raise more, we will do more! We will attack the ginger with our field crew and volunteers, and hire a team of local high school student interns this summer to ramp up the efforts. When we demonstrate the effectiveness of this effort (documented and mapped for everyone to see!), we can scale it up to more battles, in more areas, to protect more forest!

To find out more about our partnership, and to sign up as a volunteer, visit our website: http://kohalawatershed.org/. We also have a Facebook page, where we connect with volunteers and share information about other conservation projects in Hawaii. Check us out and "Like" our page! http://www.facebook.com/pages/Kohala-Watershed-Partnership/143212532421851

And, please. . . share our story! Forward email to friends, talk about it over coffee, and remember to hug a tree every day!

story:
Mexpé 2014 : l’exploration souterraine continue!


Une nouvelle expédition d’envergure est planifiée pour très bientôt dans la Sierra Negra. Ainsi, du 26 février au 30 mars 2014, une équipe internationale d’une vingtaine de spéléologues retournera sur le haut-plateau visité en 2013. Certains ambitionnent toujours d’y trouver un des gouffres les plus profonds du monde, surtout lorsqu’ils examinent une mystérieuse dépression à 2400 mètres d’altitude. Serait-ce des gouffres béants dans la jungle? Situé à deux heures de marche du bucolique village de Tequixtepec, notre camp de base dispose d’un relatif certain confort (toit avec accès facile à l’eau) mais pas d’électricité…

Auparavant, il faut terminer l’exploration des grottes explorées en 2013 : Chupa Pierna (-237 m) et Mosca Busca Pes (-273 m). Ensuite, plusieurs journées de labeur à la machette seront requises pour ouvrir un sentier praticable dans un terrain infernal serti de couteaux de pierre et envahi par une épaisse végétation pourrissante et instable…

Pour la grande histoire, Mexpé est un projet de la Société québécoise de spéléologie (SQS) qui a démarré en 1987. Depuis lors, des centaines de participants ont investi – bénévolement – temps et argent par passion pour l’exploration, la documentation et la cartographie du monde souterrain. Aujourd’hui, 27 ans après le début de cette épopée unique en son genre, les spéléologues du projet Mexpé vous demandent un appui stratégique à la poursuite de ce fascinant projet!

Vous fournissez l’énergie, on rapporte les kilomètres de galerie!


Presque trois décennies après le début du projet Mexpé, l’exploration spéléologique n’a pas tellement changé. Il faut chercher les entrées au cœur d’un terrain souvent hostile, installer les cordes, descendre, remonter, explorer, cartographier et documenter nos découvertes. Par contre, ce qui a grandement changé depuis les dernières années c’est notre dépendance à l'énergie électrique !

Notre objectif : recueillir 1 800$ pour augmenter l’efficacité de notre centrale solaire. Nous devons recharger les équipements suivant : perceuses à percussion, lampes frontales pour l’exploration, appareils de topographie souterraine, ordinateurs portables, imprimantes, système de radio à longue portée, téléphone satellite.

En tant que généreux donateur, vous serez aux premières loges de la découverte, vous serez tenu au courant de l’avancement des travaux. Pour les dons de 50 $ et plus, le donateur recevra une photo 8x12 dédicacée par l’équipe et illustrant les découvertes de 2014 (voir la section contreparties pour les détails).

Comme la Société québécoise de spéléologie est reconnue comme organisme de charité, vous recevrez un reçu aux fins d’impôt vous permettant d’obtenir des avantages fiscaux.

Des retombées diversifiées et concrètes


Fort d’une équipe solide et expérimentée, Mexpé 2014 a tous les effectifs et les compétences humaines pour atteindre ses objectifs d’exploration et de documentation du karst de la Sierra Negra.

Sur le plan spéléologique…

  • Depuis 1987, Mexpé a cartographié plus de 90 kilomètres de galeries souterraines;
  • découvert deux des plus importantes traversées souterraines des Amériques (Très Quimeras, -815 m et Sistema Tepepa, -842 m);
  • exploré sur plusieurs années, le Sistema Tepepa, avec ses douzaines d’entrées, se développe sur plus de 29 kilomètres.

Médiatiquement…

Étant le seul projet québécois du genre, Mexpé reçoit une attention médiatique toute particulière depuis ses tout débuts :

  • En 2007, un cahier complet de huit pages en couleur fut publié dans la Presse;

  • En 2012, deux participants de longue date du projet, Marc Tremblay et Guillaume Pelletier ont produit le documentaire « Attention! Traversée de gouffre mexicain » qui a a été présenté dans plusieurs festivals de film d’aventure.

Sur le plan humain…

  • Durant toutes ces expéditions, nous avons constamment développé une relation durable, solidaire et amicale avec les généreuses communautés locales qui nous accueillent année après année sur leur territoire.

Scientifiquement…

  • En 2009, lors de l’exploration du gouffre Tres Quimeras, nous avons rapporté des spécimens de scorpions cavernicoles alors inconnus. Aujourd’hui, grâce aux travaux du Dr. Oscar Francke, nous savons qu’il s’agit d’une nouvelle espèce.

En somme, les retombées du projet sont concrètes et confirment la crédibilité reconnue de la Société québécoise de spéléologie et de son projet Mexpé.

Une autre façon d’encourager le projet Mexpé


N’hésitez pas à passer le mot et faire la promotion de notre campagne de financement dans vos réseaux afin que la passion pour l’exploration reste contagieuse!

Retrouvez-nous sur Facebook

THANK YOU TO ALL OUR 300+ SUPPORTERS!

We launched our first episode online to draw attention to coastal communities before the U.N. climate talks in Paris. We have a formal letter of support from public television for a full series order (!), and are discussing partnerships with brands, networks and foundations about our first season.

Beyond entertainment, this is a social action campaign geared for IMPACT, so we are reaching out to press and encouraging leaders of America's largest coastal communities to promote their plans for preparedness and resilience. Partnering with top NGOs like The Nature Conservancy, Virgin Unite and other policymakers to influence reform, we also plan to help scale the great work done by the astonishing characters featured in our show.

Last Glimpse has hosted sold-out showings in San Francisco, Chicago, Brooklyn, D.C., Los Angeles, presented at Summit Series, and during the General Assembly of the United Nations in New York.

--- Our crew still has personal production and marketing costs to recoup and welcome your additional support. ---

Below is a 15 second teaser trailer for a peek at some of the footage we got. Fan us on Facebook to stay in touch and thanks again for your support!


Watch the original IndieGoGo Pitch Video here. Our original IndieGoGo campaign story is below....

The Maldives

Population: 345,023
Average elevation: 4 feet, 11 inches above sea level
Climate change disaster plan: re-locate the country.

While the islands of the Maldives are known as paradise to some, soon this nation could be known to the world as something different: the canary in the coal mine. A rise of just three feet in sea level will make the Maldives uninhabitable. The stark reality is that the science says it is going to happen -- and already, groundwater supplies are being polluted and portions of the coastline are eroding away. A national identity, a rich culture, an entire country could potentially be lost at sea.

Let's marvel at modern Atlantis in bittersweet beauty. Join us as we head to The Maldives this December to capture a #LastGlimpse!

WHAT is #LastGlimpse?

Our plan with this travel documentary is to not only show what makes this area so unique, but also raise awareness around the plight of the Maldivian people as the cornerstone of a global action-oriented campaign around climate change.

It's a bold idea to celebrate Maldivian culture, the people, the stories of this island nation before it may very well disappear. Along the way, we’ll introduce you to the restaurateur and her family, the fisherman and his boat, the traditions and the dance – the people whose lives are on the front-lines of climate impact. We seek to highlight each story through a lens of authenticity, as well as through a prism of hopeful futures.

WHO is #LastGlimpse?

Each member of the #LastGlimpse team has highly relevant backgrounds for the project; visit our about page here for full bios. We are Josh Burstein (Host), Ben Youngerman (Head of Production/Post), Ken Fisher (Story Architect), Maya Katherine (Engagement), Silvia Mahan (Producer) and Sundeep Ahuja (Exec Producer):

WHERE are the funds going?

Four of us will be on the ground late December into early January for about 12 days. Everyone is volunteering their time and gear for the project, and while an initiative like this would normally price out at $75k, we’re aiming to keep our entire travel and production budget to around $15K. Here’s how it breaks down:

Flights (long, economy class hauls): $8k
Lodging (sleeping on floors if we have to): $2k
Food & Water (grocery stores, not fancy restaurants): $2k
In-country transportation (interviews are spread across islands): $2k
Insurance & miscellaneous: $1k

We have some other projected costs including hiring a translator, specialty shots, and more, but we’re starting with a $15k goal to cover basic expenses (which it really won't, because of the costs we'll incur fulfilling perks!). We’ll of course cover all personal expenses out of our own pockets; every dime raised from this campaign will go 100% into the project or fulfilling perks.

PRE-ORDER TODAY & get perks!

We unconventionally decided that instead of raising private funds we wanted to invite our friends, family, and the broader Indiegogo community to JOIN us on this project. We’ll be blogging the experience at lastglimpse.org, sharing updates from on the ground and doing what we can to make it feel like YOU'RE THERE as part of the team. In exchange for your donations, we’ve got some great perks. Check ‘em out, pick what sings to you, and let's go capture a #LastGlimpse!

FAQ

Are you a non-profit?
Not yet, but we intend to be. If you’re looking to come in at a high value perk and would like a tax-deductible receipt, email us at lastglimpsedoc (at) gmail. We’re currently working to identify a Fiscal Sponsor.

How long will the documentary be?
We’re aiming for a 30-minute piece, but will cut various shorter lengths for as wide distribution as possible. We see the documentary as the cornerstone of a larger movement, and storytelling will be a big part of it.

I know someone in the Maldives who can help; who should I contact?
Fabulous! Please drop us a note at lastglimpsedoc (at) gmail and we’ll get in touch.

When can I expect to receive my perks?
We’re expecting to have a final cut of the documentary sometime in March or April. Our backers will be the first to receive it around then, at the same time as t-shirts, postcards, or anything else pre-ordered. We expect our initial screenings will take place at that time.

What if I buy a ticket to a screening but the date changes?
If we change the date and you can't make it, upon request we'll send you "The Doc PLUS" perk instead; if you ordered a VIP ticket, upon request we'll send you "The Home Viewing Party" perk and refund the $24 delta.

How do I win a free perk by sharing on Facebook or Twitter?
We'll be watching Facebook & Twitter for people sharing this campaign with the tag "#LastGlimpse" -- and when the campaign ends, we'll identify 3 winners for whom we’ll bring back a special something from The Maldives.

Share this campaign on Facebook or Twitter (use links up top) with #LastGlimpse for a chance to win free perks. THANK YOU!


Photo credits: https://www.flickr.com/photos/trodel/3599395828 | https://www.flickr.com/photos/nattu/2670211903 | https://www.flickr.com/photos/shazwan/8184849164 | https://www.flickr.com/photos/nattu/4401430914/in/photolist-71DpBy-7GWu4U-6aPgD7-5Bkd7d

Population: 345,023Average elevation: 4 feet, 11 inches above sea levelClimate change disaster plan: re-locate the country.While the islands of the Maldives are known as paradise to some, soon this nation could be known to the world as something different: the canary in the coal mine. A rise of just three feet in sea level will make the Maldives uninhabitable. The stark reality is that the science says it is going to happen -- and already, groundwater supplies are being polluted and portions of the coastline are eroding away. A national identity, a rich culture, an entire country could potentially be lost at sea.
Let's marvel at modern Atlantis in bittersweet beauty. Join us as we head to The Maldives this December to capture a #LastGlimpse!

WHAT is #LastGlimpse?
Our plan with this travel documentary is to not only show what makes this area so unique, but also raise awareness around the plight of the Maldivian people as the cornerstone of a global action-oriented campaign around climate change.
It's a bold idea to celebrate Maldivian culture, the people, the stories of this island nation before it may very well disappear. Along the way, we’ll introduce you to the restaurateur and her family, the fisherman and his boat, the traditions and the dance – the people whose lives are on the front-lines of climate impact. We seek to highlight each story through a lens of authenticity, as well as through a prism of hopeful futures.


WHO is #LastGlimpse?
Each member of the #LastGlimpse team has highly relevant backgrounds for the project; visit our about page here for full bios. We are Josh Burstein (Host), Ben Youngerman (Head of Production/Post), Ken Fisher (Story Architect), Maya Katherine (Engagement), Silvia Mahan (Producer) and Sundeep Ahuja (Exec Producer):


WHERE are the funds going?
Four of us will be on the ground late December into early January for about 12 days. Everyone is volunteering their time and gear for the project, and while an initiative like this would normally price out at $75k, we’re aiming to keep our entire travel and production budget to around $15K. Here’s how it breaks down:
Flights (long, economy class hauls): $8k Lodging (sleeping on floors if we have to): $2k Food & Water (grocery stores, not fancy restaurants): $2k In-country transportation (interviews are spread across islands): $2k Insurance & miscellaneous: $1k 
We have some other projected costs including hiring a translator, specialty shots, and more, but we’re starting with a $15k goal to cover basic expenses (which it really won't, because of the costs we'll incur fulfilling perks!). We’ll of course cover all personal expenses out of our own pockets; every dime raised from this campaign will go 100% into the project or fulfilling perks.

PRE-ORDER TODAY & get perks!
We unconventionally decided that instead of raising private funds we wanted to invite our friends, family, and the broader Indiegogo community to JOIN us on this project.  We’ll be blogging the experience at lastglimpse.org, sharing updates from on the ground and doing what we can to make it feel like YOU'RE THERE  as part of the team. In exchange for your donations, we’ve got some great perks. Check ‘em out, pick what sings to you, and let's go capture a #LastGlimpse!

FAQ
Are you a non-profit?Not yet, but we intend to be. If you’re looking to come in at a high value perk and would like a tax-deductible receipt, email us at lastglimpsedoc (at) gmail. We’re currently working to identify a Fiscal Sponsor.
How long will the documentary be?We’re aiming for a 30-minute piece, but will cut various shorter lengths for as wide distribution as possible. We see the documentary as the cornerstone of a larger movement, and storytelling will be a big part of it.  
I know someone in the Maldives who can help; who should I contact?Fabulous! Please drop us a note at lastglimpsedoc (at) gmail and we’ll get in touch.
When can I expect to receive my perks?We’re expecting to have a final cut of the documentary sometime in March or April. Our backers will be the first to receive it around then, at the same time as t-shirts, postcards, or anything else pre-ordered. We expect our initial screenings will take place at that time.
What if I buy a ticket to a screening but the date changes?If we change the date and you can't make it, upon request we'll send you "The Doc PLUS" perk instead; if you ordered a VIP ticket, upon request we'll send you "The Home Viewing Party" perk and refund the $24 delta. 
How do I win a free perk by sharing on Facebook or Twitter? We'll be watching Facebook & Twitter for people sharing this campaign with the tag "#LastGlimpse" --  and when the campaign ends, we'll identify 3 winners for whom we’ll bring back a special something from The Maldives. 
Share this campaign on Facebook or Twitter (use links up top) with #LastGlimpse for a chance to win free perks. THANK YOU!
Photo credits: https://www.flickr.com/photos/trodel/3599395828  |  https://www.flickr.com/photos/nattu/2670211903 |  https://www.flickr.com/photos/shazwan/8184849164  |  https://www.flickr.com/photos/nattu/4401430914/in/photolist-71DpBy-7GWu4U-6aPgD7-5Bkd7d

story:
When Sue the snail was crowned Miss Gila last October, she vowed to promote her platform of environmental justice for creatures big and small.  She began touring the state, representing constituents of her home stream of Mineral Creek, the whole Gila River Basin, and riparian animals everywhere.  She kissed the pollywogs of amphibians and shook stomach-feet with fellow mollusks all along the Gila, Rio Grande, and San Juan.  Over the past four months, she tirelessly participated in political hearings and protests on behalf of all the wonderful creatures she has encountered.  But, there’s only so much one snail can do. 

So, Sue realized she could increase her small steps by creating alliances with human activists who are already advancing on environmental issues with leaps and bounds.  To support these giants, Sue has rallied all the gastropods from around the state and is preparing to pair each one of them with a human advocate who can adopt them and their satchel of props to further the snails’ cause.

Never underestimate the power of a snail.  Miss Gila draws huge crowds wherever she goes and has made the news on more than few occasions.  People around the state recognize and revere her, and there is no reason to believe her siblings and cousins wouldn’t have the same spellbinding effects, especially when accompanied by an amazingly able activist.

With just $25, you now have the power to connect these unconventional traveling companions and set them on a path for steady progress towards a healthier and happier planet for all living beings.

story:
Short Summary

  • I am a student at Simpson University studying Outdoor Leadership where I have been trained in leadership, facilitation, writing, teaching, rock climbing, backpacking, canoeing, trip planning, and wilderness rescue.  We have studied topics including the ethics behind environmental conservation, experiential education, and creation care.  I am also a freelance photographer who is passionate about documenting and sharing stories.  Through my education I have learned about the current state of the environment and the necessity for a push to live sustainably as well as the affect that super-power countries such as the US has on marginalized populations especially with environmental pollution.  I believe that a revolution in the way people live on the land can bring health and life back to group of people and the project I will be working on in Kenya is working towards exactly that.  
  • In less than a month, I am setting off to live in a tent in the middle of Kenya where I will be working with a non-profit, called Sadhana Forest, to develop a sustainable Food Forest and teach Water Conservation to the Samburu People.  
  • The area of Maralal in the Samburu district has a very high rate of malnutrition and most of the local population depend on foreign food aid for their sustenance.  
  • Sadhana Forest plans to utilize its vast experience in creating indigenous food forests in order to join the Samburu in their effort to live a healthy and self-sustaining life on their land.  
  • I will be helping with the planning of a Permaculture Design Course starting in June, training the local people in building a Food Forest, water conservation techniques, and training new volunteers as they arrive.  
  • In addition to volunteering, my hope is to research and document the effect of building a food forest on the local population as well as the new sustainable permaculture and water conservation techniques we will be learning in a semi-arid environment through photography and journalism.  

What I Need 

  • I need $4,00 to cover my plane ticket, visa, vaccine's, food while living at our location, travel insurance, transportation fees to and from the airport, biodegradable toiletries and vitamin supplements (we are required to live 100% organic and vegan and can only bring natural soap/mosquito repellent etc), sleeping pad for my new tent home, and last but not least...... a SOLAR POWERED adaptor that will charge my computer and camera while I live in a remote area without electricity!! I hope to purchase this from GoalZero, an ethical environmental company who manufactures solar-powered gear for backpacking, etc. and will enable me to work on my photojournalism project.  The solar-powered adaptor is $400.  
  • If I raise more money that I need, I will donate 100% to the Sadhana Forest in Kenya who rely solely on donation and volunteers to run their project.  

The Impact

  • If you know anything about Africa, you know that this continent has suffered centuries of economic, political, and environmental hardship.  I have always wanted to be a part meeting an actual physical need for people and feel this experience will allow me to do just that, as well as learning skills that can be transferred to other communities in need.  The most attractive aspect of volunteering with Sadhana Forest is that they are focusing on a long-term goal instead of a short-term solution.  I may not be able to see the immediate affects of what this food forest will ultimately reap, I appreciate the opportunity to contribute to the long-term effort of healing the land for it's people.  

The Internship

  • This experience will qualify for my internship requirements at Simpson University.  While volunteering and working on my photography project, I will also be fulfilling the curriculum of an internship which includes writing reflection papers, receiving feedback from the organization, and staying in communication with my professors throughout my experience.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are unable to contribute financially, that's ok!! Could you help me spread the word?? You can share this fundraiser through any social media links provided by the website.

story:
The West Seattle Bee Garden needs your help!

My name is Lauren, and I want to bring an educational beehive enclosure and pollination garden to my green neighborhood in Seattle, Washington.

Why?

High Point is home to many Somali, Cambodian, and Vietnamese families, and cultivating honey bees is part of our shared heritage.

Being part of the solution is a good thing. Bees are in trouble; we need them, and they need our help.

Pollination – West Seattle has beautiful plants and lush P-Patches– let’s keep them happy and pollinated

Honey to share and enjoy

Increased educational opportunities for kids and adults alike

 

Background

Honey bees pollinate 30% of all the food we eat and 80% of all fruits and vegetables. The global honey bee population has suffered a dramatic decline in recent years. Wild honey bee populations in the US have decreased by 50% over the past 50 years, and bee colonies maintained by beekeepers have decreased by about two thirds. This is due to a variety of reasons - most of them man-made. Without intervention, the continued demise of these incredible pollinators would have a dramatic effect on our ecosystems and food supply.

I had heard about the plight of the honey bee, but I wasn't fully aware of the situation and importance until I saw the film Vanishing of the Bees. I posted my idea on the West Seattle Blog asking how my neighbors felt about installing an educational beehive in a local P-Patch. The response was incredible and truly inspiring! So here we are, after more than a year, with a beautiful space for the bees and a pollination garden, a huge level of community support, local beekeepers to help us out (one has even taken me under her wing as an apprentice), pledged labor and funding from the High Point Neighborhood Association and Seattle P-Patch for sustained maintenance into the future, and a Department of Neighborhoods grant to get things rolling.

How you can help

We've come so far, but we need your support for the final push. We've gotten here thanks to the excitement and support of people just like you- friends who offered their time, money, expertise, and dedication. Will you join us? 

Every bit counts towards our goal. A donation of $5 buys one square foot of mulch for our garden- $250 fully outfits a novice beekeeper.  

So spread the word! Donate what you can, and tell friends and family. Best of all, come join us! Sign up to volunteer at an upcoming work party, and we'll see you in the garden.

What is the money for?

Thanks to the Seattle Department of Neighborhoods and other contributions, here is what we have:

- Fence for the pollination garden ($3,000 for material and labor)

- Polycarbonate to enable a transparent and secure beehive enclosure ($4,000)

- Remaining materials for the 9' tall beehive enclosure and shed ($3,000)

- Landscaping and grading, etc. ($2,000) - (this includes wood chips, gravel, compost, and plants for gardens, much of this is being donated as well)

- 2 traditional beehives and stands, butterfly house and mason bee structure ($500) - actual cost is $1250, but $750 worth is being donated)

- Equipment rental ($2,000)

- Materials to install a waterline, spigot and sink ($500)

-Translation and interpretation - final community meeting, invitations to meetings and work parties  ($1000)

- Supplies for mosaic (currently being constructed by WSE students) – ($200)

- Permit to build enclosure – ($520)

- Work party supplies, tools, tent ($1,000)

- Honeybees and mason bee larva ($300)

- Stainless steel donor’s sign ($300)

- Pavers ($100)

- Translation and interpretation (four languages) for signs and events so that everyone can participate ($1,500) 

-Solid wooden benches, enough for an entire classroom ($1,000). Acquired free lumbar from a local fallen tree, and help from a local furniture builder)

- Colorful educational signs ($5000) 

 

How your contributions will be spent:

- Beekeeping equipment, enough to share ($1,500)

- Food and drinks for volunteers during work parties ($1,000)

- 2 additional beehives with frames from Shipwreck Honey -local hive carpenter ($1000)

- WiFi webcam to place at entrance of hive - would create interactive component for visitors, and research opportunities for local educators ($250)

- Small solar panel for basic power ($500)

- Live demonstration supplies ($500)

- Additional educational signs for demonstrations (would purchase with any additional funding left over)

 

 

 

The Impact

The West Seattle Bee and Pollination Garden will teach visitors, residents and school children about bees and pollination. The beehives will be enclosed inside a primarily transparent enclosure. This enclosure heightens the flight path of the bees, minimizing direct human interaction and protecting curious children from getting too close to the hives. The space will be surrounded by beautiful flowers and trees, illustrating the symbiotic relationship of bees and plants.

Schools will be welcome to take field trips to the hives and see demonstrations with the bees. Visitors will learn about bees and pollinators through posted signs and observing the hives. Our community, families and local groups will be welcome to host meetings in the space. Seattle residents and community members will learn new skills and share experiences by being part of this great project.

By hosting bees and educating residents, High Point continues its environmental stewardship. Everyone is invited to our first annual Bee Parade & Picnic on May 19, 2013 to welcome the bees to their new home, learn about bees, and enjoy our beautiful park.

story:
Hi, my name is Pennie Opal Plant, and I am a grandmother of Native American, Mexican & European descent.  I have been a grassroots activist for over 30 years in the San Francisco Bay Area.  Currently, my focus is ensuring the future of the next 7 generations of life on Mother Earth.  For the past year I have been involved in one of the most active Idle No More groups in the United States here in the SF Bay area.  I also helped organize the large demonstration in August 2013, at the Chevron refinery in Richmond, California, which is my home town.

The Declaration on the Rights of Nature (Mother Earth) is a paradigm shifting document that has the potential to change the dangerous course that humanity is on.  (More about the Rights of Nature here: https://therightsofnature.org/)  Most of us understand that the life boat of humanity is rapidly heading toward the cliff of climate chaos. I believe that the Declaration on the Rights of Nature is an important part of the solution.  I was recently invited to participate in the Rights of Nature Summit in Ecuador in January 2014 and would appreciate any assistance you would like to offer to help pay for my trip.  Contributions would pay for the air fare, lodging & meals from January 11-18.  Any additional funds raised will go to our local Idle No More group.

I promise to do everything I can to ensure the future of all of our children, as well as our other relatives with whom we share our beautiful Mother Earth.  I will send contributors a report of what happened at the Summit.  Thank you for any assistance you can offer at whatever level.  And, if you are unable to financially contribute, you can help by spreading the word about the Declaration on the Rights of Nature.

Please feel free to pass along this funding request to folks you know who like to support this effort.

story:
Bref résumé

A brief presentation 


-Présentement, au Québec, seulement 7% de la population fait du compost et cela doit changer!

Currently, in Quebec, only 7% of the population uses compost. This needs to change!

-Notre mission est de réaliser un documentaire sur les méthodes et techniques avancées de compost pratiquées sur la ferme auto-suffisante Rio Muchacho en Équateur. Ensuite, ce vidéo sera présenté dans des écoles à travers le Québec pour informer les jeunes et qu'ils acquièrent la débrouillardise de faire du compost pour aider à sauver notre planète. Bien sûr, nous allons aussi aidés les propriétaires de la ferme en réalisant diverse tâches et en travaillant fort!

Our mission is to make a documentary on the advanced methods and techniques found on the self-sufficient farm of Rio Muchacho in Ecuador. Afterwards, we will distribute our documentary across schools in Quebec so that younger students can learn and acquire the knowledge to do compost and help save our planet. Of course, we will help the owners of the farm by doing various tasks on the farm and working hard! 


-Nous sommes une équipe de cinq étudiants du Collège Sainte-Anne de Lachine faisant partie du programme internationale Défi Monde. En janvier 2016, nous allons réaliser un voyage d’éco-volontariat en Équateur. 

We are a team of five students from the Sainte-Anne College and we are part of an international program named Défi Monde. In January 2016, we will realize an eco-volunteering trip in Ecuador.

Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

What we need to realise this project

-Nous avons besoin de 11 000 dollars pour pouvoir réaliser notre voyage. L'argent vas contribuer au financement des billets d'avions et en plus, puisqu'il y a une école très près de la ferme, nous feront une collecte de matériel scolaire que nous apporterons sur place pour les enfants de l'école. 

We need 11 000 dollars to be able to make our trip. The money will help us pay our plane tickets and, since there is a school near the farm, we will collect school furniture to bring to the children attending the school. 


L'impact

The impact 

-Notre projet n'aura pas seulement un impact en Équateur, mais aussi au Québec. En Équateur, le plus grand impact sera sur les enfants qui vont à l'école près de la ferme. Ils n'ont pas beaucoup d'argent donc ils ne peuvent pas se procurer du matériel scolaire, nous avons donc décidé de faire une collecte et de leur apporter. Au Québec, il y aura un impact sur l'environnement et les élèves québécois. Ce projet nous tient à cœur parce qu'il va nous permettre d'aider des enfants moins fortunés que nous tous en ayant un impact environnemental chez nous, au Québec. 

Our project will not only have an impact in Ecuador, but also in Quebec. In Ecuador, the biggest impact will be on the students attending the school near the Rio Muchacho farm. They don't have a lot of money and they can't afford school furniture so we decided to collect some and bring it to them. In Quebec, there will be an impact on the environment and on the Quebec students. We really care about this project because it will allow us to help kids who don't have a lot of money and also have an environmental impact in our home, Quebec.  


D'autres façons d'aider

Other ways to help

-Vous pouvez nous contacter et donner du matériel scolaire pour les enfants de la ferme.

You can contact us and donate school furniture for the children at the farm.

lamainalapelle@gmail.com

-Partagez notre lien indiegogo et notre adresse web :
You can share our indiegogo and our website :
story_txt:
Bref résumé
A brief presentation 

-Présentement, au Québec, seulement 7% de la population fait du compost et cela doit changer!
Currently, in Quebec, only 7% of the population uses compost. This needs to change!
-Notre mission est de réaliser un documentaire sur les méthodes et techniques avancées de compost pratiquées sur la ferme auto-suffisante Rio Muchacho en Équateur. Ensuite, ce vidéo sera présenté dans des écoles à travers le Québec pour informer les jeunes et qu'ils acquièrent la débrouillardise de faire du compost pour aider à sauver notre planète. Bien sûr, nous allons aussi aidés les propriétaires de la ferme en réalisant diverse tâches et en travaillant fort!
Our mission is to make a documentary on the advanced methods and techniques found on the self-sufficient farm of Rio Muchacho in Ecuador. Afterwards, we will distribute our documentary across schools in Quebec so that younger students can learn and acquire the knowledge to do compost and help save our planet. Of course, we will help the owners of the farm by doing various tasks on the farm and working hard! 




-Nous sommes une équipe de cinq étudiants du Collège Sainte-Anne de Lachine faisant partie du programme internationale Défi Monde. En janvier 2016, nous allons réaliser un voyage d’éco-volontariat en Équateur. 
We are a team of five students from the Sainte-Anne College and we are part of an international program named Défi Monde. In January 2016, we will realize an eco-volunteering trip in Ecuador.

Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez
What we need to realise this project
-Nous avons besoin de 11 000 dollars pour pouvoir réaliser notre voyage. L'argent vas contribuer au financement des billets d'avions et en plus, puisqu'il y a une école très près de la ferme, nous feront une collecte de matériel scolaire que nous apporterons sur place pour les enfants de l'école. 
We need 11 000 dollars to be able to make our trip. The money will help us pay our plane tickets and, since there is a school near the farm, we will collect school furniture to bring to the children attending the school. 




L'impact
The impact 
-Notre projet n'aura pas seulement un impact en Équateur, mais aussi au Québec. En Équateur, le plus grand impact sera sur les enfants qui vont à l'école près de la ferme. Ils n'ont pas beaucoup d'argent donc ils ne peuvent pas se procurer du matériel scolaire, nous avons donc décidé de faire une collecte et de leur apporter. Au Québec, il y aura un impact sur l'environnement et les élèves québécois. Ce projet nous tient à cœur parce qu'il va nous permettre d'aider des enfants moins fortunés que nous tous en ayant un impact environnemental chez nous, au Québec. 
Our project will not only have an impact in Ecuador, but also in Quebec. In Ecuador, the biggest impact will be on the students attending the school near the Rio Muchacho farm. They don't have a lot of money and they can't afford school furniture so we decided to collect some and bring it to them. In Quebec, there will be an impact on the environment and on the Quebec students. We really care about this project because it will allow us to help kids who don't have a lot of money and also have an environmental impact in our home, Quebec.  







D'autres façons d'aider

You can contact us and donate school furniture for the children at the farm.

story:
Summary

MATTKEL REGENERATIVE CENTER is the vision of two creative, resourceful, prolific and spotaneous young men: Matthew Amechi Onyeanula and Innocent Kelvin Coffie.
www.facebook.com/mattkelregenerativecenter
Matthew Amechi Onyeanula is a Nigerian born (Citizen from Lagos, Nigeria) was educated in Nigeria and Ghana. He is a certified Permaculturist and has had the opportunity to work and volunteer with different organisation in Nigeria and Ghana.

Innocent Kelvin Coffie is a Ghanaian, born and raised in the Volta region. Once a teacher in Akosombo Estern Region he is now a Farm Manager/Permaculturist.

VISION
Our vision is of humanity living in harmony with a functioning ecosystem. Our goal is to establish a regenerative agriculture and permaculture demonstration center within the Kyrehi community of Kintampo South in the Brong Ahafo Region in Ghana.

MISSION
Our earth ecosystem is in shambles. Healthy ecosytems are fundermental to sustainable business and vibrant and social communities; indeed peoples health and well being are intricately linked with the Earths health and well being. These issues need to be addressed. Our Mission is to address this by:
Experimenting with and demonstrating possible solutions to problems faced by poor Kyrehi community farmers such as degraded land, dependency on erratic weather patterns, and lack of resources(capital, education, tools, etc.) 
Increase soil fertility and biodiversity in the broader community landscape , making the land more
productive for future generations by sharing and spreading techniques and technologies we are currently working with to achieve our mission including the following:
Natural building, bee keeping and agro-forestry systems, chicken
tractors, greenhouses, micro terraces, contour ditches, edible forest gardens, sustainable animal management, rainwater catchment, low cost irrigation systems, intensive gardens, greywater systems, composting, passive solar energy, value added product development, etc. 

What We Need 

We are are looking for all possible support/sponsorship/collaboration from local and foreign organizations wishing to help us combat land degradation, restore and protect the environment, encourage sustainable agriculture, and aid rural inhabitants (common people) in achieving self-reliant and well improved living standards.
We are seeking $20,000 USD to kickstart this project.

Funds raised in this campaign will be allocated to the following items in order of Priority:

Registration of Ngo, bank account.: $1000

Land : $7000-10000 USD

Water: Creation of Bore/Well: $5000

Farm Tools/Inputs: $500

Structures: $3500

The Impact

 Poverty is the greatest issue people are facing here (in our region) as almost 70 percent here are living below the poverty line. Many youths have remained unemployed for years and are fast loosing hope of getting out of the grips of poverty. The situation is very critical and needs urgent attention in the form of capacity building and the creation of employment opportunities.
Risks & Challenges

One of our greatest challenges is the socio-economical difficulties that Africa faces. Deforestation and land degradation creates food security issues for many Ghanaians . Often However, the individuals who would benefit most from what we are teaching are also those who are least able to afford a permaculture education. We are meeting this challenge by offering the most affordable education we can. As a non-profit organization, we also intend to minimize our expenses and reinvest our profits to further improve the accessibility of a permaculture education.

A potential risk that our project faces is a downturn in the local and global economy. Ghanaians and internationals alike are less likely to invest in self-education or consider other techniques in trying times. Ironically, if this happens what we are teaching is even more valuable (i.e. making home, garden and business more resilient and productive). Thus this risk also comes with great opportunity,

Other Ways You Can Help

 We are also seeking for foreign youths wanting to come for internship as part of their university degrees/ studies or wishing to do volunteer service here in
Ghana (West Africa) with us for 3, 6 to 12months.

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
What is GreenByBlue?

The world is witnessing an economic, social and environmental crisis. Fortunately, a growing number of people and communities across the globe are taking action to make the world a more sustainable, equitable and prosperous place. They are doing so through entrepreneurship, collaboration and innovation.

GreenByBlue is our one-year long project investigating the transformational power of green and sustainable initiatives on people, cities and natural environments around the world. Our focus is on action and policy, challenges and opportunities. GreenByBlue will meet the people behind these initiatives, whether they are sustainable businesses, community-based projects, green start-ups, cleantech companies, renewable energy cooperatives, green tourism, green design, or ecological projects.

The two-person team will travel around the world by land and sea (no planes) to visit these initiatives. Travelling this way ensures that we integrate fully with the communities and environments at every stage of the journey. It also ensures we minimise our carbon-foot print. Departing from Amsterdam on 1 May, 2014, our route will take us eastwards through Europe, Central Asia, China, South East Asia, Australasia, across the Pacific, into Latin America, North America, across the Atlantic and back to Europe.

Our Vision

A sustainable post-carbon world driven by creativity, collaboration and innovation.

Our Goals

  • RAISE AWARENESS of green and sustainable initiatives across the globe
  • ENGAGE with entrepreneurs, innovators, activists and policy makers to exchange ideas and develop sustainable solutions
  • APPLY new learning to strengthen existing projects and launch new initiatives

The Team

We are Rachel Creane and Alex Romaniuc. Although based in Amsterdam, we come from Ireland and Canada respectively. We are well-seasoned travellers, having visited over 50 countries, and speaking 8 languages between us.

Rachel has worked for 10 years in the communications industry in Dublin, London, and Amsterdam, with a Bachelor’s degree in visual communications and a Master’s degree in Cultural Studies.

Alex has over 10 years experience in governance, democracy, and sustainable development projects particularly in Eastern Europe and Central Asia. His focus in the last few years has been on low-carbon issues.  He has lived in Canada, Belgium, Ukraine and the UK.

Do you run a green initiative? We’d like to meet you!

Do you run a sustainable business, green start-up, cleantech company, or a renewable energy cooperative? Perhaps you are involved in green tourism, green design, or an ecological initiative? Or you are promoting green growth, democratization of energy, collaborative consumption, or a positive economy? If you run or are part of a green initiative we’d like to meet you and feature you on our website.

Featured initiatives will gain exposure on our website and also receive copy of the book to be we will publish at the end of the project.

How else can you help?

Become a backer: We will be launching a 45 day Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign from 31 March 2014 to collect funds for the project. Become a backer, receive a reward, and spread the word! 

Provide local knowledge: We hope to get local insights in the places we visit, whether it is on the local renewable energy collective, a sustainable farm, or the best hikes in the region.

Share a place to stay: Every night we will need to lay our heads down and rest. Help us out with a bed for the night. We would welcome the opportunity to stay with locals or people who have the same passion for green initiatives!

Speaking events: The project is about raising awareness and creating contacts. We’d be delighted to speak at your event.


CONTACT US!
Twitter: @GreenByBlue
Email: info@greenbyblue.com
Website: greenbyblue.com
Facebook: facebook.com/GreenByBlue

story:
Short Summary

My name is Joe Bik and I am the Founder & Director of Voice of Yongos (VOY), a community based organization involved in reforestation, environment and community development projects in the Yongomugl Sub-District of Simbu Province, Papua New Guinea. 

Everything we do daily like the use of electricity, use of office equipment, driving a car, travelling in bus or in a train or in a plane or in a ship we all contribute to emit carbon dioxide (CO2) into the atmosphere which cause global warming and creates climate change that brings misery and disastrous destruction to many lives around the globe so we as global citizens living on this planet we should be responsible for our own actions.

The simple thing we all need to do now is to plant trees because the battle against climate change cannot be won without trees; the potential contribution for re-balancing the carbon equation is to more plant trees as it will sequester carbon and play a major role in mitigating the effects of global climate change.

With this understanding, VOY had initiated a community driven tree planting project in 2012 and had so far raised and planted 16,519 trees already but the target is to plant 50,000 trees by 2014 so we need donations from generous people, charity groups and corporate citizens to expand our seedlings production and planting to meet the target.

Planting trees also creates employment for rural people to support their families and also it provides cash income to women and children and with this small income they are able to get basic needs to sustain their livelihoods.

We would like to raise US$5000 to purchase project materials and here is a small budget (Seeds - $1000.00, Poly Bags - $1500.00, Shade Cloth - $500.00, NPK Fertilizer - $500.00, Stipend - $1500.00).

Your donations will help us to increase our production capacity to raise and plant 50,000 or more trees by 2014 to reduce global carbon emissions, restoring local ecosystem services, alleviating poverty and sustaining rural livelihoods of the people.

As a contributor, you are part of the project team and co-own the trees so we request that you encourage your friends, your family and your work mates to contribute, participate in tree planting activities and involve in local environmental awareness education programs in your area.

All contributors will receive certificates, posters, updates on the project and also we offer special local hand weaving hand bags to first 10 generous people who contribute $100 and local hand weaving cap to first 20 people who contribute $50, these perks will be delivered, three weeks after the campaign ends.

As a contributor, you can also claim 100% credit for contributing to the reduction of global carbon emissions and at the same time you should be proud that you are creating cash income opportunities for local families in this remote part of the world so become a partner, make a donation and let us work together to raise and plant more trees and make earth a cooler place to live.

story:
Hi,

My name is Morgane Angéniol, I am a biologist with a medicinal plant speciality. I met in Peru a family of shamanes last year. They welcomed me as if I were part of their family and I spent weeks with them to discover what they are doing and  where they are living. I really appreciate them and  they have a really nice and interesting project. 

Peru is a big country: deforestation and pollution go fast. People are not aware here about these problems. It's really important to help people who are concerned about the preservation of nature and the effects of global warming. It's a first project which can inspire others.

Today, we have a life more stressful, we eat junk food, spend time in traffic jam... We are more susceptible to disease, fatigue, depression ... and we forget to take a break to take care of itself. This center is the perfect place to have a totally natural treatment with medicinal plants, life in the midst of nature, reiki, massage ...
For me, it is important to promote this type of care because it is much more effective than many drugs and therapies.

Help us and you will be helping the Earth and Human


Project

There is a retreat center called Buri Buri near Tarapoto, San Martin, Peru. The center is a rustic place with simple accommodations and without facility. We would go there with a team and upgrade the center: building ecological toilet, installing a water pump, upgrading accommodations to prevent problemsrelatedto termites, developing the soil for plantation (medicinal plant, garden, etc). In addition, we could create informative signs about facilities and surroundings (depending on the team, money and time).


1.  Tangaranas center

Hernan Saavedra is a vegetal healer (shaman) with a plant specialty: ayahuasca (hence the title of ayahuasquero). With his wife: Jesus Arce, they have a center called: etnomedicina amazónia Tangaranas (http://www.tangaranas.com). Their primary work is a project for conservation, diffusion and treatment with traditional Amazonian medicine. The office is localized at Jr. Jorge Chavez n°858, Tarapoto, Peru; Phone number: +51/42521757.

They offer holistic treatment, ayahuasca ceremonies, sauna therapy, massage, reiki treatment, retreat, etc.


2.  Buri Buri - the Amazonianspiritual retreat

Buri Buri is located at about 20 km from Tarapoto. The location is reachable by boat, motorbike or four-wheel drive vehicle.

Buri Buri is centered next to the river:  Rio Mayo, so convenient for swimming, showering, etc.

The pergola is stationed for the practice of yoga, meditation, massage, reiki, ceremony, etc.

Hernan lives next to the retreat center (in the house of his father) during the diet where he does cooking and preparing medicines.


3.  Project

Hernan is concerned about the preservation of nature and the effects of global warming. He loves and needs plants to work. He also promotes human connection and their contact with the nature when they come for a spiritual retreat. He doesn't want that his activities have a bad impact on the environment. For him, it's really important that people know more about the plants, animals, insects, making it possible to experience the unique environment and act responsibly.

The main structure to build is eco-toilet because human excrements are a source of contamination and pollution. Water is a precious resource, so it's important to preserve it.

There is no other water access than the river. So a water pump and tank will be a great help for his garden (medicinal plant, vegetable and fruits) and eventually for a shower. The water is not potable and water containers must be taken on site. A water filtration system for drinking would save time, transportation and reducing plastic contamination.

Termites are living in Buri Buri and eat the wood. Hernan doesn't want to kill them because it's their natural habitat. The solution would be to build a separation between the structure and the ground. Currently, the carbets start to be destroyed.

The soil is poor and dry. He needs to be worked and enriched.

Some signs could be put on the site to inform people about the natural surroundings, to promote what responsible behavior.


§  Objectives

- Step 1: obtaining the money for the project (minimum 10 000€).

- Step 2: finding a team.

- Step 3: travelling to Peru and work on site.


§  Progress

Step 1

- Finding partnership or/and donation.

Step 2

- Finding the team (4 or 5 persons).

·  Morgane Angéniol (Head project)

·  2 volunteers with skills in manual work and medicinal plants

·  1 or 2 volunteers with eco-construction skill

·  1 volunteer who want to be involved in this project

- Making construction plan.

Step 3

- Traveling to Tarapoto.

- Buying material.

- Building constructions in Buri Buri

·  toilet

·  water pomp and tanks

·  upgrade accommodations

·  developing soil

·  shower (optional)

·  signs (optional)

·  water filter (optional)

- Advising Hernan about the construction and eco-tourism activities he can develop


§  Starting date

Step 1: Now

Step 2: February 2014 (can be changed according to step 1)

Step 3: April 2014 (can be changed according to step 1)


§  Option

Making a documentary about the project.

accommodations to prevent problemsrelatedto termites, developing the soil for plantation (medicinal plant,
garden, etc). In addition, we could create informative signs about facilities
and surroundings (depending on the team, money and time).
1.  Tangaranas center

Hernan Saavedra is a
vegetal healer (shaman) with a plant specialty: ayahuasca (hence the title of ayahuasquero).
With his wife: Jesus Arce, they have a center called: etnomedicina amazónia Tangaranas (http://www.tangaranas.com). Their primary work is a
project for conservation, diffusion and treatment with traditional Amazonian
medicine. The office is localized at Jr. Jorge Chavez n°858, Tarapoto, Peru;
Phone number: +51/42521757. 

They offer holistic treatment,
ayahuasca ceremonies, sauna therapy, massage, reiki treatment, retreat, etc.
2. 
Buri
Buri - the Amazonianspiritual retreat
Buri Buri is located at about 20 km from
Tarapoto. The location is reachable by boat, motorbike or four-wheel drive
vehicle. Buri Buri is centered next to the river:  Rio Mayo, so convenient for swimming, showering, etc.The pergola
is stationed for the practice of yoga, meditation, massage, reiki, ceremony,
etc.
Hernan lives next to
the retreat center (in the house of his father) during the diet where he does
cooking and preparing medicines.

3.  Project

Hernan is concerned about the preservation of nature
and the effects of global warming. He loves and needs plants to work. He also
promotes human connection and their contact with the nature when they come for
a spiritual retreat. He doesn't want that his activities have a bad impact on
the environment. For him, it's really important that people know more about the
plants, animals, insects, making it possible to experience the unique
environment and act responsibly.
The main structure to build is eco-toilet
because human excrements are a source of contamination and pollution. Water is
a precious resource, so it's important to preserve it. 
There is no other water access than the river.
So a water pump and tank will be a great help for his garden (medicinal plant,
vegetable and fruits) and eventually for a shower. The water
is not potable and water containers
must be taken on site. A water filtration system
for drinking would save time, transportation and reducing plastic contamination.
Termites are living in Buri Buri and eat the
wood. Hernan doesn't want to kill them because it's their natural habitat. The
solution would be to build a separation between the structure and the ground.
Currently, the carbets start to be destroyed.
The soil is poor and dry. He needs to be worked
and enriched.
Some signs could be put on the site to inform
people about the natural surroundings, to promote what responsible behavior.
§  Objectives
- Step 1: obtaining the money
for the project (minimum 10 000€).
- Step 2: finding a team.
- Step 3: travelling to Peru
and work on site.
§ 
Progress
Step 1
- Finding partnership or/and donation. 
Step 2
- Finding the team (4 or 5 persons).
· 
Morgane
Angéniol (Head project)
· 
2
volunteers with skills in manual work and medicinal plants
· 
1
or 2 volunteers with eco-construction skill
· 
1
volunteer who want to be involved in this project
- Making construction
plan.
Step 3
- Traveling to Tarapoto.
- Buying material.
- Building constructions
in Buri Buri
· 
toilet
· 
water
pomp and tanks
· 
upgrade
accommodations
· 
developing
soil
· 
shower
(optional)
· 
signs
(optional)
· 
water
filter (optional)
- Advising Hernan
about the construction and eco-tourism activities he can develop
§ 
Starting
date
Step 1: Now
Step 2: February
2014 (can be changed according to step 1)
Step 3: April
2014 (can be changed according to step 1)
§ 
Option
Making a documentary about the
project.

story:
The Project

Kilimanjaro Hope Organization (KIHO) is a non-governmental organization in Tanzania, founded in 2010. Our general website can be seen at http://kilimanjarohopeorganization.weebly.com/.  KIHO is working on many projects to promote knowledge and tools for locals in the Kilimanjaro Region to make their farming more sustainable and profitable. Since the start of the "Mkume Sub-Village: Farms for the Future" project one year ago, locals have worked together with international volunteers to create a public learning center in one village, as well as pipe infrastructure for irrigation farming during the region’s dry season, and contour farming projects to reduce soil erosion. The next phase of the project is the installation of 10 domestic biogas plants for local families. 

The goals of the project are to build 10 biogas plants in the area to reduce deforestation caused by the need for firewood, to educate the local population about this technology, and to relieve women and children from the work of collecting firewood, and the long time spent cooking, so that they may be involved in other economic activities, thus improving their families' situations, and allowing children to attend school. 

For more details, please see More Information About Biogas and the project's main website.

What can we do with $2000?

We can begin work on our project! While the entire project budget is $5,300, $2000 is enough for us to get started. It will be enough to install the first 3 biogas plants. The sooner we can build these first few plants, the sooner we can start to run workshops and raise awareness about this technology, enabling locals with the tools and knowledge to follow our example.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to make a donation, that's okay! You can still help!

If each person who reads this shares it with 10 friends, and they share it with 10 of their friends, then we have much better chances of raising the funds we need. So please! Share!!! You can use the share tools of the Indiegogo website or stick to good old email and facebook. The important thing is that you share and help make this project public!

 

Thanks!!!!
