story:
Help Be Pawsitive raise $15,000 for our first production run! Check out our story, what we are about and our amazing dog treats below.

IT ALL STARTED WITH LOLA. Lola is a former shelter dog, who is now the Chief Treat Tester at Be Pawsitive. I found Lola abandoned in a park in Arlington, Texas. Taking her to the local shelter to see if anyone had lost her, she had no microchip and after days with her picture on the lost dogs website she was put into the adoption system along with many other dogs. That is where I first saw just how many dogs are waiting for new homes, and that’s what gave me the idea to do something that can help. So I guess you can figure out by now that I adopted Lola and now we are working hard to provide a way to help bring a little happiness to dogs still waiting for homes in the form of great tasting nutritious dog treats.

FEEL GOOD ABOUT GIVING. Our treats our amazing. We know how much you care about your dog. Thats why we carefuly choose what goes into our treats. They really are the best treats you can buy.

  • Small Batch Baked
  • USDA Certified Organic 
  • Made with all natural ingredients
  • No fillers or gluten
  • Made in the USA
  • Flavors Dog Love

Easily Digestible Grains

Whole spelt, millet, oats, barley, and brown rice flour are easily digestible. In addition, they are rich in nutrients, high in protein, and full of essential vitamins & minerals. These grains are the foundation of our wheat free biscuit varieties.

Whole-Wheat Flour

Whole-Wheat Flour is used as a primary ingredient in our “original flavor” biscuits. It is an excellent source of protein and fermentable fiber. The fiber aids in intestinal health and is important for reproduction. We use coarse-ground high-protein flour, which contains the germ and bran. Wheat helps to stimulate liver functions and cleanse toxins from your dog’s body. Whole wheat contains B vitamins, folic acid, calcium, iron, magnesium, phosphorus, zinc and other minerals.

Brown Flax Seed

Rich in Omega 3, flax seed has been shown to possess qualities that promote good heart health, cancer prevention, and healthy skin and coat.

Extra Virgin Olive Oil (the only type of organic olive oil)

Extra Virgin Olive Oil contains the optimal ratio of omega 6 and omega 3 fatty acids which play a vital role in healing inflammation, particularly in joints (arthritis), skin (allergies), and intestines (inflammatory bowel disease). Fats are also the most concentrated form of food energy providing your dog twice the energy of proteins or carbohydrates. Essential fatty acids must be added to a dog’s diet because their bodies cannot synthesize them in sufficient amounts. A deficiency of essential fatty acids may result in reduced growth or increased skin problems.

Canola Oil

Canola oil is high in lineolic acid (omega 6), an unsaturated essential fatty acid that plays an important role in the regulation and functioning of every organ and cell in the body. Linoleic acid also helps to balance and heal the immune system as well as reduce inflammatory reactions such as those seen in arthritis and allergic reactions.

Eggs

Eggs offer a host of vitamins and minerals beneficial to muscles, coat, skin, and joints. They are also an excellent source of protein, the building blocks of cells, antibodies, hormones, etc. Eggs are essential for growth, reproduction, and maintenance. They also contain essential amino acids, which cannot be synthesized by dogs and must be supplied to their diets.

Non-Fat Dry Milk

Milk in moderate amounts, is easily digestible, high in protein and contain amounts of vitamins & minerals that are essential to your dog’s healthy diet. Vitamins B, D, and E, are necessary to help strengthen bones, fight anemia, prevent certain forms of dermatitis, and improve muscle actions. Iodine, a major mineral in milk, helps to regulate your dogs metabolism.

Honey

Honey contains many essential nutrients including B-complex vitamins. It helps fight colon cancer, is a natural antiseptic, promotes healing, and is a good source of energy for your dog.

Garlic

Garlic is an antioxidant, which in small amounts help fight infection and disease. It is a source of selenium, which aids in proper immune response, can help neutralize free radicals in your dog’s body, and minimize the effects of daily stress. Garlic also helps keep your dog’s coat healthy and is a natural repellent of biting insects.

We donate the same great treats to dogs in animal shelters and rescue organizations that we sent to your dog.

 

GIVING BACK TO SHELTERS. This is the part of our business that really gets us excited. Thanks to our customers we are able to provide our treats to dogs who are still waiting for homes and families. The adoption process can be long and arduous for some dogs and we want to provide something that can help during that waiting time. Not only can our treats be used to reward dogs for good behavior but also provide a way for people looking to adopt to warm up to dogs with a gesture of good faith (dog treat). Not all dogs let their personalities come out the first time you meet them so being able to give them a treat and show them your intentions are good allows for a better connection during a meet and greet and hopefully leads to more adoptions. They are also used as rewards during obedience training. Dogs that are leash trained and obedient have a higher rate of adoption. 

 

 

THE MONTHLY TREAT BOX. Our treats are shipped out at the first of each month via our monthly treat box subscription. When you sign up, you receive a different flavor each month and each box you receive provides treats for a dog in an animal shelter.

WE NEED YOUR HELP. To get started we need a little help from you guys. Be Pawsitive needs AT LEAST $15,000 to launch in June. The funding from you guys will go to help produce our wonderful treats, and help with the cost of our treat packaging and shipping boxes.

ALLOCATION OF FUNDS

PERKS FOR YOUR HELP. Your money is not just a donation; it's our seed funding to launch our product. So we want to give you back more than just a thank you, so we have come up with some great perks. Almost all of our perks give you at least one of our treat boxes, and of course for every treat box we ship out, we donate a treat box to a shelter. That includes the boxes rewarded on this campaign. Please comment with any suggestions you have on current or any future perks you would like to see. Continental US shipping only.

 

                                               OUR TREAT BOX

 

                          DOG BANDANA                                                            5x5" STICKER

T-SHIRTS (ONLY AVAILABLE FOR INDIEGOGO FUNDERS!)

Shirts come in mens and womens sizes. Colors are white, gray, and pink. We will follow up with you after the campaign has ended to get your sizes, colors, and designs.

  

 

 

BRING YOUR PUP AND LET'S HANG OUT AT THE DOG PARK

NAME A FLAVOR OF OUR TREATS. 

Name one of our treat flavors after you or your dog (ex Rusty's Berry Biscuits).

 

SHARE OUR STORY. If you like what we're doing, please share this campaign with your friends and family. Not all contributions need to be $ you can help by spreading the word.
story_txt:
Help Be Pawsitive raise $15,000 for our first production run! Check out our story, what we are about and our amazing dog treats below.
IT ALL STARTED WITH LOLA. Lola is a former shelter dog, who is now the Chief Treat Tester at Be Pawsitive. I found Lola abandoned in a park in Arlington, Texas. Taking her to the local shelter to see if anyone had lost her, she had no microchip and after days with her picture on the lost dogs website she was put into the adoption system along with many other dogs. That is where I first saw just how many dogs are waiting for new homes, and that’s what gave me the idea to do something that can help. So I guess you can figure out by now that I adopted Lola and now we are working hard to provide a way to help bring a little happiness to dogs still waiting for homes in the form of great tasting nutritious dog treats.

FEEL GOOD ABOUT GIVING. Our treats our amazing. We know how much you care about your dog. Thats why we carefuly choose what goes into our treats. They really are the best treats you can buy.

Small Batch Baked
USDA Certified Organic 
Made with all natural ingredients
No fillers or gluten
Made in the USA
Flavors Dog Love

Easily Digestible Grains
Whole spelt, millet, oats, barley, and brown rice flour are easily digestible. In addition, they are rich in nutrients, high in protein, and full of essential vitamins & minerals. These grains are the foundation of our wheat free biscuit varieties.
Whole-Wheat Flour
Whole-Wheat Flour is used as a primary ingredient in our “original flavor” biscuits. It is an excellent source of protein and fermentable fiber. The fiber aids in intestinal health and is important for reproduction. We use coarse-ground high-protein flour, which contains the germ and bran. Wheat helps to stimulate liver functions and cleanse toxins from your dog’s body. Whole wheat contains B vitamins, folic acid, calcium, iron, magnesium, phosphorus, zinc and other minerals.
Brown Flax Seed
Rich in Omega 3, flax seed has been shown to possess qualities that promote good heart health, cancer prevention, and healthy skin and coat.
Extra Virgin Olive Oil (the only type of organic olive oil)
Extra Virgin Olive Oil contains the optimal ratio of omega 6 and omega 3 fatty acids which play a vital role in healing inflammation, particularly in joints (arthritis), skin (allergies), and intestines (inflammatory bowel disease). Fats are also the most concentrated form of food energy providing your dog twice the energy of proteins or carbohydrates. Essential fatty acids must be added to a dog’s diet because their bodies cannot synthesize them in sufficient amounts. A deficiency of essential fatty acids may result in reduced growth or increased skin problems.
Canola Oil
Canola oil is high in lineolic acid (omega 6), an unsaturated essential fatty acid that plays an important role in the regulation and functioning of every organ and cell in the body. Linoleic acid also helps to balance and heal the immune system as well as reduce inflammatory reactions such as those seen in arthritis and allergic reactions.
Eggs
Eggs offer a host of vitamins and minerals beneficial to muscles, coat, skin, and joints. They are also an excellent source of protein, the building blocks of cells, antibodies, hormones, etc. Eggs are essential for growth, reproduction, and maintenance. They also contain essential amino acids, which cannot be synthesized by dogs and must be supplied to their diets.
Non-Fat Dry Milk
Milk in moderate amounts, is easily digestible, high in protein and contain amounts of vitamins & minerals that are essential to your dog’s healthy diet. Vitamins B, D, and E, are necessary to help strengthen bones, fight anemia, prevent certain forms of dermatitis, and improve muscle actions. Iodine, a major mineral in milk, helps to regulate your dogs metabolism.
Honey
Honey contains many essential nutrients including B-complex vitamins. It helps fight colon cancer, is a natural antiseptic, promotes healing, and is a good source of energy for your dog.
Garlic
Garlic is an antioxidant, which in small amounts help fight infection and disease. It is a source of selenium, which aids in proper immune response, can help neutralize free radicals in your dog’s body, and minimize the effects of daily stress. Garlic also helps keep your dog’s coat healthy and is a natural repellent of biting insects.
We donate the same great treats to dogs in animal shelters and rescue organizations that we sent to your dog.
 
GIVING BACK TO SHELTERS. This is the part of our business that really gets us excited. Thanks to our customers we are able to provide our treats to dogs who are still waiting for homes and families. The adoption process can be long and arduous for some dogs and we want to provide something that can help during that waiting time. Not only can our treats be used to reward dogs for good behavior but also provide a way for people looking to adopt to warm up to dogs with a gesture of good faith (dog treat). Not all dogs let their personalities come out the first time you meet them so being able to give them a treat and show them your intentions are good allows for a better connection during a meet and greet and hopefully leads to more adoptions. They are also used as rewards during obedience training. Dogs that are leash trained and obedient have a higher rate of adoption. 
 
 
THE MONTHLY TREAT BOX. Our treats are shipped out at the first of each month via our monthly treat box subscription. When you sign up, you receive a different flavor each month and each box you receive provides treats for a dog in an animal shelter.

WE NEED YOUR HELP. To get started we need a little help from you guys. Be Pawsitive needs AT LEAST $15,000 to launch in June. The funding from you guys will go to help produce our wonderful treats, and help with the cost of our treat packaging and shipping boxes.
ALLOCATION OF FUNDS

PERKS FOR YOUR HELP. Your money is not just a donation; it's our seed funding to launch our product. So we want to give you back more than just a thank you, so we have come up with some great perks. Almost all of our perks give you at least one of our treat boxes, and of course for every treat box we ship out, we donate a treat box to a shelter. That includes the boxes rewarded on this campaign. Please comment with any suggestions you have on current or any future perks you would like to see. Continental US shipping only.
 
                                               OUR TREAT BOX

 
                          DOG BANDANA                                                            5x5" STICKER

T-SHIRTS (ONLY AVAILABLE FOR INDIEGOGO FUNDERS!)
Shirts come in mens and womens sizes. Colors are white, gray, and pink. We will follow up with you after the campaign has ended to get your sizes, colors, and designs.
  

 
 
BRING YOUR PUP AND LET'S HANG OUT AT THE DOG PARK

NAME A FLAVOR OF OUR TREATS. 
Name one of our treat flavors after you or your dog (ex Rusty's Berry Biscuits).

 
SHARE OUR STORY. If you like what we're doing, please share this campaign with your friends and family. Not all contributions need to be $ you can help by spreading the word.

story:
The Tabebuia Project is creating a field guide to the plants of dry tropical forest in coastal Ecuador. It will feature common and Latin names of plants, full-color photos and illustrations, identifying features and ecology, and ethnobotanical information.

www.tabebuiaproject.com

Tabebuia is the name of the genus of plants that includes the Guayacán, which is beautiful and also noted for it's timber and medicinal properties.

Our Indiegogo campaign has now ended, fully funded! We can still use additional help, and if you are inspired to aid our cause, visit the support page on our website.

Why?

Dry tropical forests of coastal Ecuador are a biological hotspot, and one of the world’s most threatened ecosystems. More than 90% of lowland areas in western Ecuador have been converted to agricultural use; only 1-2% of original forest cover remains. Few references exist that describe plant species, interactions, or uses in this populated, ecologically fascinating, and rapidly changing region, and most that do are aimed solely at a scientific audience.

A bilingual guide to plants in dry tropical forests will help establish a foundation for conservation in this region: if you know what you are protecting, you can do can do a better job of protecting it.

Check out this beautiful video by Reserva Biologica Cerro Seco about the region.

Author's inspiration:
"While traveling through South America in 2009-10, I was always on the lookout for resources to understand more about the flora and fauna I experienced. When traveling to new places, some people collect shot glasses, others collect t-shirts or mugs. I collect field guides. I love them. Some are insightful, others are less so; they are my way of staying in touch with a place. Throughout my travels it became increasingly difficult to find plant field guides, especially in hyper-biodiverse areas. This makes sense: there are so many things to describe, discoveries of new species in these areas are common, and taxa are not always clearly defined. With this in mind, I decided to follow an ambitious dream to develop locally-to-regionally based guidebooks, starting with the most recent place I spent time volunteering: Reserva Cerro Seco, on the Ecuadorian coast, in the ‘eco-ciudad’ of Bahia de Caraquez, 1 degree south of the Equator in dry tropical forest."
Natalie Pyrooz, MES, Field Associate, California Academy of Sciences
By supporting this project, you have the opportunity to help conserve some of the last of the dry tropical forest in South America. This guide will first be published as an e-book in the coming months.

What We Need & What You Get

The Tabebuia Project has been entirely funded on my dime and passion, and in-kind donations of people offering their time and expertise without compensation. World-renowned botanists assisted me with identifications. Rural Eucadorian guides shared their knowledge of the forest with me. Out of the kindness of their heart and their believing in my work. I want to pay them back, as well as put some money towards some much-needed equipment. And a bit of assistance towards my travel costs. This sort of project often only happens with tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars of funding, which is one of the reasons so few guides exist in tropical America.

The $2,000 goal will be put towards:

  • GPS and Ecuador basemap package
  • hiring local Ecuadorian guides
  • compensating expert botanists
  • reserve entry fees
  • workshop materials
  • shipping of specimens
  • website maintenance
  • transportation, room and board for research for 1 month
If I am lucky enough to reach and exceed my goal, as you can see the expenses easily surmount what I hope I can raise, and any extra funding will be put to enhance this work.

Rewards! Here's the fun part -- you can be involved!
All donations are tax-deductible as I am a Field Associate with the California Academy of Sciences.

$5 ~ I just <3 biodiversity!

$10 ~ Shout-out of gratitude: thank-you card, shout-out on our Facebook page, project updates
$20 ~ NEW: an Ecuadorian souvenir, shout out of gratitude, project updates

$25 ~ Set of 3 cards featuring flora and landscapes of coastal Manabi, shout-out of gratitude, listed as support on website

$40 ~ Copy of the ebook! + shout-out of gratitude, listed as supporter on website

$40 ~ hand-crafted earrings featuring flora and fauna-themed photos from exotic places, shout out of gratitude, listed as support on website
$80 ~ Hand-crafted earrings featuring flora-themed photos from exotic places, + copy of ebook, shout-out of gratitude, listed as support on website

$125 ~ 11x14 print (I'll have a link up to photos soon), + copy of ebook, shout-out of gratitude, listed as support on website

$175 ~ Hand-bound gratitude journal, + copy of ebook, shout-out of gratitude, listed as support on website

$300 ~ A bit of everything above.

$525 ~ Two of everything above, + your name listed as a supporter in the book & website

$1100 ~ Presentation explaining my work and results at location and event of your choice
+ copy of e-book, 11x14 print, shout-out of gratitude, listed as a supporter in the book & website

$1500 ~ A week in the field with me!
+ copy of e-book, 11x14 print, shout-out of gratitude, listed as a supporter in the book & website

The Impact

My first goal in this project was to put together a rapid field guide. This is already done and featured on the Chicago Field Museum website. It is downloadable for free. This is the first step in helping people to know what is around them.

A field guide will help people get in touch with their landscape so much more. The information it will share will open doors for people. I've done a lot of research both online and in academic libraries and spent a lot of time compiling information. I've talked with botanists from several countries doing my best to ensure accuracy of my identifications. In the States we are very accustomed to having easy access to knowing so much of our natural heritage. This is disappearing - quickly - in places like coastal Ecuador. While oral histories and local ecological knowledge are waning, deforestation is accelerating.


How else can you help?

Hey, I know some people are broke, or trying to raise money for other worthy projects. So, if you think this is awesome, please, share it with people you know. Or, maybe you have a skill you want to donate.

story:
How it started

JunaProject started out as a simple experiment. Originally the idea was to share a bike with friends and let it travel, passing it from person to person...with the goal of seeing how far it would go.

Then, between a chat and another, things evolved into something bigger.


The Project

Here's the plan: repair three vintage bicycles, one that can be folded, the second that can be disassembled, and the third one that can be extended and shortened.

The idea is, to pass on the bikes from friend to friend, highlighting the principle of sharing in general, and letting them travel around the world.

It's a different way to travel and see the world. We will start as explorers, however we will leave our three beautiful bikes to other people, who will continue the journey living this experience.

Our aim is to document this wonderful adventure with stories, videos, photos that will be uploaded on our website and on social networks!


We set the departure date: May 3 in Ticino (Switzerland)! This incredible journey will officially start on that day!



100Missions

One of the goals of the JunaProject is to have fun with the bicycles... We want to laugh and to interact with people in an amusing way!

For this reason, we have thought up 100 special missions to be carried out during the bikes’ trip. Every rider has the opportunity to choose one of the many missions available.

Here a few examples:
- Mission #15 - Ride the bike as a superhero and help people do their daily tasks
- Mission #22 - Ride from sunset to sunrise… one whole night with the bike
- Mission #42 - Ride the bike with at least 30 balloons attached to it

Click here to see all the 100 missions!

Why are we doing this?

We have decided to use bicycles because it is a sustainable and ecological way to move around. The pace of the bicycle allows us to best observe everything that surrounds us.

These bicycles are easy to carry, they can be folded, disassembled or shortened, and they can be easily placed on any means of transportation, be it train, car, boat, or airplane.

Here are just a couple of messages that we would like to convey through JunaProject:

  • promote the use of bicycles

  • promote healthy living and physical activity

  • promote sustainable transport

  • foster friendship, trust and relationships between people

  • foster the concept of sharing in general

  • have fun, not only with bikes but in life in general

  • dream big!

Your support will fund

  • Bicycle repair and maintenance

  • Bicycle equipment

  • Website, domain, server, hosting maintenance

  • Virtual Private Server or Dedicated Server

  • Multilingual translations of website content and video subtitles

  • Freelancers for solving any kind of website/server/internet problem

  • GPS-Tracker (BikeSpike)

  • If necessary we provide local support for maintenance

  • Freelancer to help us with video editing... our goal is to post as many videos as possible

  • Music licences if needed

Risk and challenges

There are many challenges and, of course, many questions may arise.

  • Will we be able to update the current location of each bicycle?

  • Will we receive all the necessary information from the cyclists?

  • How much time will the bicycles hold out without breaking?

  • How shall we proceed if a bicycle gets lost?

We have created a specific FAQ section, to reduce the risks and explain our project in more detail.

... and another funny video...

story:
Help Our CCL Group Get to DC to Lobby for a Carbon Fee and Dividend

Hi, my name is Maria and I am the group leader of the all volunteer Citizens' Climate Lobby (CCL) in Santa Fe. I, along with many of our group members, am a long-time climate activist. We've joined CCL because we recognize the need for federal legislation on energy and climate issues- you just can't adapt to the moving target of human-induced climate chaos. And, we believe that CCL has the winning formula to succeed on this issue.

Modeled after Gandhi's Satyagraha movement, Citizens' Climate Lobby's purpose is to create the political will for a livable world and to empower individuals to exercise their personal and political power. Economists across the political spectrum have said that CCL's proposed revenue-neutral carbon tax is the most efficient policy proposal to combat carbon emissions. 

At the Citizens' Climate Lobby conference in DC in June we will strategize how to be more effective catalysts of action, and to meet with our legislators – including those who are not convinced of the need for action.

Your contribution will help us learn the best practices and messaging to convince Congress of the need to take decisive, courageous action. Attendees will meet with legislators in their offices in the days immediately following the conference.

The Impact

Citizens' Climate Lobby is all about face-to-face persuasion. And persuasion means about talking with people with whom you disagree. Whether Republican, Democrat, Independent or Socialist, they need to understand the urgency of the situation and that their constituents support action. We have all signed petitions, written letters, and made phone calls; but there is nothing better than looking in the eye of your representative and making your case.

In the last few months we have convinced the Santa Fe City Council and County Commission to pass resolutions supporting policy to reduce carbon emissions; we have met with one of our senators and the staff of the other, and with our US Representative; and we have proposed a Hearing in our state legislature with high profile proponents of a revenue-neutral carbon tax. We are building consensus from the ground up, writing to media outlets, doing research, collaborating with other environmental groups. Send us to DC: maybe we’ll talk some sense into YOUR representatives.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Can't donate money? Do you have airline miles that you can pass along?
  • Share our campaign with others using Indiegogo's share tools!

story:
Who we are and what we want to do

Friends of the Earth Scotland believes in local solutions to global problems – people coming together to make the environment better for everyone.

That’s why we’re bringing a diverse group of activists to the UN climate talks in Paris. It’s vital that we demonstrate people power and show our politicians that communities worldwide are calling for swift, fair action on climate change.

With your help, we can provide financial support to ensure our group includes people from all walks of life. Even a small donation will give vital support to those who cannot afford to make the journey on their own.

What We Need & What You Get

We’ve worked hard to make the trip to Paris as affordable as possible – we’re travelling overnight by bus, and the accommodation in Paris is basic and simple. But it will still cost around £135 per person. This is affordable for some, but not for everyone. If we reach our goal of £2,500, this would allow us to fully fund 16 activists, or 50% of the costs of 32 activists. In line with our principles, we will share the funds fairly based on need.

We'll reward your contribution with a perk to show our appreciation:

  • For a gift of £5, we send you a personal thank you email
  • For a gift of £10, we will send you a pack of FoES climate action stickers
  • For a gift of £50, we will send you a postcard from Paris
  • For a gift of £100 or more, we will write your name and message on a placard and take it to the streets of Paris (*we'll work with you to give your message the most creative presentation we can)

Why people power is important

A strong people’s voice at the Paris climate talks will mean that politicians cannot ignore the needs of the most vulnerable. This will be a major moment for climate justice, putting the voice of people and communities at the centre of international negotiations. We don’t believe that anyone be denied a voice on the grounds of cost. So we’re asking for your help with travel costs for activists with limited means. 

Getting activists to Paris isn’t the whole story.

Bringing activists from Scotland to Paris will mean they can use the energy of the COP21 actions as a catalyst, to launch actions in their neighbourhoods and universities, starting a new chapter in the people’s climate movement. We hope you will be part of this key moment. A donation of any size will make a big difference.

Risks & Challenges

We're working hard to recruit a diverse pool of activists, reaching out to groups like the crofter's association, our partners in Stop Climate Chaos, The Ethnic Minority Environmental Network, Student's groups and Unions.

If we raise more than we need to take activists from Scotland, we will donate to a European solidarity fund, helping activists from countries such as Croatia, Hungary and Bosnia make it to the COP21.

Other Ways You Can Help

We recognise that not everyone will be able to donate towards our cause. Even if you can't make a financial contribution yourself, please share this page amongst your networks. You can also check out our climate briefing page for more details on what is happening.

story:
Us and The Chinampas

Hello!!!! We are an interdisciplinary group (different areas of profession: biological sciences, psychology, and economic science) focused on ecological projects based on the model of permaculture.
We want you to become part of our community and help us build the kitchen and multiple- purpouse  room inside the Tlicuilli Farm (Tlicuilli means "Three stone fire" in Nahuatl language)  so it can have a better service for visiting school groups, camping trips, or when workshops, internships take place on the farm. This would have a impact involving the local community in Mexico City and developing the model for the recovery of the area.
If you support us, you would be part of a project that is developing a model for a sustainable enterprise on a 1.5 acre chinampa that regenerates the natural environment and revives the farming practices used by the ancient cultures of the region. With your support we will have the commodities necessary to involve the local community and improve the work conditions on our chinampa. Our project is located in a poor, but rapidly developing area inside of Mexico City, where there is a great need for quality jobs. Also Mexico City is one of the most polluted cities in the world and the natural area in the eastern part of the city, where this project is located, has very delicate water management problems, while it faces an enormous pressure for urban development. We believe that by involving the community and finding economic uses for this area, we will be able to preserve it in its natural form, as it has been used for food production for hundreds of years. At the same time it would have a very important impact on the air pollution of the city, mitigating climate change, while improving the local economy in a sustainable way.


Become a Chinampa Guardian

We want to built the kitchen and multi-purpose area with our community as an integrative program. That is why we first made a participative design, involving all the people that work on the farm and some technicians that guided us through the architecture and the construction protocols. Now we are funding the material for the natural building and organizing an internship that would take place in November of this year, constructing the infrastructure on the Chinampa Tlicuilli and integrating our community in the activities we are planning for 2017. The kitchen and the multi-purpose area involves a construction of 112 m2, of sheet metal and a thatched roof, wooden columns and crossbars, cob walls, stump floors, and a water catchment system with a cistern. We also plan to install an ecological wood stove, a storage shed, a dishwasher, a hybrid system mixing the wind generator we already have with a solar panel to be able to power the kitchen and dinning room.


If you want to see our expenses and our schedule for the construction to get a clearer idea of where your money is going, take a look here


Four our contributors we have different perks:

The lowest is our Love and gratitude to your support. We also have a Personalized Digital Memory, a sweat lodge, an Agroecology workshop, individual consultancy services and you opportunity to be part of an internship in Natural building.

The sweat lodge takes part inside the chinampa and its a day long activity which also includes one meal and the sweat with use of therapeutic medicinal flowers. The Agroecology workshop will occur in February of 2017 in the chinampa where you are going to learn all about the chinampa ancient agricultural system, we will show you how to grow your own food and you will enjoy of one night camping with all meals included. The internship in natural building is going to take place in November 2016 during the construction of the kitchen and the community room, it includes all accommodation (camping) and meals during the internship.

If we reach 50 % of the goal we will build the kitchen without the dinning room. If 70% of our goal is funded we will construct the kitchen and dinning room, but without the floor or the thatched roof, which we will install another time.


Restore the Chinampas in México City

You can collaborate in The Chinampa 'Tlicuili', a sustainable farm inside of one of few green areas of Mexico City. Even though the natural area were it stands is a place protected by federal and international laws, the urban pressure and the abandonment of sustainable farming activities places it in danger of extinction. This fact compromises the ability to retain the rain water, and mediate other environment impacts, like pollution, breaking the city’s precarious balance. Our project aims for the return to sustainable farming, being a model for restoring and preserving the area.

We have been learning to cultivate and integrate the farm's work since 2011. By now we have built a room with natural construction techniques, and activated four areas: a medicinal garden, a greenhouse, a biointensive orchard, and a circular orchard. Beside the work in this space, we have intervened in another chinampa where we were hired to design and implement the construction of a therapeutic garden and natural buildings. These included a shade house, a bamboo salon, a filter channel, and a composting toilet. Also we have collaborated in multiple educational programs with different schools and universities and our professional formation allows us to overcome all the inconveniences we found in the way.
At the same time we have consolidated us into a working team, capable to perform this kind of projects with our own hands and at low costs, while involving the community. We trust in the power of the community because we experience that power each day on the chinampa. That’s why we believe we can make miracles happen, with a little help from you.
If you want to see a more detailed description of our team Click here



Our Experience and the planning proccess

The project of the Chinampa Tlicuilli started 10 years ago, in the search of a more healthy and sustainable way of living, without leaving the city, hoping there are solutions in natural urban landscapes. Permaciudad as a team has been working in this area for 5 years, and we have been getting close with agriculture practices. Also part of the team has participated in different workshops and university degree programs in agriculture, natural building and permaculture.

Last year we had various activities that included a small internship (with 5 volunteers) in natural building that re-built a room that now is used for multiple purposes with ecological techniques (the entrance to the temazcal, massage room, changing room for the guests and bedroom for the guard). We also worked together with the Autonomous University of Mexico City (UACM) developing the circular orchard and teaching the students about agro-ecology, the chinampas and permaculture.

We are planning to use the economic resource of the crowdfunding campaign to fund our efforts. After achieving this goal we are going to work without volunteers for two weeks to be able to buy the material, transport and prepare it, and set up the columns and the crossbars that will support the walls and the roof. The other part of the materials that are used for the construction are local and from natural sources so when the volunteers come the first two days we will spend this time on theoretic sessions and preparing the materials (cow manure, straw, etc). We want to invite some friends to work that are a carpenter and a builder and that will support with wood tools and getting the foundation in place. After that, with the volunteers, we are going to work the remaining 10 days on learning how to do the mixture and build a wall. They would also be able to watch the installation of the metal sheets for the roof. The last 4 days would be spent on the details of the construction (plastering, construction of the stove, installing the dishwasher, the doors and windows, the stump floor, and the thatched roof). If you want to see a detailed schedule of the construction please click here.

With a little help from you and your friends

If you don't have the economic funds to support the Chinampa Helper project please help us reach more people. We can change the world together, involving the community around us, taking care of nature and developing a sustainable enterprise in one of the biggest cities on earth.

Please help us spreading the voice and achieving our goal. 


Versión Español


Nosotros y las Chinampas

Hola, somos un grupo interdisciplinario (formado en diferentes áreas: economía, psicología y ciencias biológicas) enfocado en proyectos ecológicos basados en el modelo de permacultura. Queremos que formes parte de nuestra comunidad y nos ayudes a construir la cocina y un salón de usos múltiples dentro de la Chinampa Tlicuilli (Fogón de tres piedras en Náhuatl) para poder brindar un mejor servicio cuando grupos escolares y visitantes vengan a la granja, así como para los campamentos y programas de aprendizaje que ocurran en la chinampa. Esto tendría un impacto positivo al involucrar a la comunidad local de la Ciudad de México y al generar un modelo para la recuperación del área.
Si nos apoyas serás parte de un proyecto que está desarrollando un modelo para el desarrollo sustentable en una chinampa de 1.5 acreas (0.7 ha) que regenere el ambiente natural  y reviva las prácticas agrícolas ancestrales locales. Con tu apoyo  contaremos con las comodidades necesarias para involucrar a la comunidad local  y mejorar las condiciones de trabajo dentro de la chinampa. El proyecto está localizado en un área de bajos recursos económicos, pero que se desarrolla de forma acelerada dentro de la Ciudad de México y donde existe una necesidad  de trabajo dignos. Además es una de las ciudades más contaminadas y el área natural protegida al oriente de la ciudad, donde el proyecto se encuentra, tiene serios problemas de hundimientos e inundaciones mientras enfrenta una presión por parte del desarrollo urbano. Creemos que involucrando a la comunidad  y encontrando un uso económico para esta área permitirá preservarla con su ecosistema natural  como ha sido por cientos de años para producir comida. Al mismo tiempo  esto tendrá un efecto positivo en  en la polución del aire ayudando a mitigar el cambio climático mientras se mejora la economía local.

Convierte en un Guardián de la Chinampa

Queremos construir la cocina y un salón de usos múltiples con nuestra comunidad como un programa de integración. Por esta razón realizamos un diseño participativo involucrando a todos los que trabajan en la chinampa y algunos técnicos que nos guiaron en la parte arquitectónica y en los protocolos de construcción. Ahora estamos fondeando  los recursos económicos para la compra del material y los gastos del internado que se llevarán a cabo en la construcción e integrar a nuestra comunidad a las actividades de 2017. La cocina y el salón de usos múltiples consta de 112 m2 de construcción, lamina de metal, un techo natural, paredes de COB, piso de tocones, una alacena, estufa, lavadero, un sistema de captura de agua y un sistema híbrido con una celda fotovoltáica y un generador eólico que se encuentra en la granja para abastecer la cocina y el salón de usos múltiples.
Si quieres ver nuestro gastos con más detalles haz click-

Recompensas para nuestros donatarios

La primera recompensa es nuestro cariño y gratitud por tu apoyo. También contamos con una memoria digital personalizada, un temazcal, un taller de agroecología, servicio de consultoría y la oportunidad de participar en un internado de construcción natural.
El temazcal se realiza dentro de la chinampra tlicuilli y es una actividad que se va desde las 10:00 hasta las 18:00 horas que incluye la comida  y el baño de vapor prehispánico con plantas medicinales. En el taller de agroecología que ocurrirá en Febrero de 2017 en la chinampa vas a tener la posibilidad de aprender cómo cultivar tu comida y disfrutarás de una noche de campamento con todo incluido.
Si alcanzamos el 50% de nuestro objetivo contruiremos la cocina sin el salón de usos múltiples. Si alcanzamos el 70% de nuestro objetivo haremos la cocina y el comedor sin el techo de tule ni el piso de tocones y eso lo instalaremos en otra ocasión.

Restaurando las chinampas en la Ciudad de México

Puedes colaborar en la Chinampa Tlicuilli, una granja sustentable dentro de una de las pocas áreas verdes dentro de la Ciudad de México. Aunque este lugar se encuentra protegido por leyes federales e internacionales la presión urbana y el abandono de las actividades agrícolas sustentables la ponen en peligro de desaparecer. Esto comprometería la capacidad para retener agua de lluvia y mediar otros impactos ambientales como la contaminación atmosférica. Nuestro proyecto busca el regreso a las actividades sustentables siendo un modelo para la recuperación y preservación del área.
Nosotros hemos estado aprendiendo a cultivar y nos integramos al trabajo desde 2011. En estos momentos hemos hecho un cuarto con elementos naturales y hemos activado cuatro áreas de cultivo: un jardín medicinal, un huerto circular, un invernadero y un huerto biointensivo. Además del espacio en la chinampa hemos colaborado en programas educativos con diferentes escuelas y universidades. Nuestra formación profesional nos ayuda a sobrepasar los retos e inconvenientes que nos encontramos en el camino.
Al mismo tiempo nos hemos consolidado como un grupo capaz de realizar este tipo de proyectos con nuestras propias manos y a bajo costo mientras involucramos a la comunidad. Creemos en el poder de la comunidad porque lo vivimos todos los días. Es por eso que consideramos que podemos hacer maravillas con un poco de tu ayuda y la de tus amigos.


Nuestra experiencia y el proceso de planeación

El proyecto de la Chinampa Tlicuilli inició hace 10 años por la búsqueda de un estilo de vida más saludable sin dejar la ciudad,  creyendo que existen soluciones a los paisajes urbano-naturales. Como Permaciudad hemos estado trabajando 5 años  en el área y nos hemos familiarizado con las prácticas agrícolas ancestrales y las actuales. Además parte del equipo ha participado en programas educativos de permacultura, construcción natural, agricultura y agroecología.
El año pasado realizamos varias actividades que incluyeron un internado (con 5 asistentes) en construcción natural, donde  reconstruimos un cuarto que hoy es usado para múltiples funciones (entrada al Temazcal, cuarto de masajes, vestidor y cuarto de vigilancia. Además participamos con la Universidad de la Ciudad de México (UACM) en el desarrollo del huerto circular como parte de un programa educativo en el que se les enseñó a los estudiantes de agroecología, las chinampas y permacultura.
Estamos planeando obtener el recurso económico a través de la campaña de Crowdfunding. Después de lograr esta meta vamos a trabajar sin los voluntarios por 2 semanas para poder comprar, transportar y preparar todo el material para la construcción. La otra parte de los materiales son de origen local y van a ser recolectados durante los primeros días del internado. Queremos invitar a algunos amigos, carpintero y albañil  a trabajar para que nos apoyen con las herramientas para el trabajo de la madera y levantar los cimientos. Cuando lleguen los voluntarios vamos a dedicar los siguientes días a sesiones teóricas y la recolecta de materiales. Los asistentes van a poder observar la instalación de los travesaños y el techo. Los últimos 4 días se realizarán los detalles de la construcción  (revoque, construcción de la estufa,  puertas y ventana, el piso de troncos y el techo de carrizo).

Con un poco de tu ayuda y la de tus amigos

Si no tienes los recursos económicos para apoyar el proyecto de “Chinampa Helper” por favor ayúdanos a llegar a más personas. Juntos podemos cambiar el mundo, involucrando a la comunidad cercana a nosotros y cuidando la naturaleza en el desarrollo de un proyecto sustentable en una de las ciudades más grandes del mundo.
Ayúdanos difundiendo para alcanzar nuestro objetivo,

Por esta razón realizamos un diseño participativo involucrando a todos los que trabajan en la chinampa y algunos técnicos que nos guiaron en la parte arquitectónica y en los protocolos de construcción. Ahora estamos fondeando  los recursos económicos para la compra del material y los gastos del internado que se llevarán a cabo en la construcción e integrar a nuestra comunidad a las actividades de 2017. La cocina y el salón de usos múltiples consta de 112 m2 de construcción, lamina de metal, un techo natural, paredes de COB, piso de tocones, una alacena, estufa, lavadero, un sistema de captura de agua y un sistema híbrido con una celda fotovoltáica y un generador eólico que se encuentra en la granja para abastecer la cocina y el salón de usos múltiples.Si quieres ver nuestro gastos con más detalles haz click-Recompensas para nuestros donatarios
La primera recompensa es nuestro cariño y gratitud por tu apoyo. También contamos con una memoria digital personalizada, un temazcal, un taller de agroecología, servicio de consultoría y la oportunidad de participar en un internado de construcción natural.El temazcal se realiza dentro de la chinampra tlicuilli y es una actividad que se va desde las 10:00 hasta las 18:00 horas que incluye la comida  y el baño de vapor prehispánico con plantas medicinales. En el taller de agroecología que ocurrirá en Febrero de 2017 en la chinampa vas a tener la posibilidad de aprender cómo cultivar tu comida y disfrutarás de una noche de campamento con todo incluido. Si alcanzamos el 50% de nuestro objetivo contruiremos la cocina sin el salón de usos múltiples. Si alcanzamos el 70% de nuestro objetivo haremos la cocina y el comedor sin el techo de tule ni el piso de tocones y eso lo instalaremos en otra ocasión.Restaurando las chinampas en la Ciudad de MéxicoPuedes colaborar en la Chinampa Tlicuilli, una granja sustentable dentro de una de las pocas áreas verdes dentro de la Ciudad de México. Aunque este lugar se encuentra protegido por leyes federales e internacionales la presión urbana y el abandono de las actividades agrícolas sustentables la ponen en peligro de desaparecer. Esto comprometería la capacidad para retener agua de lluvia y mediar otros impactos ambientales como la contaminación atmosférica. Nuestro proyecto busca el regreso a las actividades sustentables siendo un modelo para la recuperación y preservación del área.Nosotros hemos estado aprendiendo a cultivar y nos integramos al trabajo desde 2011. En estos momentos hemos hecho un cuarto con elementos naturales y hemos activado cuatro áreas de cultivo: un jardín medicinal, un huerto circular, un invernadero y un huerto biointensivo. Además del espacio en la chinampa hemos colaborado en programas educativos con diferentes escuelas y universidades. Nuestra formación profesional nos ayuda a sobrepasar los retos e inconvenientes que nos encontramos en el camino.Al mismo tiempo nos hemos consolidado como un grupo capaz de realizar este tipo de proyectos con nuestras propias manos y a bajo costo mientras involucramos a la comunidad. Creemos en el poder de la comunidad porque lo vivimos todos los días. Es por eso que consideramos que podemos hacer maravillas con un poco de tu ayuda y la de tus amigos.Nuestra experiencia y el proceso de planeaciónEl proyecto de la Chinampa Tlicuilli inició hace 10 años por la búsqueda de un estilo de vida más saludable sin dejar la ciudad,  creyendo que existen soluciones a los paisajes urbano-naturales. Como Permaciudad hemos estado trabajando 5 años  en el área y nos hemos familiarizado con las prácticas agrícolas ancestrales y las actuales. Además parte del equipo ha participado en programas educativos de permacultura, construcción natural, agricultura y agroecología.El año pasado realizamos varias actividades que incluyeron un internado (con 5 asistentes) en construcción natural, donde  reconstruimos un cuarto que hoy es usado para múltiples funciones (entrada al Temazcal, cuarto de masajes, vestidor y cuarto de vigilancia. Además participamos con la Universidad de la Ciudad de México (UACM) en el desarrollo del huerto circular como parte de un programa educativo en el que se les enseñó a los estudiantes de agroecología, las chinampas y permacultura.Estamos planeando obtener el recurso económico a través de la campaña de Crowdfunding. Después de lograr esta meta vamos a trabajar sin los voluntarios por 2 semanas para poder comprar, transportar y preparar todo el material para la construcción. La otra parte de los materiales son de origen local y van a ser recolectados durante los primeros días del internado. Queremos invitar a algunos amigos, carpintero y albañil  a trabajar para que nos apoyen con las herramientas para el trabajo de la madera y levantar los cimientos. Cuando lleguen los voluntarios vamos a dedicar los siguientes días a sesiones teóricas y la recolecta de materiales. Los asistentes van a poder observar la instalación de los travesaños y el techo. Los últimos 4 días se realizarán los detalles de la construcción  (revoque, construcción de la estufa,  puertas y ventana, el piso de troncos y el techo de carrizo). Con un poco de tu ayuda y la de tus amigosSi no tienes los recursos económicos para apoyar el proyecto de “Chinampa Helper” por favor ayúdanos a llegar a más personas. Juntos podemos cambiar el mundo, involucrando a la comunidad cercana a nosotros y cuidando la naturaleza en el desarrollo de un proyecto sustentable en una de las ciudades más grandes del mundo.Ayúdanos difundiendo para alcanzar nuestro objetivo,

story:
Help Blue Mountains Biodiversity Project fight destructive timber sales on four National Forests in Eastern Oregon! 

You can help us by contributing to this year’s field season. Every summer, our volunteers help us field survey thousands of acres of proposed timber sales. Their survey sheets and photos become evidence used in our comments to the Forest Service, and in potential negotiations and litigation. A fully funded field season in 2015 will help us reach a level of greater financial stability for our growing organization.  

Photo of a healthy creek in the Descutes National Forest


What is the Blue Mountains Biodiversity Project?

The Blue Mountains Biodiversity Project has been working to protect and restore the ecosystems of Eastern Oregon for 24 years. We work to stop or modify projects on federal lands that threaten ecological integrity and biodiversity, such as logging, road building, livestock grazing, herbicide and biocide use, and mining. Our work area includes the Blue Mountains in the Malheur, Ochoco, and Umatilla National Forests, and the Eastern Oregon Cascades in the Deschutes National Forest. Our work is important for the conservation of numerous species, including salmon, wolves, lynx, rare woodpeckers, Pacific fishers, marten, and wolverine.

We field-check every major timber sale in our geographic work area. Getting to look at timber sales and grazing allotments in person provides us with valuable information including possible legal violations within the timber sale, specific environmental conditions, and which areas to prioritize for defending. During the upcoming field season we will field-check eight major timber sales and three livestock grazing allotments. Volunteers are the backbone of our field-checking efforts. Through our summer volunteer program, we have trained over 200 interns in forest ecology and activist skills.


Photo of an intern in a stand of healthy Old Growth Ponderosa Pine Trees


What are some of our accomplishments?

We have a proven track record of successfully defending forests from ecologically destructive timber sales and other projects. We have stopped the logging of many thousands of acres of forests, including ancient and never-logged forests, post-fire and riparian areas, moist mixed-conifer forests, and potential wilderness and roadless areas. In 2014 alone, we and our environmental allies saved over 10,000 large trees and stopped logging on approximately 8,800 acres in the Snow Basin timber sale. This legal victory in the Ninth Circuit Court upheld the argument that the Forest Service could not move forward with their plans to violate existing legal standards in the Snow Basin sale (such as those protecting large trees), and set important precedent providing for increased protections for other similar timber sales. In 2014 we also stopped logging on 1,300 acres in the Rocket timber sale. These are only a few of our accomplishments! Please see our website to learn about some of our other many accomplishments.


What is at stake?

This field season will be one of our busiest yet. The timber sales we will be field-checking pose threats to water quality, important wildlife habitats, and numerous species. For example, the Tiger-Webb sale in the Umatilla National Forest proposes logging in previously unlogged and pristine forest, roadless areas, scenic canyons, and moist-mixed conifer forest. Logging is also planned in steep areas over streams- potentially putting water quality and fish at risk. The Ringo timber sale on the Deschutes National Forest proposes to log in Northern spotted owl habitat,  other important wildlife habitats, and areas with high recreational use. The Ringo sale would also log in magnificent mixed conifer old growth forests containing Sugar pine, White pine, and rare Shasta redfir, as well as Mountain Hemlock, Grand fir, Douglas fir, and Ponderosa pine. The Magone timber sale on the Malheur National Forest plans to extensively log beautiful forests around the popular Magone Lake recreation area, manage inventoried roadless areas, and further degrades mixed conifer and Ponderosa forests in already over-logged and over-grazed areas. Several of the livestock grazing allotments we will be surveying pose threats to water quality and fish, and may negatively affect Redband trout, rare Oregon spotted frogs, and Columbia spotted frogs. 


How will these funds be used?

Timber sales on National Forests in eastern Oregon have greatly increased in size compared to recent years. In past years, timber sales ranged from 2,000 to 6,000 acres per sale. Average timber sale size is now 4,000 to 10,000 acres of commercial logging per sale. Consequently, our workload in relation to defending these areas from logging has also increased. In response, we have recently expanded our paid staff from one to two people. In addition, over the last few years our average volunteer force has increased from a dozen or so volunteers per field season to 45 in 2014.


Photo of Director Karen and intern working with the map and compass


Our funding has not kept pace with the increased staff and volunteer-related expenses associated with covering more and larger timber sales. Our lean budget is used for two minimally paid staff people, truck repairs, gas, vehicle insurance, field equipment, film development, expenses for lawsuits, and other basic needs.

We need to fully fund this year’s field season in order to put us in a better position to:

·  Collect site-specific, in-depth information during the field season

·  Have adequate funding for all gas, vehicle maintenance and repairs, staff pay, and field equipment necessary for the field season

·  Use the information we collect during the 2015 field season to protect the important ecosystems that are currently at risk

·  Help provide us with the financial stability and staff capacity necessary to successfully continue our work for the remainder of the year

While some of the necessary funds for our 2015 field season have already been raised through other sources such as grants, we continue to have a funding gap. All of the money raised from this Indiegogo drive would go towards our field season expenses.

·  $3,500 would go toward field expenses including: gas, vehicle expenses, and field equipment (for example: compasses, cameras, maps, survey sheets, batteries).

·  $3,000 would go toward the cost of paying two paid staff people to lead field crews and coordinate and train volunteers during the field season.

Photo measuring the diameter of an Old Growth Ponderosa Pine Tree


If successful, this Indiegogo effort will help us overcome immediate financial barriers, allow us to retain our staff capacity for the remainder of the year, and achieve some of our long-term organizational goals. Contributing to our Indiegogo crowdfunding effort will help to ensure that our work can continue this year and into the future. 

Even if we do not reach our goal, funds would still go toward our 2015 field season. 



Photo of an Old Growth Juniper 

No other organization in eastern Oregon covers as much ground as we do (literally!), and no other organization so consistently and strongly challenges destructive timber sales and toxic herbicide use. However, we face financial challenges to fully fund this year’s field season and in gaining greater financial stability. Luckily, we are fortunate to have a community of experienced volunteers helping us with fundraising efforts and with field-checking. We also have a well-established reputation for important environmental victories. Please help us continue to “walk our talk” in the forests. Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

We are two college kids with an interest and passion for the environment and education of all people. What's better than saving the environment yourself? Getting people who deny climate change to save it with you! We want to provide a tangible, environmentally-friendly product with a flair of sass, that not only holds your groceries but also holds your political ground. 

From left to right: Molly and Becky! :)

Our Campaign Image is a reusable bag prototype, we promise it will look a lot better once you help us reach our goal!


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal of $500 will help us achieve the following: 

 - Purchasing and designing the reusable bags

 - Shipping said bags to retailers and customers

 - Advertising our product

 - Carbon credit purchase to offset footprint of bag production

    The Impact

    Reusable bags shouldn't always be marketed with tie-dye, "tree hugger," baby seals, or a recycling sign. You have to speak to your audience, the WHOLE audience. This is why we want to create Sassy Sacs to empower and validate those who fight their inner environmentalist. 

      Risks & Challenges

       - People may be offended by the sarcasm and sass of the Sassy Sacs. 

       - Demographically speaking, is our intended audience motivated to purchase a Sassy Sacs?

       - Climate change will take over before the production of one bag is complete...

        Other Ways You Can Help

         - Tell your friends! Brag about the cool Sassy Sacs you just discovered! 

         - Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word through Facebook, Twitter, or Email!

story:
Solar Fest Description

Solar San Antonio (SSA) is a nonprofit organization dedicated to transforming the city of San Antonio, Texas into a leader in renewable energy. Founded in 1999 by civic leader and activist Bill Sinkin, SSA has helped San Antonio rank 6th in the nation for solar power deployment.

SSA will be hosting the 13th annual Solar Fest on Saturday, October 4, 2014 from 10a.m.-3p.m. which will be during the National Solar Tour put on by the American Solar Energy Society. Solar Fest will be an official stop on the tour! We invite the community out to enjoy solar demonstrations, great food, and fun under the sun. An important annual event for South Texas, Solar Fest will have 40 to 60 exhibitors offering valuable information about solar and other renewable energy products, green building options, green products for home and office use, and a variety of other offerings. 

The 13th Annual Solar Fest will be a particularly exciting event.  SSA is partnering with local community college Alamo Colleges to host the festival on the grounds of San Antonio College.  The central hub of the event will be the recently dedicated William R. Sinkin (WRS) EcoCentro, named after the founder of SSA.

The WRS EcoCentro houses and displays the following: composting, community gardening, 3,000 gallon water catchment tank and five 30 gallon tanks, 135 solar panels, xeriscaping and native plant garden, electric vehicle charging station, highly rated thermopane windows, energy efficient hot water heater and AC units, energy efficient lighting and demonstrations for solar thermal, solar energy, spray foam insulation, and historical upgrades.

Participants will include CPS Energy and the City of San Antonio.  There will be a kids area, tent talks, and other special presentations.  The VIA green bus and electric cars will demonstrate new transportation options.

Alamo Colleges is doing outreach to all the campuses to let students know about the festival.  Solar San Antonio is doing outreach to all the nearby neighborhood associations to encourage their notifying their residents of the festival.  Both organizations are putting the event on calendars and sending out information to the media.  Social media will also be used extensively to encourage people to attend.

With both of the organizations working to promote this event, Solar San Antonio projects attendance at between 4,000 and 5,000 people.

What We Need 

The aim of Solar Fest is to make solar energy information accessible to the public and encourage sustainable living practices. The event also serves as a fundraiser for SSA, which depends on generous sponsorships from supporters. Funding for the event is needed to cover the following expenses including:

·  Booths and canopies for the exhibitors,

·  Street closures and barricades,

·  Security,

·  Electricity from renewable energy sources,

·  Kid zone activities,

·  Advertising and signage,

·  Meals for volunteers and sponsors, and

·  T-shirts.

What You Get

Make a tax-deductible contribution and you are eligible for a discounted ticket at 3-day SXSW Eco Conference taking place Oct 6-8th in Austin, Texas. (visit www.sxsweco.com for more information) Discounted ticket price is $195. (Walk-up price is $395)

Additionally, for your generous donation, you will receive the following rewards:

$25 - name on donor sign at Solar Fest

$50 – name on donor sign at Solar Fest and recognition on Webpage

$100 – name on donor sign at Solar Fest, recognition on Webpage, and Solar Fest 2014 T-shirt

$250 – name on donor sign at Solar Fest, recognition on Webpage, Solar Fest 2014 T-shirt, and name included on T-Shirt

$500 - Invite to VIP Donor Reception - Date to Be Determined plus all of the above

Beyond Solar Fest

Your donation to cover the costs of Solar Fest will free up funds for our ongoing work in the community:

·  Speaking engagements at schools and other venues

·  Conferences and film screenings to educate the community about topics including climate change and resiliency

·  Engaging with key stakeholders on policy issues to support the growth of solar deployment

·  Maintaining Bring Solar Home Campaign, which connects people interested in solar with the solar industry.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, we appreciate volunteers for the day of Solar Fest to help set up, manage the kids zone, and clean up. If you are available, please visit http://solarsanantonio.wufoo.com/forms/s7x3k7/ to sign up!

story:
PERU-YUNGAY

A HOME FOR SMILING AGAIN

 

We are both 30-year-old Italian architects Sara e Chiara.Our project would create a new way for social assistance in this community and offer job opportunities for the citizens:

This project consists of a multi-purpose building for 60 people (50 seniors and 10 children) to give them a reason to SMILE!!!

LIFE IN THE PERUVIAN ANDES

It’s hard not to be impressed by the central Andean region in Ancash, Peru with its striking landscape at 3.000 meters above sea level (more than 9,000 feet). Here is where the mountain chains aptly named Cordillera Blanca for its snow and Cordillera Negra for its striking features run parallel, where campesinos crowd the markets in their colored clothes, where 4.000 varieties of potatoes grow to flavour any Peruvian dish. The area includes the town of Yungay, destroyed by an earthquake in 1970 and entirely rebuilt by the citizens themselves. Despite the pristine mountain setting, the Andean communities face daily challenges:

PROBLEMS

  • Lack of drinking water

One of the main problems that impacts the “campesinos” livelihood and health, it involves:

- Inability to drink natural flowing water;

- Inability to eat raw fruits and vegetables;

- Inability to provide water sources for animals.

  • Abandoned Elderly

Life in the Andes is particularly difficult for the elderly whose lives are defined by hard laborious work in the fields that lead to :

- Inability to travel for long distances, to buy food and water, and to cultivate their land because of fatigue and illness;

- High cost of medication and treatment;

- Considerable distance between home and health posts;

- Absence of family support for cultural reasons and community understanding about this issue.

  • Lack of support for children

Alcoholism is a widespread problem for this community. Fathers of families frequently drink excessively and become aggressive towards their family members, especially their children. The youngest members of the family are forced to work the land, tend to the store or the market stand under the harsh treatment from their parents.

There are few options of assistance for these families and limited knowledge of child psychology issues.

These problems are the major reasons for us to design and realize this project.

ABOUT US AND OUR PERUVIAN PARTNERS

We are both 30-year-old Italian architects who have lived as volunteers with the movement, OMG (Operation Mato Grosso www.artesanosdonbosco.com), which has worked for more than 40 years in Latin America, and on behalf of an NGO IBO Italy (http://www.iboitalia.org/it/  and  http://www.iboitalia.org/it/progetti-nel-mondo).

During this experience, a local association called "Charities of Yungay" asked us to design and build a multi-purpose facility that seeks solutions to the many challenges facing the elderly and children in their community.

We are taking on the design of this center with the aim of entrusting it to the local organization. Our devotion for this place and its people is demonstrated in the work we’ve already done as volunteers with the OMG movement that organizes free schools and co-operatives of Peruvian artisans.

OUR PROJECT WOULD CREATE A NEW WAY FOR SOCIAL ASSISTANCE IN THIS COMMUNITY AND OFFER JOB OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE CITIZENS.

Moreover, all the pavilions will be built using local techniques of construction and traditional building materials such as bricks, wood, and adobe used in many homes to keep the structure dry from the rain and warm in the cold nights.

THE PROJECT:

A PLACE TO EAT, TO PLAY, TO REST AND TO FIND  THE SMILE AT LAST!

  • What do we want to accomplish?

Our whole project consists of a multi-purpose facility that will accommodate 50 elderly and 10 children. The structure will consist of several pavilions with different functions to be carried out in several stages. The remaining part of the land is designed for green spaces available to the whole community and gardens managed by the project’s collaborators who will seek to employ local residents.

The structure will be built on a plot of land in Yungay measuring almost 1300 square meters which has already been purchased by the "Charity of Yungay" (local association), through a fundraising activity.

This fundraising ($ 40,000) is aimed particularly for the completion of the first pavilion that includes the kitchen, dining hall and toilets.

  • Who is realizing the project?

The whole project will be coordinated and constructed by members of the cooperative "Artesanos Don Bosco" OMG.

THE PHASES OF CONSTRUCTION OF THE ENTIRE PROJECT (long-run goal)

  • Pavilion 1: kitchen, dining hall and toilet and arrangement of the outer (green spaces and gardens) _ SUBJECT TO THIS FUNDRAISING_
  • Pavilion 2: nursing care and clinics open to the entire community
  • Pavilion 3: rooms for seniors who need assistance
  • Pavilion 4: workshops and activities for children (bakery and tailoring)

HOW CAN YOU HELP US?

Following us on facebook and twitter (https://www.facebook.com/PeruYungayHomeForSmilingAgain and https://twitter.com/SMILING_PERU ) where we’ll be spreading the word about our campaign, updating you on the progress of this project, and sharing information about people we are helping.

This is your chance to help those who truly need the help.

GIVE A SMILETO:

  • Children who have grown up to fast in the adult working world for lack of a place to play and feel safe;
  • Single mothers who have to work long hours to secure basic needs ;
  • Elderly persons who have little strength in them and few family around them for support.

ALL TOGETHER WE CAN HELP THEM!!!

  • We can be strong.
  • We can change people's lives.
  • With our experience we have understood that it’s possible to do it so that we believe strongly in this concrete possibility to provide these Peruvian people with a great joy and a better life.

We look forward to starting this project as soon as we receive your funds and keep you updated with the progress reached day by day.

We will do our best to achieve these results and even now we thank you so much for your contribution and for your "GIVING SMILES".

WHAT DO WE EARN?

  • The smile of these people;
  • The satisfaction of giving them a better life;
  • New friends, because we will put you into contact with them and you could write them whenever you want
  • A wonderful experience: you may come and visit us in Yungay (Peru) and we will be happy to let you see how fundamental had been your help, also sharing with your new friends your culture to create a new way of "tourism".

story:
Hello friends. I've been accepted to facilitate a workshop called Being Nests: From Our Guts to Our Gardens to Our Galaxies at the Knowledge/Culture/Ecologies Conference in Santiago Chile, November 15-18th, 2017! Super excited and grateful. And...since I'm by no means a headliner, I'm having to pay my way down, with the conference fees around $300 and the flights currently in the $800-$1000 range (and rising fast) which unfortunately makes it out of my ability to pay on my own as an elementary school garden teacher. So...I'm asking for help traveling down there from the Bay Area. If any of you are able to either donate to this indiegogo I just put together or support in other ways, I'm so deeply grateful for any help you're able to offer. I'm just leaving the indiegogo open for one week, so I can hopefully still find cheaper tickets while they're available.
 


The conference is asking urgent and important questions: "If life on earth is changing for everybody and everything, how can we invent different habitats, milieus, and ways of being together that enable more things to matter and make a difference? How are novel forms of social cohesion emerging around socio-environmental conflicts and justice? What experimental knowledge and political practices do we need to understand these emergent socioecologies and provoke new ones? And how do these profound earthly challenges intersect with obdurate and unevenly distributed forms of violence and inequality/exploitation particularly in the ‘global south’?" They are inviting "academics, practitioners and activists from a range of backgrounds and institutions to debate the shifting roles of knowledge, culture and ecologies in historical, contemporary and future scenarios of crisis, environmental justice and inequality, governance, socio-environmental change and reckonings with nature and a diversity of cosmologies."  http://knowledgeculture.org/
 


 

My workshop (Being Nests) Embracing Our Embedded Holobiont Bodies, from Our Guts, to Our Gardens, to Our Galaxies explores ways we can regenerate healthy relationships over vast scales ~ between our "personal" bodies, the transforming body of the planet, and across our enormous cosmic bodies, all nested within one another. We'll be creatively and somatically tracing the connections between our microbiome, our fascia, and our epigenetic lineages, in cahoots with our watersheds, foodsheds, and bioregions, even mapping the long seasons of our galactic superclusters. Our allies are abundant! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yL8ATquhJXA
 


In my first professional international travel since receiving an MA in Integral Ecologies from the California Institute of Integral Studies in SF, I will listen, learn, and absorb all I can from the multiple perspectives and diverse ways of understanding being shared at this conference, offer the gems of perspective I'm able, and report back to our beloved local home communities the most skillful wisdoms, strategies, and creative engagements around our shared climate concerns.

I hope you are all wonderful, finding solidarities amidst all the change ~ and thank you for your consideration. 

~Josh

ecocourageous.com
