story:
“Saving the Planet One Mile at a Time... for Our Keiki (Children)” 


David is doing good things…

David Jung is the owner and general manager of EcoCab Hawaii.  A company founded on the principle of striving to meet the highest level of social responsibilities expected of them by the community it serves.  In an effort to reduce carbon output, EcoCab launched Hawaii’s first hybrid electric fleet of taxis in 2012.  The company has now embarked on providing the highest level of service to our disabled community by becoming Hawaii’s first taxi company to purchase a fleet of MV-1 – America’s only purpose built wheelchair accessible vans. 


David needs a rest…

Since launching EcoCab in September of 2012 with just 7 cabs and 20 employees, my team and I have worked tirelessly not just to survive but to thrive.  EcoCab is now 44 cabs and 120 employees strong!!!  But the business world can be brutal, dirty, and downright nasty; it takes its toll on you physically, emotionally and, perhaps most importantly, spiritually.

So after 3 years in the “trenches” without a break, I want to set aside a week to cleanse my body and soul by supporting something that is the antithesis of business.  Shriners Hospitals for Children represents the pure and unadulterated goodness of humanity.  They transform the lives of those that we hold most dear, our children, while asking for NOTHING in return.  

Please visit their website:  http://www.shrinershonolulu.org/


David needs your help…

Please support the children of Shriners.  As an expression of my appreciation for your generosity and to raise awareness for the great work of Shriners, I will be embarking on a 130+ mile, 5 day perimeter walk of Oahu.  Scott, my brother and co-founder of EcoCab, will be joining me on the walk as support, i.e. he will be carrying the water and backpack with the tent since he’s younger and “presumably” stronger than me ;-)

Here are the essential elements of the Walk 

What:  130+ Mile Perimeter Walk of Oahu.

When:  6:00 a.m., Saturday, August 22, 2015 to (estimated) Noon, Thursday, August 27, 2015.

Where:  Beginning and ending at 3060 Ualena Street, EcoCab’s facility.

How:  Tent, backpack, well fitted shoes, sheer grit, and hopefully a high tolerance for pain.  Also, David and Scott will be chronicling their walk on EcoCab’s Facebook – edited and censored ;-) 

Once again, David, Scott and all of us at EcoCab family humbly ask for your support for this very worthy cause by donating $10, $15, $20 or more.

If you want to learn more about EcoCab Hawaii, please visit our website at www.ecocabhawaii.com and like us on Facebook.

MAHALO!

story:
Our Story

In June of 2011, a team of four cyclists will ride across America to share the Alabamboo story. The Alabamboo initiative is a growing movement to bring sustainable bamboo production to Alabama, thus strengthening the economic and social fabric of the rural south.

We will converge in Greensboro, Alabama and build bicycles from Alabama-grown bamboo. We will then pedal west for two months, stopping at various locations to shed light on Alabamboo, sustainability, alternative transportation, and the benefits of bamboo all in the hopes of shaping a positive future.

The Impact
We are planning to build a workshop in Greensboro, Alabama that will be the future home for building Common Cycles. This facility will create jobs and empower local residents with access to affordable and sustainable transportation options. The bamboo bike facility and cross-country bike ride is a small part of what Alabamboo is aiming to accomplish. We've partnered with Marsha Folsom, wife of former Alabama Governor Jim Folsom, to develop this ride as one part of a much larger bamboo initiative. Marsha is helping lead a movement to have bamboo grown as a sustainable agricultural crop in Alabama in partnership with Washington-based Booshoot Gardens. Booshoot has developed technology to produce bamboo tissue culture for propagating bamboo rapidly at a large scale—and Alabama is ripe for growing it. We branded the initiative "Alabamboo" as the first step to making Alabama mean bamboo the way Florida means oranges, Idaho means potatoes and Maine means lobsters.


Project M, Alabamboo and Common working together
The Alabamboo bike ride is a joint effort between these three initiatives. Our action is a living embodiment of the power of collaboration.

ABOUT PROJECT M

Project M is a collective of designers and creative doers who develop ideas to improve the world and work together to make them happen. We’ve delivered supplies to Hurrican Katrina victims, opened a pie shop and community center in rural Alabama, built a horseshoe park in Detroit, protested in Iceland, inspired bankers in Germany, and provided clean drinking water to homes in need—just to name a few. Many of these projects have been covered by the New York Times, GOOD, Fast Company, and numerous design publications.


ABOUT ALABAMBOO

The United States is the largest importer of bamboo in the world, with no domestic, commercially available supply of its own. Our goal is that Alabamboo will one day represent the largest domestically available resource. Bamboo is a valuable and sustainable alternative for many products including textiles, wood floors, furniture, and paper products. It is also one the most efficient carbon-sequestering plants in the world. There are many misconceptions about bamboo and the truths make it more of a miracle plant than a nuisance. There is already a growing movement taking place in Alabama and we want to be a part of sharing the story.


ABOUT COMMON

COMMON is one part community, one part business prototyper, and one part collaborative brand. COMMON is a living network of creative people rapidly prototyping dozens or hundreds of progressive businesses designed to solve social problems—connected to a brand that’s community designed, community owned, and community directed. We’re confident that benefiting people, communities, society, the environment and future generations is the new advantage in business. We’re launching the COMMON CYCLES brand in support of this transition from competitive advantage to collaborative advantage.


What We Need
With 5 core riders, we are asking for enough money to complete the construction of our team bikes and to help sustain us on our journey. We are also looking for equipment, clothing and food sponsors, places to stay during our trip, and any other ways to help make our trip and its impact legendary (like an electric support vehicle).

Other Ways You Can Help
Help spread the word via Twitter, Facebook, blogs and other media outlets.




More Info About Project M
Project M
New York Times
GOOD
Fast Company
Communication Arts
Metropolis

More Info About Thinking Wrong 
Video interview w/ John Bielenberg

More Info About Common
Common
PSFK
Design Observer
GOOD


Photos in video by Blair & Mark
Music in video: Island, Is by Volcano Choir

story:
The organization responsible for developing a partnership and alliance with Sustainable Energy Corp. who's TCOM technology converts oceanic plastic and debris to usable fuel has announced an official partnership with the founder of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, Captain Charles Moore and his foundation, Algalita Marine Research Institute. The meeting between Tom Hirshberg, founder of COORC and Captain Charles Moore, founder of Algalita Marine Research Institute, marked a productive and progressive step forward in the formation of the COORC strategy to clean up the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.

The Great Pacific Garbage Patch is a massive collection of plastic debris floating within the Pacific Ocean. Estimates of the size of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch range from 270,000 square miles to more than 5,800,000 square miles.

The first campaign COORC is focused on is bringing the awareness to the world. In doing so we will be joining Captain Moore on his July 2014 research voyage to the GPGP. We will film a documentary cultivating Captain Moore's 15 years of research into one report. We are very excited to be able to invite Classrooms from around the world to log in and interact "LIVE" via streaming video. A ship to shore date will be set for classrooms to organize and for students to ask the onboard scientists and marine biologists questions. This voyage will consist of 6 weeks aboard Captain Moore's Research vessel. For more info on this climatic voyage see www.algalita.org

COORC’s new relationship with the Algalita Marine Research Institute will bring legitimacy to the efforts of its team and further inspire the developments of COORC and theTCOM technology Sustainable Energy Corp. has demonstrated. Founder of the Algalita Marine Research Institute, Captain Charles Moore, was the first to bring attention to the immensity of garbage debris floating throughout the Pacific. Captain Moore’s 1999 research showed that there were six times more plastic in this part of the ocean than there were zooplankton that feeds ocean life. These numbers were significantly higher than expected and shocked many marine scientists and oceanographers.

The mutual partnership between Algalita and COORC will bring about more awareness to the dire situation of that which is "The Great Pacific Garbage Patch" and its negative effects on the ocean currents, aquatic marine life as well as human life. This partnership will galvanize community support and further produce additional interest from volunteers, technology experts and research scientists alike.

With the support of the global community and the money raised we will educate the world and irradiate the plastic epidemic posing the the worlds oceans. 

Thank you for your support.

Estimates of the size of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch range from 270,000
square miles to more than 5,800,000 square miles.
The first campaign COORC is focused on is bringing the awareness to the world. In doing so we will be joining Captain Moore on his July 2014 research voyage to the GPGP. We will film a documentary cultivating Captain Moore's 15 years of research into one report. We are very excited to be able to invite Classrooms from around the world to log in and interact "LIVE" via streaming video. A ship to shore date will be set for classrooms to organize and for students to ask the onboard scientists and marine biologists questions. This voyage will consist of 6 weeks aboard Captain Moore's Research vessel. For more info on this climatic voyage see www.algalita.org
COORC’s new relationship with the
Algalita Marine Research Institute will bring legitimacy to the efforts of its
team and further inspire the developments of COORC and theTCOM technology Sustainable Energy Corp. has demonstrated. Founder of the
Algalita Marine Research Institute, Captain Charles Moore, was the first to
bring attention to the immensity of garbage debris floating throughout the
Pacific. Captain Moore’s 1999 research showed that there were six times more
plastic in this part of the ocean than there were zooplankton that feeds ocean
life. These numbers were significantly higher than expected and shocked many
marine scientists and oceanographers.
The mutual partnership between
Algalita and COORC will bring about more awareness to the dire situation of
that which is "The Great Pacific Garbage Patch" and its negative
effects on the ocean currents, aquatic marine life as well as human life. This
partnership will galvanize community support and further produce additional
interest from volunteers, technology experts and research scientists alike.With the support of the global community and the money raised we will educate the world and irradiate the plastic epidemic posing the the worlds oceans. Thank you for your support.

story:
“Earth provides enough to satisfy every man's needs, but not every man's greed.” - Mahatma Gandhi


Who are we?

We change our LOCAL community to build a greater GLOBAL community for tomorrow. We are Greenkeepers. 

Greenkeepers is an environmental, student-run, not-for-profit organization filled with dedicated members with dreams of making the world a better place. We began in Beijing, China and would like YOUR help to support the start of our branch in the United States. The improving of our environment is a global effort. 

Check out our site (US and Indonesia pages coming soon!)


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $1,000. The funds go to:

  • Our annual major project (providing local farmers with water conserving irrigation systems)
  • Minor projects (e.g. unplugged concerts, river cleanings, etc.)
  • Facilities for hosting meetings and events
  • Fundraising materials

Any amount that you donate will be much appreciated. Perks include:
  • Stickers
  • T-bulbs
  • A YouTube video of a dare of your choice (must be legal and environmentally friendly)
  • Pie-ing a core member (local only)
  • Naming a project after you (or a name of your choice)
  • And MORE!


The Impact

In donating, you will be:

  • Supporting the ideas and projects of high school students from around the world
  • Promoting a sense of social and environmental responsibility for current and future generations
  • Helping create a sustainable world of environmental consciousness
  • Making me very happy :)


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread awareness! Tell people who we are and what we're doing.
  • Like our Greenkeepers USA Facebook page
  • Like our Greenkeepers International Facebook page
  • Visit our website
  • Check out our Instagram @greenkeepers_USA
  • Support other environmental groups and student organization around the world
  • And last of all, have a wonderful day!

story:
(Scroll down for English)

Tudatos élet, lemondások nélkül

Ahogy a nagyüzemi állattartás, környezetszennyezés, felelőtlen fogyasztói és energiafelhasználói szokások folyamán a klímaváltozás egyre félelmetesebb méreteket ölt, úgy válik egyre fontosabbá,  hogy tudatos döntéseket hozzunk, és együtt tegyünk meg minden tőlünk telhetőt, hogy megóvjuk környezetünket és egészséges bolygót hagyjunk itt az utánunk következő generációknak.

Szerencsére egyre több felelősségteljes, innovatív, zöld életmódot elősegítő vállalkozás van jelen már Budapesten is, így egyre könnyebb olyan környezettudatos életvitelt folytatni, ami nem a megvonásokról és áldozathozatalról szól, hanem örömöt csempész az életünkbe.

Gyűjtésünkkel segíteni kívánjuk a Budapesten élőket és ide látogatókat ezeknek a helyeknek a bemutatásával, hogy a helyi, tudatos vállalkozásokat, pozitív kezdeményezéseket támogassuk, hiszen a pénztárcákkal szavazunk arról, milyen világban szeretnénk élni.

Bemutatkozás

Mimma, Dávid és Niki vagyunk. A tervezőgrafikus Mimma és műszaki-környezeti szakmérnök Dávid közös vállalkozása a növénydekorációval és környezetbarát grafikai termékekkel foglalkozó RisoPlant, Niki pedig a vegán, fenntartható utazásról blogol Fly Unbound néven.

Mindhárman elkötelezettek vagyunk a fenntarthatóság és környezettudatosság iránt, és igyekszünk folyamatosan tanulni, fejlődni a témában. Imádunk utazni, új helyeket felfedezni, de a túlzsúfolt látványosságok helyett sokkal jobban szeretünk lelassulni, és parkokban, botanikus kertekben időzni, helyi finomságokat kóstolni a piacon, vagy éppen kávét szürcsölni, és amennyire csak tudunk, (környezet)tudatosan fogyasztani, étkezni, létezni. 

Budapest zöld térképe

Saját példánkból kiindulva született meg az ötlet, hogy egy ingyenesen elérhető, kézzel fogható információs, tájékoztató anyagot hozzunk létre, ami segítheti a budapestieket és az ide látogatókat, hogy tudatosabb és fenntarthatóbb módon fogyasszanak, pihenjenek, közlekedjenek és vásároljanak. Olyan kétnyelvű térképet készítünk, ami több zöld témakört egyesít és ajánl: olyan helyeket, illetve programokat, amelyek a fenntarthatóságot, az egészséges életvitelt és a hulladékok minimalizálását tartják szem előtt.

Ezeket a következő kategóriákra bonthatjuk:

  • Kikapcsolódás: parkok, botanikus kertek, zöldövezetek
  • Vásárlás: piacok, bioboltok, ökotudatos ajándékboltok és concept store-ok, csomagolásmentes boltok és a hulladékmentes életmódot segítő eszközöket áruló helyek   
  • Étkezés: vegán vagy vegánbarát kínálattal rendelkező étkezdék és kávézók, melyek fenntartható megoldásokat alkalmaznak (pl. lebomló/komposztálható csomagolás, helyi termelőktől való beszerzés, biciklis szállítás
  • Közösség: család-, kutya- és biciklibarát helyek, valamint a környezettudatos életmódot népszerűsítő közösségi terek és rendezvények
  • Hasznos információk: szelektív gyűjtőpontok, teherbicikli kölcsönző pontok

A térkép ugyanazzal a tartalommal két verzióban, magyar és angol nyelven is meg fog jelenni.

A térkép felépítése

A térkép egy A3 méretű újrahasznosított lap két oldalára lesz két színnel nyomva, a már említett rizográf technikával. Az egyik oldala egy stilizált, egyedi tervezésű Budapest-térkép lesz kis illusztrációkkal és az ajánlott helyeket jelölő pöttyökkel, a másik oldalára pedig az információk kerülnek: a helyek listája és azok leírása.

Miért offline?

Jogosan merülhet fel a kérdés, hogy miért nem digitális verzióban, applikációban gondolkozunk. Mivel a RisoPlant egyik fő tevékenysége a környezetbarát rizográf nyomatok, ezen keresztül merült fel a térkép ötlete is. Egyáltalán nem zárjuk ki a lehetőségét annak, hogy a jövőben a térkép applikációként is megjelenjen, de jelenleg nem ez az elsődleges cél.

Hisszük, hogy nem egy farzsebbe gyűrt paprífecni - és ezáltal papírhulladék -  lesz a térképből, hanem akár a hazatérő utazók lakásának dekorációja, hiszen a térkép az egyedi designnak köszönhetően esztétikai értéket is fog képviselni.

Ezentúl úgy érezzük, most, a digitalizáltság csúcsán, egyre nagyobb népszerűségnek örvendenek a különböző nosztalgikus, kézzel fogható, analóg megoldások, mint például a polaroid képek. Egy papír alapú térkép a méltán népszerű slow life mozgalomba is illik: sokkal hangulatosabb egy szép illusztrációt bogarászni, mint a telefonunkat nyomkodni.

Mire használjuk az adományokat? 

Mivel a térképet ingyenesen elérhetővé szeretnék, tenni, annak megvalósításához közösségi segítséget kérünk, illetve néhány, a térképre kiválasztott vállalkozástól támogatást kapunk. A térképek előállításának költségét nettó 1.200.000 és 1.500.000 Ft (4200-5200 USD) közé becsüljük.

Ez az összeg a következőket tartalmazza:

  • Gyártási költségek: 5000 db térképhez (és a tesztnyomatokhoz) szükséges papír és festék, a RISO nyomtató üzemeltetése
  • Hármunk több száz órányi befektetett munkája: kutatás, kommunikáció, ötletelés, szövegezés, grafikai tervezés, nyomtatás, hajtogatás, terjesztés, online marketing, bemutató szervezése, adminisztráció

Hogyan tudsz még segíteni?

Még a legapróbbnak tűnő adomány is számít, de ha jelenleg nem tudod pénzzel támogatni projektünket, ám tetszik a kezdeményezés, megköszönjük, ha megosztod ezt a kampányt az ismerőseiddel.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Our Mission

As the destructive meat industry, pollution, consumerism and irresponsible use of Earth's resources make climate change a grave issue, it is more important than ever to make conscious decisions and try the best we can to protect our environment and leave a healthy planet behind for future generations.

Luckily, responsible, innovative businesses aiding a greener lifestyle now abound in Budapest as well, so it's becoming increasingly easier to lead an eco-friendly lifestyle that requires little to no compromise or sacrifice, yet brings plenty of joy.

Green Guide Budapest, a subjective, curated list of Budapest-based places aims to introduce these places to locals and visitors, so that they can support local, conscious businesses and positive initiatives - after all, we vote with our wallets about the world we want to live in.

Introduction

We're Mimma, David, and Niki, three creatives passionate about both travel and the environment. Graphic designer Mimma and technical-environmental engineer David run RisoPlant together, a creavite business specialising in potted and printed goods: succulents and custom-designed risograph products. Niki blogs about vegan, sustainable travel and lifestyle under the name Fly Unbound.

All three of us are committed to living as environmentally consciously as possible, while constantly learning and developing in this field. We love exploring new places, but rather than visiting crowded sights, we prefer to slow down and relax in parks or botanical gardens, savour local delights at the market, or sip coffee in a hidden café, and as much as possible, shop, eat and live consciously.

Green Guide Budapest

To help and inspire like-minded people, we've decided to create a freely available, printed informational publication that can aid Budapest locals and visitors to eat, relax, travel and shop in a more conscious and sustainable way. We're creating a bilingual map that unites various green topics: venues and events that prioritise sustainability, a healthy lifestyle and waste reduction.

These can include the following:

  • Leisure: parks, botanical gardens, green zones
  • Shopping: markets, bio organic shops, eco-conscious gift shops and concept stores, zero waste shops  
  • Dining: vegan and vegan-friendly opting for sustainable solutions (e.g. biodegradable/compostable packaging, sourcing from local farmers, cargo bike deliveries) 
  • Community: family, dog, and bike-friendly places, as well as community spaces and events organised with an eco-conscious mindset
  • Practical information: recycling points, cargo bike rental locations 

The map will be available both in English and Hungarian.

About the Map

The map will be printed on both sides of a recycled A3 size paper in two colours, with RisoPlant's risograph printing technique. One side will be a stylized, illustrated map of Budapest with dots marking points of interest, while the other side will be filled with information, brief descriptions and tips about the chosen venues and the city.

Why Offline?

Why aren't we working on a digital version or application? As one of RisoPlant's main craft is the eco-friendly risograph printing, the concept of the map was originally formed through this as well. We're very open to the possibility of taking this project one step further and developing an app, but for now, our focus is on the physical, paper-based map.

We strongly believe these maps won't end up as a crumpled pieces of paper in the bottom of your bag - and therefore, paper waste - but that they may even end up as decoration on travellers' walls due to the custom design and aesthetic value to it.

Besides, now, living in such a heavily digitalized age, various nostalgic, physical, analogue solutions  - such as polaroids - are becoming increasingly popular. A paper-based map is a great addition to those enjoying the slow life movement: reading a physical map feels a lot more interesting than scrolling on your phone.

Where Your Donation Goes

We estimate the production costs of the 5000 limited edition maps to be between $4200 and $5200.

This amount includes the following:

  • Production costs: paper and ink needed for 5000 maps and test runs, as well as operating the RISO machine
  • Hundreds of hours of work invested by the three of us: research, communication, brainstorming, planning, writing, graphic design, printing, folding, distributing, online marketing, organising the launch event, administration 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little helps - but if you can't currently support us financially, it is also a great help if you share this campaign with your friends.

Supported by:

Production costs: paper and ink needed for 5000 maps and test runs, as well as operating the RISO machine

Hundreds of hours of work invested by the three of us: research, communication, brainstorming, planning, writing, graphic design, printing, folding, distributing, online marketing, organising the launch event, administration 
Other Ways You Can HelpEvery little helps - but if you can't currently support us financially, it is also a great help if you share this campaign with your friends.Supported by:

story:
Short Summary

Our transportation network is one of our most important resources, allowing us to access basic needs such as food, housing and employment. Yet we contribute a lot of time and money to a system that has been poorly designed and does not work well for anyone.Awareness is rapidly growing that a society dominated by cars is expensive, dangerous and unsustainable, and that we must take action to move in a new direction. We must now develop the political will to admit our mistakes and change course, making sure our actions and policies match the need to build safe, effective, interconnected, sustainable transport networks.

I am touring cities and towns across the US and Canada -- exclusively by bicycle or public transit -- to raise awareness of the role that sustainable transportation can and does play in supporting vibrant, livable communities. By understanding what is (and is not) working in other places we can address the challenges and opportunities to improving access and mobility anywhere. This information will help all of us be better planners, operators, advocates and activists -- ultimately improving the lives of countless others by working toward a shared vision of a safe, convenient, affordable transportation network that works for everyone.

I encourage you to participate in this project by sharing your experiences in the comments section, on Facebook or Twitter, or contact me, so that we can all learn from each other for the benefit of everyone.

Follow the tour on my blog and weekly podcast -- www.criticaltransit.com -- and please share your questions and suggestions.

 

What You're Supporting

This campaign is projected to fund 6-9 months of the project, depending on an estimated $30 per day for housing, food and transportation. Any additional funds of free housing (greatly appreciated!) will extend the tour on the same budget. [In the event that the goal is not reached I will use the money for as much of a tour as can be funded.]

By supporting this tour and my reporting, you are helping to improve the lives of many thousands of people by advocating for safe, convenient, affordable transportation and limiting exposure to the harmful effects of car use as more people shift to other modes. That benefits everyone.

 

What You Receive

Supporters can choose one of several exciting perks such as transit maps/schedules, access to my photo gallery, bonus podcast material, a bike/transit ride, bicycling advice or even guest hosting the Critical Transit podcast.  Feel free to suggest others.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this page with all your friends, colleagues and anyone else who likes safe, convenient, affordable and sustainable transportation.

Share the blog and podcast, leave an iTunes review, or do something else to help my work reach more people.

Connect me with anyone who can share something important for this project.

Provide an inexpensive place to stay for anywhere from a day to a week, or connect me with someone you know who might have some space.
 
Help with some of the technical aspects of the project such as web site maintenance, podcast editing, etc. 
 

Thank you so much for your support which makes my reporting possible!

story:
Hi, I'm Laura Bailey, owner of Royal Wind. I, along with my husband John, have created a revolutionary new wind power generator that will make renewable energy affordable for more people than ever before.
 
Several years ago, while living in the Blue Ridge Mountains, we became aware of the environmental destruction being inflicted upon the people and the land in the coal mining areas by the coal industry: contaminated water, children endangered by slurry ponds, mountain top removal, etc. We discussed the need for a clean source of power, one that would produce enough power to make it attractive to individuals and businesses beyond the environmentally-conscious community. We created the Royal Wind.
The benefits of the Royal Wind include:
~ low capital cost
~short payback time
~high output
~reduced drag
~quiet operation and low visual impact
~storm-ready
~operates in a wide range of wind conditions, including coastal and high-wind mountain areas
~made of low-cost materials (when in full production a large percentage of materials will be recycled styrofoam)
~made in USA
 
Our dream is to provide low cost, high output wind turbines to homeowners and businesses worldwide. With our turbine, many families will be able to provide for their economic futures by purchasing a Royal Wind 3.2 and selling excess electricity into the grid for decades to come. With this Indiegogo project we are seeking funding to build the forms (for which you can see the plugs in the video) for our 3.2 kW model, as well as to build and install a full-scale prototype. From this prototype installation we will be able to collect wind speed and weather condition specific data which is the first step toward getting the Royal Wind 3.2 certified as eligible for renewable energy tax credits and rebates.
 
We are offering preorders of the Royal Wind 3.2, $150-$3500 coupons toward the future purchase of a Royal Wind 3.2, as well as conversation-starting t-shirts, magnets and certificates of appreciation featuring the digital image you see at the top of this page. Supporters from the $250 level and up will be listed on the supporter page of our website.
 
We anticipate monthly output between 800-1000 kilowatt hours in average wind conditions, which is 2-3 times more than other small wind turbines of similar capacity. This make the Royal Wind an economically wise choice for business, industry, and residential use, even for those not concerned with their carbon footprint. For distributed generation scale wind power to make a significant positive environmental impact , it has to be attractive to a wider spectrum of customers. With longevity and warranty long exceeding payback time, the ability to operate in a wide range of wind conditions (which means more hours of production per day) and a storm-ready design, the Royal Wind is a renewable energy option that makes sense. The average payback time for many small-scale renewable energy sources is 20 years, before which many systems wear out. We expect our customers to have a pay back period of 3-7 years without rebates, and even shorter with rebates.
Please visit the climate change page of our website
http://royalwindturbines.com/index.php?p=1_6_Climate-Change
to read about our plan to use our turbines to remediate climate change, restore health and vibrancy to our oceans, and to create cold water barriers to hurricanes along our Gulf and Atlantic coasts.
 
We have devoted several years to perfecting the design of the Royal Wind and believe that the Royal Wind is the future of wind power. You can help to bring the Royal Wind into production. Please donate what you can and share this project with your friends via FB and Twitter using the buttons below. Every share helps to keep us visible and gets us closer to our goal. Thank you.
 
*Donations can be made by direct credit or debit card payment or through Paypal. Paypal is our preferred method of payment (but we're happy to recieve donations either way!) and can be used by people without a Paypal account in amounts up to $500. Preorders of a Royal Wind 3.2 should be paid for by direct credit or debit card rather than with Paypal.

story:
On the brink

The western quoll once roamed over 70% of the Australian mainland, but was extinct except for in a small pocket in south-western Western Australia.  

But in April 2014, 42 western quolls were released in the Flinders Ranges, in South Australia, where they had been missing for 130 years, as part of a groundbreaking re-introduction program. 

The western quoll has been thrown a lifeline, but it's not out of danger yet. It needs help to survive. 

In the last century, dozens of unique Australian mammals have been made extinct, and many others are perched precariously on the brink. But for the western quoll, we have this unique chance to save it, and undo some of the damage of the past. 

Western quoll about to be released. Photo courtesy of Ecological Horizons.


The western quoll is being hunted

This precious colony needs to stay alive long enough for them to breed and multiply. But the large release area is unfenced, and feral foxes and cats are hunting the quolls. 

It is estimated that there are 15 million feral cats across Australia, each killing an average of five native animals a night. The quoll reintroduction team is battling to keep our quolls safe from these ferocious predators.


Why is this project important?

This is not just about the western quoll. Making the release area safe for the quoll will mean that it will be safe for many other native species, as well. 

Up until now, the concentration of the western quoll population in just one pocket of Australia made them vulnerable. Spreading the quoll population around is an important insurance policy for the survival of the species as a whole.


This is where we need your help

All money raised from this campaign will go directly towards maintaining a safe environment (feral predator control of goats, rabbits, foxes and cats); and towards funding equipment, vet care and research to support the survival and breeding success of reintroduced quolls. 

Young male western quoll with tracking collar in soft-release pen.
Photograph courtesy of Ecological Horizons


Who is running this project?

This release is a culmination of 7 years of research and work, and is being run by FAME, the Foundation for Australia's Most Endangered Species, a non-profit organisation. www.fame.org.au

The project plan is supported by the Western Australian Department of Parks and Wildlife (DPaW) which has been protecting Australia’s last remaining Western quolls for 17 years. DPaW are providing the animals for translocation. The South Australian Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources (DEWNR) is providing support for feral control via Operation Bounceback.

Female western quoll with babies. Photo courtesy of Western Australian Department of Parks and Wildlife 


What is special about this project?

In Australia, re-introduction of locally extinct native species is rare. Most often, species are protected where they still remain. Many dozens of native Australian species have been extinguished over the last 200 years, and most projects aim to halt that decline. The Western quoll re-introduction program is different in that it is putting an important species back where it once lived. 


About the western quoll

The western quoll, roughly the size of a small domestic cat, is central Australia’s largest remaining native carnivore. As a predator at the top of the food chain, the western quoll helps safeguard the health of the whole ecosystem. 

The decline of the western quoll has been the result of many factors including: habitat alteration, land clearing, bushfires, and disease. Other dangers are predation by, and competition for food with, foxes and feral cats; being hit by motor vehicles; illegal shooting, poisoning and trapping; accidental drowning in water tanks; and entanglement in barbed wire fencing.


Map of South Australia, showing records of where fossil remains were found, as well as potential western quoll release sites.

story:
Join me in supporting park rangers in Mongolia!

Robert McIntosh, or Mac, is co-founder of the Lake Hovsgol Conservancy.  He has been working in Lake Hovsgol National Park since the summer of 2011. Inspired by the rangers in the park, Mac was determined to find ways to help them. After seeing the chief ranger’s decrepit motorcycle break down while chasing a law-breaker, he said to his friends “I am going to buy a bike, ride it all the way to the lake, and give it to this ranger. Are you in?” That’s how the idea of our Blue Waves Motorcycle Rally got off the ground.

This Motorcycle Rally will not only raise funds for park rangers; it will also provide them with new motorcycles and a variety of outdoor gear they need protect this pristine park. International riders will ride 1500 miles to deliver the motorcycles + gear to 15 different park rangers in July, 2014.

Here's what I need...

I am a late entry to this project, the other riders have been raising funds since last year. Each of us is expected to raise at least $7,000 including the cost of our transportation. I have already raised the $2,300 I need to cover my travel (my family is awesome!), so your contributions will go directly to the rally providing gear and motorcycles to these rangers in need. YOUR DONATION IS TAX DEDUCTABLE!

Imagine...

...Lake Hovsgol, northern Mongolia... rangers watching a fleet of motorcycles ride up to them and hand them the keys and the gear for them to do their jobs more successfully and effectively. Please help them better protect the amazing resources of this incredible park.

Share this project with whomever you can so we can provide as much support to these dedicated rangers as possible. Thanks for taking part in the preservation of this special place half way round the world.

story:
I'm Paul Sharp from Two Hands Project. We inspire people from around the world to remove plastic from their environment.
We are joining the world leaders in marine plastic pollution, studying debris from the Japanese tsunami!
This is important as it will help us understand how plastic impacts the ocean and help us convince plastic makers and governments to stop plastic pollution at the source :)
 
Contribute to support this incredible expedition!
 

Have you heard about the debris from the Japanese Tsunami heading across the Pacific towards the USA?

Or the Great Pacific Garbage Patch? ..A swirling vortex of currents contaminated with plastic pollution!

It's remarkable stuff, and more than a little concerning when you start to explore the problems that plastic can cause, both in the ocean environment and closer to home.

Well, it's stories like these that drive me, I'm passionate about ending plastic pollution in our oceans!

So understandably I was over the moon upon recieving an invite from Jeanne at Algalita Marine Research Foundation to join their joint 2012 Tsunami Debris Field expedition with 5 Gyres!!

How awesome is that?!! Surveying the Pacific Ocean with AMRF and 5 Gyres, the two leading scientific organisations on the issue of plastic pollution and a volunter crew of like minded changemakers, artists and scientists from around the world.. One word.. Brilliant!

This pioneering research doesn't come cheap, so I need your contribution for my place on the expedition vessel Sea Dragon! To show my appreciation I have a boatload of perks to reward you with..(if you want to donate an amount but don't NEED the perk let us know! We don't want to send you stuff you don't need;) Check them out to the right ----> 

         
Any contribution you make will support the 2012 Tsunami Debris Field expedition, give myself and Two Hands Project the opportunity to learn more about plastic pollution, build relationships with our peers from around the globe and become more effective at fighting plastic pollution!

(update!) I am committed to this issue ..so much so I have borrowed the funds for the expedition, I still need your contribution though, if I can cover this voyage I'll be free on my return to get on with telling the story of what we learn in the Pacific.

This is a once in a lifetime voyage to study the Tsunami debri field, a unique opportunity that will give us a greater understanding of what happens to a diverse range of plastics from a known source during it's first year at sea.. This information is invaluable to building data to compell lawmakers and industry to change the way we design and use plastic to end plastic pollution.

You can also help by spreading the word! Tell people about what we're up to and invite them to check out this crowdfunding page (You can use the IndieGoGo share tools)

I'd also love it if you would pick up some plastic pollution, take a photo and share it on Two Hands Project :) Seeing a photo of you picking plastic will make my day!

You can find us on the Facebook, YouTube, Twitter and our website using the buttons below..

Thanks to Leighton for editing the video!

Thankyou for your help,
Paul Sharp
Two Hands Project

story:
Bees fly for our life! We fly for our bees!

Important update: First flight and lesson on the 7th of November! Stay tuned!

We did it!!! Airborne! Details to follow soon! Thanks to you, the dream became true!


Progress:

We thank our first donators! And we feel grateful to the bee-companies which support our campaign:

-Vita (Europe) Ltd! Though their huge donation of 3000 euro does not appear at the campaign (due to PayPal problems) the money has been sent!

-ANEL Standard! The first huge contribution came from ANEL, Greece!

-Swienty! Donation from Denmark!

-Civan! Huge donation! Huge thank you!

THANK YOU!

The mission of our airclub "Pigasos of Chalkidiki" is to support the maintainance of honeybees and to educate people, especially young kids, about the importance of honeybees in our life. This will be obtained through a novel , inspiring idea, the "air bee-school".

Our Airclub is located at the beautiful peninsula of Chalkidiki in Greece. One of our pilots, Dr. Alexandros Papachristoforou, owning a PhD on apiculture, intends to fly from Chalkidiki to numerous places around Greece, covering a total of 2000 miles on air, carrying an observation hive of 2000 bees next to him! At each stop he will be giving lectures at primary schools about honeybees. And he will offer short flights to students and teachers. Just imagine how impressive this experience will be for kids: watch the teacher arriving with the bees from the sky! An experience they will never forget.

           

                   


At every school we visit we will also carry honey for kids to taste and we will leave at their libraries two lovely bee-tale books (one in Greek and one in English):

                      

                                    "Melifteri the honeybee" by Dr. Fani Hatjina and
                                         "The honeybee castle" by Dr. Asli Ozkirim


The aircraft we fly with is an ICP Savannah MXP 70. In order to make this dream come true, except from fuels (plenty of fuel!) we need service expenses, a new ballistic parachute, money for accommodation, internet facilities and much more... In simple words, we need your contribution! 

To contribute, please, select a Perk from the list on the right and make us happy by pressing the Contribute Now button.

What We Need & What You Get

The money we raise from your contribution will go on fuel, airplane's fuselage reinforcement, ballistic parachute, internet support during flight, accommodation, teaching materials and any other expenses might occur during flights. If by chance we get more money than we hope, we might use it to rent an aircraft in better condition or even buy a newer, used aircraft. If we make it, the project will continue in 2014 and 2015 and we will expand it to nearby countries.

As a reward for your support, we have a list of tempting perks such as jars of our own honey, amazing short or long-lasting flights and unforgettable visits to nearby islands! Though ultralight pilots can carry only one person as co-pilot, if you want to share this unique experience with a friend, we can operate parallel flights with two aircrafts. All you have to do is to visit us in beautiful Chalkidiki. Combine perfect flight and vacation! For you convenience, all flights are valid anytime you can until December 2015!

Note that we have the right to refuse contributions. So, companies producing products that are harmful to honeybees or to the environment are not exactly welcome (to say the least) at this campaign.

If we don't make it with crowed funding... oh, well, we'll do it anyway. With any money we have raised. At least for one trip, one place, one school and for limited miles. Not so good but so we hope for the entire project!

The Impact

We must thank honeybees for 1 in every 3 mouthfuls we eat! Bees are responsible for the pollination of numerous crops, for the maintenance of the biodiversity and for the environmental equilibrium of our planet. But their population is in decline. Bees are dying off or disappearing thanks to a still-unsolved malady called Colony Collapse disorder (CCD).

Any action designed to inform people about the importance of bees and attract the interest of public and press, is important for the recruitment of "bee-supporters". We intent to do both: Inform (mainly) kids and attract the interest of press about the project. Since our Dr. pilot, who is also the Vice-President of the European Professional Beekeepers Association, has published important scientific papers which have been reported by major mass media (including BBC, National Geographic, Le Monde, Telegraph, LA Times, Der Spiegel,  etc) this flight project is expected to receive great publicity. Be part of it!

Read more for bees and bee projects:

http://bees-decline.org/

http://www.foe.co.uk/what_we_do/bee_cause_david_cameron_petition_39395.html

http://www.savehoneybees.org/

http://www.vanishingbees.com/

http://www.helpsavebees.co.uk/to_do_list.html

http://ecowatch.com/2013/obama-save-the-bees

http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2149141,00.html#ixzz2cu9LJQd1

Visit also the exciting Honeybee Online Studies project (HOBOS) and learn a lot about honeybees!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, we fully understand. Positive energy and warm thoughts are very welcome! There are also other ways to help:

-Pass on our link

-Get informed and support honeybees any way you can

-Use the Indiegogo share tools for this project
story_txt:
Bees fly for our life! We fly for our bees!Important update: First flight and lesson on the 7th of November! Stay tuned!
We did it!!! Airborne! Details to follow soon! Thanks to you, the dream became true!


Progress:
We thank our first donators! And we feel grateful to the bee-companies which support our campaign:
-Vita (Europe) Ltd! Though their huge donation of 3000 euro does not appear at the campaign (due to PayPal problems) the money has been sent!
-ANEL Standard! The first huge contribution came from ANEL, Greece!
-Swienty! Donation from Denmark!
-Civan! Huge donation! Huge thank you!
THANK YOU!

The mission of our airclub "Pigasos of Chalkidiki" is to support the maintainance of honeybees and to educate people, especially young kids, about the importance of honeybees in our life. This will be obtained through a novel , inspiring idea, the "air bee-school".Our Airclub is located at the beautiful peninsula of Chalkidiki in Greece. One of our pilots, Dr. Alexandros Papachristoforou, owning a PhD on apiculture, intends to fly from Chalkidiki to numerous places around Greece, covering a total of 2000 miles on air, carrying an observation hive of 2000 bees next to him! At each stop he will be giving lectures at primary schools about honeybees. And he will offer short flights to students and teachers. Just imagine how impressive this experience will be for kids: watch the teacher arriving with the bees from the sky! An experience they will never forget.
            
                    

At every school we visit we will also carry honey for kids to taste and we will leave at their libraries two lovely bee-tale books (one in Greek and one in English):
                                                           "Melifteri the honeybee" by Dr. Fani Hatjina and                                         "The honeybee castle" by Dr. Asli Ozkirim

story:
CHANGE IS HAPPENING! START WHERE YOU ARE

Have you ever thought about cashing it all in and getting out of the rat race?!

Well, we decided to do it! On April 28, 2013, we leave everything in LA to begin a year-long expedition, by RV, across the USA visiting low-impact organic farms and eco-villages to learn best practices in sustainable farming, construction, energy, water and waste management. We will be visiting and working on low-impact organic farms and eco-villages, educating and preparing ourselves for establishing a sustainable, low-impact, eco-retreat and training center of our own. Good Foot Project is our personal revolution – our immersive masters class in sustainability.  And we want to share it with everyone.

We recently launched www.goodfootproject.com to document our journey, discoveries and even our mistakes. By sharing our experiences, we hope to empower people to make their own lives more sustainable. No change is too small. Everyone can start where they are! Can you help us?

We are raising money to purchase solar panels for the RV and to secure video equipment to help us make and share educational videos. Even though we have a lot on our plate with all of the changes and apprenticeship, we are committed to sharing what we learn on the road. The total cost for these items is $9,800 and every little bit makes a difference.

Here's how you can help:  First, spread the word about www.goodfootproject.com. Second, support our campaign by selecting 1 or 2 awesome perks from the list on the right!

AWESOME PERKS!

"Perks" are our way of giving back to our supporters. We are offering seed collections, postcards, oil paintings, photographs, prints, and greeting cards in exchange for your support!

In many ways, we have built our lives on the labors we love - now we are learning to do so in a more sustainable way.  We'd like to share some of our labors with you, our new community of supporters. Some of the perks we are offering include:

    FOOD - Selections of organic and heirloom seeds for your home garden or window boxes. We will also be sending a weekly recipe series via email to every single supporter no matter the size of your contribution! 

    MUSIC  - We are throwing an action-packed launch party on March 9th in Los Angeles.  We're bringing together some of our favorite muscial artists for some amazing live performances. Jazz, Hip-Hop and House. We hope you can join us! More details on the Updates tab above and see the invite here: On the Good Foot party invite.)

     COMMUNITY - Various opportunities to share your passions with our growing community. 

    ART - Oil paintings and photographs by JC Jaress who has had more than 70 solo and group shows nationwide. The peices on offer are drawn from several periods and range in size from 11x14" to 36x70". The work covers a broad range: Pop Surrealism, abstract photography, wry social commentary and a series of portraits of Jazz giants. 

31x15" Photographs, ink on Sintra and Lexan

Jazz Series: Joe Williams, oil on canvas, 36x56"

While We Weren't Watching, oil on canvas, 36x56"

See more images of the artwork on offer. Click the Gallery tab above. 

 

Good Foot Impact

When we tell people of our plans, most of them smile with bewilderment and a little envy and wish us well. We explain that more and more people are making similar decisions: People are turning to small-scale farming and craft businesses as a way of making a living. Intentional communities are growing every day, in every nation.  People across the planet are becoming more and more dissatisfied with the way their governments and institutions and societies operate.

That is why we decided to document our journey on our blog with photos, video and words - to show that change CAN happen. Change IS happening.

With your contribution, you can help inspire millions of people across the US and around the world to make smart changes - for themselves and the planet - RIGHT NOW.   

 

Beyond the Dollars

There are so many ways that you can help without contributing a single dollar! Here are a few:

- Help us get the word out! The value of our project is measured by the strength of the Good Foot Project community. Talk to your friends and family about Good Foot Project.

  1. Subscribe to our mailing list:www.goodfootproject.com
  2. Join our Facebook community:  https://www.facebook.com/GoodFootProject       
  3. Join the conversation on Twtitter:  @GoodFootP

- Suggest places for us to visit on our travels. Send info on your favorite farms, family and friends - it's always good to find a friendly face on road. Very soon we will post a map of our route on the website so you can follow along!

- Share your own tips, advice and knowledge.  The comment pages on the website are open to all and we are launching a Resources page shortly.

More About GFP and Our Big Adventure...

JC Jaress

JC Jaress is an artist. He paints, photographs and writes about things left unspoken or unnoticed, which, to him, are often more interesting than the things we talk about. He currently does this in Altadena, California, usually in the middle of the night in the company of his dog, Mattie, who does not speak much at all. Jaress once wrote an article in 45 minutes about the speed of life which was published a few days later in the Los Angeles Journal. His paintings and photographs have shown in over 70 exhibitions internationally and have made appearances on wine labels, book and CD covers, magazine illustrations. An active member of the arts community, Jaress served on the Board of Directors of the Los Angeles Art Association and as President and Chairman of the organization. Jaress readily admits to loving chocolate cake.

Anastasia King Jaress

Anastasia King Jaress is an award-winning media filmmaker and entrepreneur with hundreds of credits spanning the gamut of media platforms – from film and television, to interactive and live/ experiential. Her credits include work for Google, Ford, Chevrolet, Heineken, Red Bull, Amon Tobin, Drake, Alicia Keys, American Idol and the Marquee Nightclub in Las Vegas. In 2006, her first documentary, American Blackout – www.americanblackout.com, won the Sundance Film Festival Special Jury Prize among other film festival honors. The film is a controversial investigation into systematic voter disenfranchisement and the silencing of political dissent in America and has been used by dozens of political activists and civil right organizations to promote civic engagement.

Our Big Adventure

We grew up believing that if we work hard, follow the rules and play nicely with others, we will realize the American Dream – a nice house, good job, two cars and 40+ years of beachside vacations followed by an enjoyable and relaxing retirement. By most accounts, we’re more than halfway there. We own a beautiful home with a pool on a huge lot in the foothills of Los Angeles. We earn good incomes and set our own hours working mostly from home. Our free time is full of friends and family, great food, movies, music, trips, barbecues and parties. 

We are also acutely aware that this Dream is not sustainable. Mortgage payments higher than the national median income, IRA accounts decimated by Wall Street melt-downs and food, energy and medical expenses on the rise. Each and every time we do the math the answer is the same - we will never be able to retire. In fact, we will have to work more, not less, the older we get. This fiscal reality, combined with our growing awareness of how our management of food, energy, water and waste are adversely affecting the planet, make it harder and harder to justify our lifestyle. We tell ourselves, "We do our part". Yes, we repair, reuse and recycle, we compost, we shop at the farmers market and we buy organic when we have a choice - but we know this is not enough.

So, rather than turning up the volume, putting our heads down, working harder and watching the months and years fly past in a soul-dulling blur, we decided to make a change.  A radical change.

What we decided to do 

We started thinking about how to address these challenges.  We chose to resist the gravity of familiar or comfortable choices. We challenged ourselves to let go of our pre-conceived notions of how things should be and we allowed for new possibilities about how things might be. We asked ourselves: What do we value? What do we enjoy? What is meaningful to us? How do we want to spend our days? The next five years? 20 years? The rest of our lives?

We aimed to create a way of life in sync with our values and driven by the labors we love. Plus, our answers had to be a part of a sustainable solution; economically, socially and environmentally. And it was far easier than we had imagined!

Our new life would be founded in fairness, compassion, and generosity. We love to spend our time cooking, entertaining, investing in personal growth, gardening and enjoying music, art, and community. With that in mind, we decided to build a community around a low-impact farm and retreat center – a sustainable eco-village where people will live and learn and contribute. A place to grow nourishing foods and focus on creativity, art, yoga, meditation and all of the things that make us wonderfully human.

How we’re going about it

 We are both the type to build it without reading the instructions first, but we recognize we will need hands-on practical skills in organic farming, sustainable building, water and waste management practices and community building. JC researched a wealth of information on intentional communities, many of which seemed to have achieved what we dream of.  He also discovered WWOOF, Worldwide Opportunities on Organic Farms, an organization that helps organic farms across the globe connect with individual "woofers" offering their labor in exchange for training, room and board. With that, we put a plan in motion - April 2013 to April 2014 we will be living and learning at WWOOF farms, eco-villages and intentional communities across the USA. In 2014 we plan to spend a few months in Europe and several more in Central and South America before we settle down to the business of finding our own land.

We won't be marching in the streets or rising up in armed rebellion to overthrow any governments or regimes. We have simply done the math and choose to create a sustainable, more meaningful life for ourselves.  It is a personal revolution . . . but that's how they all start.

story:
Mission

Project Green Ball is a non-profit sustainability initiative to coordinate innovative recycling programs for used tennis balls and to donate surfaces based on the recycled balls to organizations servicing people with disabilities or life threatening diseases.


Check out our segment on Channel 5 News!

Summary:

Project Green Ball's goal is to remove tennis balls from the waste stream and provide social benefit to people in need.  We do this by collecting tennis balls from clubs, tournaments, schools, teams, associations, and individuals.  Once the balls are collected we send them to an equestrian turf manufacturer. Together, IGK Equestrian and Project Green Ball have developed an equestrian turf based on ground tennis balls.  Once we deliver 200,000 balls, the manufacturer will donate an equestrian turf to a therapeutic riding program for people with disabilities.  Our goal is to donate as many balls as possible to the manufacturer, resulting in the donation of many equestrian turfs to therapeutic riding centers. 

Accomplishments:

  • PGB has collected over 145,000 balls to date. 
  • PGB is the largest recycler of tennis balls in the United States
  • PGB facilitated the donation of an equestrian turf through a UPS grant to EquiCenter. 
  • Wilson Sporting Goods has gotten behind PGB and supported the shipment of nearly 40,000 balls.  
  • PGB currently has 62 organizations nation wide which have donated tennis balls and hosted 20 collection bins.
  • PGB has 8 volunteers and 4 ambassadors.
  • PGB has won 4 grants totaling in $3,500 and 2 awards, including a MassRecycle Innovation Award.
  • PGB has filed for 501(c)(3) status.

Impact:

300 million tennis balls are manufactured worldwide each year (with over 125 million used in the US) and tons of balls are discarded into landfills each year. The balls decompose very slowly and take up space in landfills, producing methane gas and contributing to global warming.  Everyone is aware of reuse applications for tennis balls—bottoms of chairs and walkers and as toys for dogs.  But there is a limit to how many balls each year can be put to this purpose.  And, even if reused, ultimately these balls still remain in the waste stream and wind up in landfills.  

There was no solution to recycling tennis balls until now. Project Green Ball removes tennis balls from the waste stream by incorporating them into ball-based turfs.

FAQs:

Please visit our FAQ page on our website: Project Green Ball FAQ.

What your donation is going to:

The more funds we raise, the more balls we will receive.  All funds raised through this project will be used to support the shipment of tennis balls. Currently, shipping is inhibiting our success.  We constantly have people calling us from all over the world asking how they can ship their balls and whether we will be able to pay for shipping.  Shipping can be very expensive, and often times we lose donations because the donors do not have funds to ship the balls.

We are aiming for $500.  If we don't reach this goal, we'll still use all of the money to ship tennis balls.  Ultimately, we are grateful for each dollar and any amount of money will significantly benefit our project. 

Other ways you can help:

If you can't support our project financially right now, that is all right.  You can help in a number of different ways.

1. Spread the word! Not very many people know about PGB.  Help us by "liking," commenting, or sharing our Facebook Page.

2. Volunteer! We currently have 8 volunteers and 4 ambassadors from all over the United States.  If you would like to volunteer your time, reach out to us at info@projectgreenball.com.

3. Donate tennis balls! If you are interested in donating, send your balls to our turf manufacturer.

        North Brook Farms

        89 York St.

        Auburn, NY 13021

        Attn: Peter Kyle

The Process:

1. Ground tennis balls


2. Pre-mixture of ground tennis balls and IGK Equestrian's soil


3. Then the balls and soil are fully mixed to create IGK Equestrian's "Grand Slam Footing"


4. And finally the footing is laid out in the arena and ready for use


Perks:

To thank you for your generous donations, we're offering some perks we hope you will enjoy.  We have found that many supporters of Project Green Ball enjoy spreading the word about Project Green Ball. Most of our perks were created with that in mind.

***We'll ship all items free of charge within the United States.

***If you live internationally, please manually add an addition $10 to the price of the perk you want. We will do the matching at the end of the campaign. If you forget to pay for shipping... Don't worry! Just click the contribute now button at the top of the page and manually enter $10.

$10 donation: A thank you video from the founders, Ben and Scott.


$25 donation: A Project Green Ball wristband and a thank you video. 


$50 donation: Two Project Green Ball bumper stickers and a thank you video.

$75 donation: A Project Green Ball t-shirt with our logo and a thank you video.


$100 donation: 

A personalized video and the Project Green Ball T-shirt shown above. 


Who is behind Project Green Ball?:

A father and son with a problem.  We play a lot of tennis and we always have a hopper full of tennis balls.  But when those balls are dead and unplayable, it is a very sad thing to throw them in the trash and know that they will be filling up a landfill.  So one day, Ben (the son) said to Scott (the dad), there has to be a way to recycle tennis balls.

That’s when this quixotic quest began and we considered options for laying to rest used tennis balls – crushed and stuffed into beanbag chairs (too heavy), embedded in buoys (not enough balls killed and didn’t have an interest in the industry), construction (maybe?), extracting the chemicals and reselling (not enough value), mats (maybe in the future), rubberized asphalt (maybe, but probably not enough balls killed)…. You get the idea – lots of trial and error.

The real breakthrough we were killing time waiting for Ben's sister to finish up at her school.  While looking at the school’s equestrian center we noticed the turf had odd stuff in it.  Upon closer inspection we determined that stuff turned out to be pieces of rubber and different kinds of fabric.  Upon further research, we learned that every manufacturer has its own turf recipe and each seems to include rubber and fiber – exactly the ingredients included in a tennis ball – and the facilities are big which can result in the dignified burial of lots of balls.  After a lot more hard work, we finally thought we had something.


Other pictures of Project Green Ball:

Rumsey Hall High School collection bin.

PGB collection event at the Tennis Hall of Fame tennis tournament.

Americorps helping run a collection event.

Tennis players helping run a collection event.
story_txt:
MissionProject Green Ball is a non-profit sustainability initiative to coordinate innovative recycling programs for used tennis balls and to donate surfaces based on the recycled balls to organizations servicing people with disabilities or life threatening diseases.Check out our segment on Channel 5 News!
Summary:Project Green Ball's goal is to remove tennis balls from the waste stream and provide social benefit to people in need.  We do this by collecting tennis balls from clubs, tournaments, schools, teams, associations, and individuals.  Once the balls are collected we send them to an equestrian turf manufacturer. Together, IGK Equestrian and Project Green Ball have developed an equestrian turf based on ground tennis balls.  Once we deliver 200,000 balls, the manufacturer will donate an equestrian turf to a therapeutic riding program for people with disabilities.  Our goal is to donate as many balls as possible to the manufacturer, resulting in the donation of many equestrian turfs to therapeutic riding centers. Accomplishments:
PGB has collected over 145,000 balls to date. 
PGB is the largest recycler of tennis balls in the United States
PGB facilitated the donation of an equestrian turf through a UPS grant to EquiCenter. 
Wilson Sporting Goods has gotten behind PGB and supported the shipment of nearly 40,000 balls.  

PGB currently has 62 organizations nation wide which have donated tennis balls and hosted 20 collection bins.
PGB has 8 volunteers and 4 ambassadors.
PGB has won 4 grants totaling in $3,500 and 2 awards, including a MassRecycle Innovation Award.
PGB has filed for 501(c)(3) status.
Impact:300 million tennis balls are manufactured worldwide each year (with over 125 million used in the US) and tons of balls are discarded into landfills each year. The balls decompose very slowly and take up space in landfills, producing methane gas and contributing to global warming.  Everyone is aware of reuse applications for tennis balls—bottoms of chairs and walkers and as toys for dogs.  But there is a limit to how many balls each year can be put to this purpose.  And, even if reused, ultimately these balls still remain in the waste stream and wind up in landfills.  There was no solution to recycling tennis balls until now. Project Green Ball removes tennis balls from the waste stream by incorporating them into ball-based turfs.FAQs:Please visit our FAQ page on our website: Project Green Ball FAQ.What your donation is going to:The more funds we raise, the more balls we will receive.  All funds raised through this project will be used to support the shipment of tennis balls. Currently, shipping is inhibiting our success.  We constantly have people calling us from all over the world asking how they can ship their balls and whether we will be able to pay for shipping.  Shipping can be very expensive, and often times we lose donations because the donors do not have funds to ship the balls.We are aiming for $500.  If we don't reach this goal, we'll still use all of the money to ship tennis balls.  Ultimately, we are grateful for each dollar and any amount of money will significantly benefit our project. Other ways you can help:If you can't support our project financially right now, that is all right.  You can help in a number of different ways.1. Spread the word! Not very many people know about PGB.  Help us by "liking," commenting, or sharing our Facebook Page.2. Volunteer! We currently have 8 volunteers and 4 ambassadors from all over the United States.  If you would like to volunteer your time, reach out to us at info@projectgreenball.com.3. Donate tennis balls! If you are interested in donating, send your balls to our turf manufacturer.        North Brook Farms        89 York St.        Auburn, NY 13021        Attn: Peter KyleThe Process:1. Ground tennis balls2. Pre-mixture of ground tennis balls and IGK Equestrian's soil3. Then the balls and soil are fully mixed to create IGK Equestrian's "Grand Slam Footing"4. And finally the footing is laid out in the arena and ready for usePerks:To thank you for your generous donations, we're offering some perks we hope you will enjoy.  We have found that many supporters of Project Green Ball enjoy spreading the word about Project Green Ball. Most of our perks were created with that in mind.***We'll ship all items free of charge within the United States.***If you live internationally, please manually add an addition $10 to the price of the perk you want. We will do the matching at the end of the campaign. If you forget to pay for shipping... Don't worry! Just click the contribute now button at the top of the page and manually enter $10.$10 donation: A thank you video from the founders, Ben and Scott.
$25 donation: A Project Green Ball wristband and a thank you video. 
$50 donation: Two Project Green Ball bumper stickers and a thank you video.
$75 donation: A Project Green Ball t-shirt with our logo and a thank you video.

story:
Hello! 

My name is Hedda and I am the farmer, florist, and owner at Full Bloom Flower Farm.  I absolutely love growing and working with flowers and all the insects, birds and soil critters who help run the farm. Full Bloom Flower Farm is part of a rising call to local, chemical-free flower power. The impact of soil building, pollinator friendly, low milage bouquet farming is simply beautiful. I love to teach workshops, design for events and weddings and bring joy in the form of flowers everywhere in West Sonoma County. 

Greenhouse Help!

Full Bloom Flower Farm is still a baby and needs help building a home for its baby plants.  Last April we assembled old scaffolding, nets and shade cloth into a long make-shift nursery.  I was still working as a garden teacher in San Francisco and was so lucky to have the help of my sister.  Leah watered the babies, sometimes 6 times a day, with wonderful germination rates and a fantastic first season to follow.  With high temperature summers and hard frost in the winter it is critical to have a solid, well functioning greenhouse.  As many personal friends know, I am going to run the farm this year as well as attend herbal school three days a week.  This one-woman operation needs a greenhouse with automatic irrigation. I can't wait to introduce herbs and herbal medicine into my business, however it leaves me with with very little money to invest into this amazing farm.  I can't wait to provide quality flowers, teas, food and medicine to the community and it all starts in the nursery. 

Thank You!

Thank you for supporting local flowers, the story of the slow flower movement and pollinators!  It truly means the world to me. My dad and I have already started the construction of a simple hoophouse style greenhouse.  I am excited to share how redwood, a plastic cover, wiggle wire, tables, irrigation, doors, paint, rebar, pvc, pump, filter, timer, irrigation and heating pads come together to make a simple model for other small farms and home gardeners to follow. And zip ties, not to be forgotten, a favorite garden tool. 

Bee Cause

Bee cause flowers are important for insects and because the story of chemical-free flowers needs a voice, I can't thank you enough for sharing my story and following the growth of this little, mighty, bright farm! Please help spread the word and share this project with friends.  Slow flowers matter!
