story:
THE MAGIC OF MANTAS!

Manta rays are mesmerizing and mysterious gentle giants, and under the sunlit water of Maui’s Olowalu reef is a rare aggregation site visited by over 350 of them.  Here, curious mantas come together to socialize, mate, and have a variety of cleaner fish remove unwanted parasites. These enchanting creatures have captured the hearts and minds of people all over the world.  And they need YOUR help.

Mantas possess one of the largest brain to body ratios of any fish, rivaling that of marine mammals, and likely responsible for their very curious nature, often prompting them to investigate boats, divers, and snorkelers. 

Sadly, recent surveys of this manta population visiting Olowalu reveal that 1 out of every 10 mantas suffer from an amputated or severely damaged cephalic fin, an important appendage used to guide plankton into their mouth. These injuries are the result of getting entangled in fishing line. So despite laws in Hawaii protecting manta rays from being killed or captured, entanglement in fishing line poses a serious threat to this population.

In some parts of the world, well-managed manta ray commercial dive operations have generated millions of dollars in sustainable revenue for small communities instead of unsustainable short-term profits from hunting and selling manta rays to the open market. But in many parts of the world, mantas are being hunted and harmed, and the race to protect them is urgent.  To do this we need to better understand their population size, range, habitat needs, and threats. And we need YOUR help to make it happen.


WHY MUST WE ACT NOW?

Manta rays take a long time to reach sexual maturity and females only have a single pup every 2-3 years.  As a result, populations grow very slowly and can be severely threatened by removal of just a few individuals. In many parts of the world where manta rays are hunted directly or killed as by-catch in fisheries, these populations have been decimated in a matter of months.

In these special areas around where manta ray aggregations can be reliably observed, commercial dive operations, if properly managed, can  generate millions of dollars in sustainable annual revenue for these communities, ones that might otherwise hunt these graceful animals to sell on the open market for much less money. The more we can learn about the population and habitat needs of the mantas rays here in Maui, the more we can champion the management and protection of manta rays in other parts of the world, and to do that we need YOU.

If we don’t act soon, manta ray numbers in these small populations may drop beyond a point at which recovery would be possible.  In light of the many environmental changes impacting our global ocean, this is not a problem we can afford to overlook.


WHAT WE WILL ACHIEVE WITH YOUR HELP

In short, we will be using the funds from this Indiegogo campaign and our other contributors to begin a three-pronged plan: enhance our manta online database, track mantas with both acoustic and satellite tags, and outreach.  The money sought through this initial funding drive will be largely devoted to purchasing and implementing both the acoustic and satellite tags.  Funding from other sources and potentially a second crowd sourcing platform will be required to complete the project in full.

  • Manta Database: Our database currently contains over 330 individual animals sited mostly from a single location.  We want to increase public access to our database and configure it to allow the public to add data and photographs, and search for (and find matches with) animals encountered in the wild.  This will serve to greatly increase our information about where these animals are being seen and other aspects of behavior and life history and also help us meet our objective of community engagement.
  • Manta Tracking (acoustic & satellite): Within their large home ranges, mantas can focus heavily on specific areas for the removal of parasites, social and reproductive behaviors, and for feeding. Identifying those critical areas can be difficult. We will use two tagging techniques; acoustic tags that emit an individual signal to receivers already installed by the University of Hawaii and satellite tags that will provide us with a more detailed picture of their habitat range and dive profiles with instantaneously accessible results.  With tag batteries lasting over a year, much can be learned about an individual manta ray’s preferences and better understanding of which habitats overlap with areas of high risk for entanglement.
  • Community Outreach: Once we identify habitats that are frequented by Maui's mantas that are also areas subject to high fishing pressure, we will be use a proven, effective outreach program known as Community-Based Social Marketing (CBSM) to target, engage, and educate local fishermen to help protect Maui’s mantas from fishing line entanglement. CBSM is a tool that identifies obstacles impeding desired behavior and identifies and implements incentives to motivate desired behavior, a proven technique for achieving positive change and promoting sustainable habits.

 

WHO ARE WE?

The Hawaii Association for Marine Education and Research (HAMER) is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization that has been conducting manta ray research in Hawaii over the last decade. We have produced several peer-reviewed scientific publications that describe Maui’s manta population size, its range, demographics, reproductive habits, and threats posed by humans.  HAMER also played a key role in establishing a law that protects manta rays in Hawaii from being killed or captured and who's research helped with the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) voting to make it illegal to trade manta rays and their parts worldwide.

This information is invaluable to the scientific community when we attempt to urge lawmakers, governments, and businesses to consider how our everyday activities impact the world we live in and the resources we will have (or won’t) in the future.

Team HAMER (and our amazing partners in the field):

·  Dr. Mark Deakos is the Executive Director and founder of HAMER, and has been conducting manta ray research in Hawaii for the past decade. During this time he has produced several peer-reviewed scientific publications describing Maui’s manta population demographics, reproductive habits, range, and human threats. 

·  Anthony Roberts is a seasoned database developer with over twenty years’ experience that will assist us with streamlining the database in anticipation of our online, public release.

·  Dr. Andrea Marshall is a world-renowned scientist from the Marine Megafauna Foundation.  She has been featured in several major documentaries concerning manta rays, has successfully satellite-tagged more than 80 individual mantas, and is the author of the first-ever doctoral dissertation on manta rays.

·  Jonathan Whitney is a doctoral candidate from the University of Hawaii, and is an expert in molecular ecology who will be assisting us with acoustic tag deployment and genetic analysis.

· Julie Hartup a HAMER board member, founded the Micronesion Manta Project and is currently the Manta Trust Project Leader for The Federated States of Micronesia and the Marianas Islands. For her Master’s Julie is describing a new feeding behavior with her manta rays in Guam that target fish spawning aggregations to feed on the fish eggs.  In collaboration with several other scientists Julie is currently tagging reef manta rays in Pohnpei, Micronesia, to look at their patterns of habitat use and home range. 


WAYS TO HELP

When it comes to saving the mantas and the planet, every little bit helps. Any tax deductible contributions you are able to donate will go towards saving the lives of mantas and protecting Maui’s legendary waters. You can rest assured that with our experience and proven track record that every dollar earned from this campaign will be used to better the lives of Maui’s manta rays both in the now and for generations to come.

If you are unable to donate financially, you can still help the mantas by spreading the word about HAMER and our Indiegogo campaign through Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, or any other social media site you use, help us spread the word!

story:
Overview

Hands Around Clear Lake is a yearly Healing Ceremony and Tribal Gathering, held on the shores of Clear Lake, geographically the largest lake in California and geologically oldest lake in North America. 

The purpose of Hands Around Clear Lake is to unite the community, honor the waters, share our healing intentions, and celebrate life. The “tribe” in “tribal gathering” refers to all of us, this growing and eclectic community of people learning to live together on this land, learning to steward the sacred waters and to share in authentic community.

We come together every year in a dynamic community expression of solidarity with the lake, with each other, and our wider human family and the community of LIFE. Hands Around Clear Lake is more than a sunrise ceremony — it is a sacred gathering of free people, coming together to co-create a better world. It features art, music, networking, co-inspiring, and co-creating this shift to a more just, peaceful and joyful world.

The gathering is FREE to all.

This Indiegogo campaign is part of how we're keeping it that way.

We are also using this campaign as a way to raise funds for a group of local nonprofits who are doing excellent work in building local resilience. (Scroll down for complete list.)

With your help, Hands Around Clear Lake will be a great success this year, and for many years to come -- and we will continue to transform Lake County into a healthier, happier, and ever more sustainable hub of peace, consciousness and natural abundance.

What We Need & What You Get

The goal of this campaign is to raise $2,000. Or more : )

The first thousand will be used to cover event costs, pay our musicians, and keep Hands Around Clear Lake free for everyone.

All additional funds will go to benefit the following valuable local nonprofits: Thrive Lake County, Transition Lake County, the Time Bank of Lake County, the Lake County Community Co-Op, Lake County Community Radio (KPFZ), Public Access TV8, The House of Living Rhythm, the Lucy Moore Foundation, and the newly formed Cobb Mountain Community Radio.

We have a growing selection of excellent perks to share with you for sharing your contribution. Take a look to the right to see our offerings, ranging from CD's and sage wraps, to healing sessions and sacred gems. The best perk, however, is knowing that you're a part of this movement, this celebration, this healing transformation taking place on our lands and in our waters. 

Money represents energy, and a contribution to this campaign represents a contribution of energy, toward the healing of Clear Lake, our communities, and our entire world.

    A Little More About Hands Around Clear Lake

    On Sunday, September 21, 2014, we will be gathering at Library Park in Lakeport, CA, for a sunrise blessing of the water at 7AM, followed by a full-day Resilience Festival filled with free activities and workshops, speeches, a potluck, and live music by local favorites Righteous Vibrations, Without a Net, Maggie’s Farmers, and the nationally-recognized Human Revolution.

    The Resilience Festival at Hands Around Clear Lake will include several free re-skilling workshops, with neighbors teaching useful skills like natural building, organic gardening, jewelry-making and yoga.

    There will be an “Open Space” meeting allowing us to self-organize into discussion and action groups, working together on the things that matter most to us — like local food security, human rights, and improving the health of our beloved Clear Lake.

    There will be engaging speeches from inspirational local leaders, as well as a “People’s Mic” for you to share your passion with the community.

    We are also planning Peace Program for the 4 o'clock hour, to honor that September 21 is the International Day of Peace AND the day of the largest-ever “People’s Climate March” in New York, Washington, Oakland, and all around the country.

    With military conflicts raging in far-off lands, police brutality erupting throughout the US, and so many other challenges and atrocities taking place in our world nowadays, it is more important now than ever for us to stand in solidarity — with our planet, with out people, with the waters.

      Risks & Challenges

      We'll be running this campaign through Sunday, October 12, 2014.

      The event itself is on September 21, 2014, just three days from the launch date of this campaign. We hope this will give event attendees ample time to visit this page after the gathering to make contributions. However, it would be optimal to reach our funding goal as quickly as possible.

      Please consider making a contribution to this campaign now... There really is no time like the present, and you never know what's going to happen once you navigate away from this page.

      Thanks for taking the time to learn more about this cause!

      : )

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Some people just can't contribute money, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

        • You can help get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!
        • You can share it on your Facebook or Twitter account... but don't stop there: 
          Tag a few friends, email this page to your coworkers, your parents, your wealthy Aunt Milly... One of the best things about Hands Around Clear Lake is that, just by existing, it is doing healing work. The more people who know about it, and who are able to send positive intention, the better.
        • Visit  www.handsaroundclearlake.com for more info, and also check out our Facebook Page and Event Page. Share widely and invite your friends!
        • Send some prayers or healing visualizations to Clear Lake, to our planet, even to your own beating heart. We really are all one, and as long as you're vibrating LOVE, you're a part of the solution. So send light! Vote our victory, as we vote yours...
        • If you're unable to attend the gathering, you can tune in for the 7AM Sunrise Ceremony LIVE on KPFZ 88.1 FM in Lake County, and streaming free on our website, www.handsaroundclearlake.com
        • Seriously, think for a sec. Which of your friends might be interested in this?
        • Please Share : )

        Many Thanks!
story_txt:
Overview

Hands Around Clear Lake is a yearly Healing Ceremony and Tribal Gathering, held on the shores of Clear Lake, geographically the largest lake in California and geologically oldest lake in North America. 


The purpose of Hands Around Clear Lake is to unite the community, honor the waters, share our healing intentions, and celebrate life. The “tribe” in “tribal gathering” refers to all of us, this growing and eclectic community of people learning to live together on this land, learning to steward the sacred waters and to share in authentic community.
We come together every year in a dynamic community expression of solidarity with the lake, with each other, and our wider human family and the community of LIFE. Hands Around Clear Lake is more than a sunrise ceremony — it is a sacred gathering of free people, coming together to co-create a better world. It features art, music, networking, co-inspiring, and co-creating this shift to a more just, peaceful and joyful world.
The gathering is FREE to all.
This Indiegogo campaign is part of how we're keeping it that way.
We are also using this campaign as a way to raise funds for a group of local nonprofits who are doing excellent work in building local resilience. (Scroll down for complete list.)
With your help, Hands Around Clear Lake will be a great success this year, and for many years to come -- and we will continue to transform Lake County into a healthier, happier, and ever more sustainable hub of peace, consciousness and natural abundance.   What We Need & What You Get
The goal of this campaign is to raise $2,000. Or more : )
The first thousand will be used to cover event costs, pay our musicians, and keep Hands Around Clear Lake free for everyone.
All additional funds will go to benefit the following valuable local nonprofits: Thrive Lake County, Transition Lake County, the Time Bank of Lake County, the Lake County Community Co-Op, Lake County Community Radio (KPFZ), Public Access TV8, The House of Living Rhythm, the Lucy Moore Foundation, and the newly formed Cobb Mountain Community Radio.
We have a growing selection of excellent perks to share with you for sharing your contribution. Take a look to the right to see our offerings, ranging from CD's and sage wraps, to healing sessions and sacred gems. The best perk, however, is knowing that you're a part of this movement, this celebration, this healing transformation taking place on our lands and in our waters. 
Money represents energy, and a contribution to this campaign represents a contribution of energy, toward the healing of Clear Lake, our communities, and our entire world.

  A Little More About Hands Around Clear Lake

On Sunday, September 21, 2014, we will be gathering at Library Park in Lakeport, CA, for a sunrise blessing of the water at 7AM, followed by a full-day Resilience Festival filled with free activities and workshops, speeches, a potluck, and live music by local favorites Righteous Vibrations, Without a Net, Maggie’s Farmers, and the nationally-recognized Human Revolution.


The Resilience Festival at Hands Around Clear Lake will include several free re-skilling workshops, with neighbors teaching useful skills like natural building, organic gardening, jewelry-making and yoga.


There will be an “Open Space” meeting allowing us to self-organize into discussion and action groups, working together on the things that matter most to us — like local food security, human rights, and improving the health of our beloved Clear Lake.


There will be engaging speeches from inspirational local leaders, as well as a “People’s Mic” for you to share your passion with the community.


We are also planning Peace Program for the 4 o'clock hour, to honor that September 21 is the International Day of Peace AND the day of the largest-ever “People’s Climate March” in New York, Washington, Oakland, and all around the country.

With military conflicts raging in far-off lands, police brutality erupting throughout the US, and so many other challenges and atrocities taking place in our world nowadays, it is more important now than ever for us to stand in solidarity — with our planet, with out people, with the waters.

  Risks & Challenges

We'll be running this campaign through Sunday, October 12, 2014.

The event itself is on September 21, 2014, just three days from the launch date of this campaign. We hope this will give event attendees ample time to visit this page after the gathering to make contributions. However, it would be optimal to reach our funding goal as quickly as possible.

Please consider making a contribution to this campaign now... There really is no time like the present, and you never know what's going to happen once you navigate away from this page.

Thanks for taking the time to learn more about this cause!
: )

  Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute money, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

You can help get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!

You can share it on your Facebook or Twitter account... but don't stop there: Tag a few friends, email this page to your coworkers, your parents, your wealthy Aunt Milly... One of the best things about Hands Around Clear Lake is that, just by existing, it is doing healing work. The more people who know about it, and who are able to send positive intention, the better.

Visit  www.handsaroundclearlake.com for more info, and also check out our Facebook Page and Event Page. Share widely and invite your friends!
Send some prayers or healing visualizations to Clear Lake, to our planet, even to your own beating heart. We really are all one, and as long as you're vibrating LOVE, you're a part of the solution. So send light! Vote our victory, as we vote yours... If you're unable to attend the gathering, you can tune in for the 7AM Sunrise Ceremony LIVE on KPFZ 88.1 FM in Lake County, and streaming free on our website, www.handsaroundclearlake.com

story:
To All Who Have Asked Me, "How can I help?"

My name is Gerry Benedicto. My father was one of the unfortunate victims of Typhoon Haiyan, also known as Typhoon  Yolanda, which hit the Philippines Nov. 8, 2013. While our family is still coping with this tragedy, we want to make light of the situation as best we can. Relief efforts are underway in the Philippines, however, I want to provide immediate and direct assistance to the victims who have lost everything, including their homes and basic necessities.

The small village of Bislig was completely destroyed, which is where my father's house was located and where he perished. Bislig meant everything to my father and I know if he were here today, he would want nothing more than to help the villagers rebuild their homes and livelihoods. So let's do what we can to make that happen.

One dollar goes a long way in the Philippines, and even further in smaller, destitute towns. When I visited the Philippines after the disaster, I had the chance to speak to a villager who survived the typhoon. He told me, "We need money to buy tools and supplies so we can rebuild our homes and our church." The villagers of Bislig are resilient people and can do a lot with minimal support. Any contribution big or small will make an impact.  This doesn't just end with you...the beauty of digital media helps us spread the word and raise awareness. Please forward this campaign to anyone who is interested in helping out.  The support I received from my friends and family has been more than I could've asked for – now it's time for me to share that support with those who are in much more dire need.

From the bottom of our hearts, thank you.

Gerry and the Benedicto family.

story:
Hamjambo! (Hi!)

My name is Yoko and I am working on a water project in Tanzania in a remote village called Mbola. I am a MS candidate in Sustainability Management and an ardent supporter of water governance and sustainability, which is what brought me here for the summer to work with the UN Millennium Villages Project (MVP).

Until the last couple of years, villagers in Mbola did not have access to a protected water source. Their primary source of water came from hand dug shallow wells that have unreliable access throughout the year and are prone to all types of contamination from agricultural runoff and human waste.

Between 2008 and 2012, dozens of boreholes and shallow wells were constructed by the MVP. However, I arrived here in early June 2013 to discover that the water taps under the piped water scheme were locked up and villagers had started using the unprotected wells again! As suspected, water scarcity was not the issue. The real issue lie in weak management and the users' lack of understanding about the value of water beyond its immediate use.

I am now analyzing the supply and demand of this piped water scheme to support 7-day access at each of these taps and to ensure its sustainability. But I am hoping to raise money to cover the first month’s energy cost to get us started. With an average use of 1,300,000L per month, we need roughly Tsh 600,000 (US$375) to run the pump. This will benefit 3,500 villagers who will experience the value of reliable and safe water every day. In addition, the drilling of 3 boreholes was suspended in early 2012 due to a lack of funding. Each borehole costs Tsh 9,000,000 (US$5,625) to drill and supplies entire communities. My goal is to raise funds for at least one of these boreholes, but any extra funds will go towards the other two boreholes.

I will also add that my birthday is 3 weeks away on July 21st, which marks the 27th year of this incredible life that I've been so lucky to have!! I’m grateful that I already have everything I want in my life so I would like to give up my birthday and have any money that would otherwise go to birthday presents go towards this cause I care so much about! Please help me in raising this fund, and thank you for reading this far. Even if you cannot contribute in monetary form, I hope I was able to change your view about water and that you will pass this story along :-)

Asante sana! (Thank you very much!)

story:
About me...

  • I am Avik Roy. I am an environmental activist, a writer, journalist and an ordinary individual with a passion to protect the environment and spread awareness among people across the world. I work for a newspaper called The Pioneer in India; I write on environment issues, climate change and international policies for the newspaper. I am also a Greenpeace activist in my country. I also track the international climate negotiations, especially my country’s role in framing policy to save the planet and people. 

    Achievements:

    My work and my passion led me to be selected to attend the Global power Shift in Istanbul last June. I received the prestigious Adopt a Negotiator Fellowship to attend the United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP19) last November, in Warsaw. 
    And now, I have been selected to attend the Climate Reality Leadership training in Johannesburg this March. Climate Reality Leaders are trained by the Chairman and Founder of the Climate Reality Project, former Vice President Al Gore to educate others about climate change and tackle the crisis head on.

  • I applied for this training since it is a great opportunity to connect to the wide spectrum of people and talk about climate change and take collective action. I will use my Greenpeace, Global Power Shift and Adopt a Negotiator fellowship experiences and take-aways and journalism platform for sharing knowledge and building movements in my country. Speakers like Kumi Naidoo, Jonathan Deal and Wanjira Mathai, other than Al Gore himself will be there to train us.

    I could be a part of the group of people from around the world that are unified around the same cause, spreading the truth about climate change and inspiring action on the climate crisis.

    However, there is no funding or scholarship that is available from any organisation right now. That is to say: I have to arrange for my own funding to cover the cost of travel, accommodation and meal. While I can afford and somehow manage to arrange for the accommodation and meals in Johannesburg, the airfare from New Delhi to Johannesburg is beyond my capacity. It is with individual support from generous friends like you that I would be able to achieve my dream of being a climate leader. 

What I Need & What You Get

  • I have done a background research on the costs involved. The cheapest round trip (return including) air-fare from New Delhi to Johannesburg is around INR 60,000 (roughly 1,000 US Dollars). That is all that I need right now. I will be able to afford the cost of Visa, accommodation and meal in Johannesburg. But, without the airfare (prices are shooting up every day) I am helpless. That is where I need your help in raising this fund. You may contribute whatever you can; any amount that you feel will could turn this into a reality. The perks and amount at the right are only suggestive.
  • I will keep each of you updated with the latest event and happening around the world in regards to climate issue, through emails, Facebook updates, Twitter feeds and my own blog. I will send pictures from the event to anyone who is interested. I know this is nothing in return compared to what you are contributing. But, together we can make this world a better place to live in.

The Impact

  • Ordinary people face challenges. Climate Reality Leaders embrace them. The Climate Reality Leadership Corps is a global network of activists committed to taking on the climate crisis and solving the greatest threat humanity has ever faced. The program takes great leaders and makes them exceptional, providing the training in climate science, communications, and organizing to tell the story of climate change and inspire communities everywhere to take action. The result is a dynamic group of world-changers shaping the conversation on climate in forums from family dinners to international summits and building a 21st-century movement for solutions. I am just one step away from achieving all these but for the fund crisis.

  • I have already taken several actions in a bid to protect the environment. As a journalist and columnist, I will write, tell stories and engage in mass communication about global climate movement. Using my experience from the summit I'll be able to inspire action among the local communities. From the journalistic point of view, this training will help me understand the existing policy framework on climate change that is in practice and what has been so far. I will write about the issues in my country's media as well as international communities and inspire others to take action. The summit will be an opportunity for me to refine my skills, share knowledge, build a network with people and communities globally. I will use these skills to build movements involving people and communities to tackle the climate crisis.
  • Within a year of completing the training with the Climate Reality Leadership Corps I will be required to perform ten Acts of Leadership, which come in a variety of forms and will involve my local community. It may include giving a presentation, writing a blog, writing a letter to the editor, organising a film screening, organising a climate change-related campaign, meeting with local, state or national leaders and organising a day of action. I will be required to take action. 

Other Ways You Can Help

It will be really generous of you if you can contribute something to help me reach this goal and eventually protect the environment. I am in earnest need of fund to realise this dream; make this a reality. However, if in case you’re not in a position to contribute right now, you can also help me in other ways too.


  • Share this funding petition among your friends, networks and anyone you may think can contribute.
  • Post this link at Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest and also email it to your contacts.
  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tool.

Thank you so much!

story:
Jessie and Jane are taking a journey

We are two young women committed to a journey of rediscovery, remembering and reskilling.

The passion was kindled for us both while on our year long Trackways course, igniting the fire of nature immersion and ancient ways within us. We now seek to take this deeper, and to bring back and share the discoveries with us as we return.

At the end of March we will both be travelling to the Rocky Mountains to meet with 16 others, all making the commitment to learn and live the ways of our ancestors.

April will be spent turning deerskins into buckskins, to then make our clothes... going on to learn pottery, fishing, trapping, foraging, camp life, stone tools, and the joy and challenges of living as a hunter-gatherer clan.

And then we return... 

And we will bring the abundance of our learning and experience back with us to share. We see this as a learning for all our community back in Devon, something we wish to share the fruits of.

We've worked out that the whole trip will cost us at least £3000 each...

we've saved our pennies, our piggy banks are emptied, we are borrowing what we need... but we would love some support in raising some money to help us on this journey. 

Why all the way to America? 

We love the Devon hills, but there just isn't the space in the UK to do this kind of project.
Lynx, the teacher, is offering us an opportunity like no other, she's spent most of her life immersing in nature and learning and teaching these skills, there is no one like her in Europe.

We don't fly lightly! what we mean is we give huge thanks that we live in a time where we can fly through the air and across the ocean towards this opportunity.

Other Ways You Can Help...

If you can't contribute online, that doesn’t mean you can’t help! Please get the word out and let people know about our fundraising!

If we cross your minds through the coming months, spare a moment and envision us healthy and strong and well and happy in America.

Enjoy your mattress, your hot chocolate, your hot running tap, your clean socks, your pretty dresses... really enjoy them, for us!

We want to say that we already feel so supported by our friends and families.

Thank you for everything.

story:
My name is Aly Tharp. For years, I've been dreaming to sail on the open sea and research plastic pollution with the 5 Gyres. Now is my chance! 

When I saw that 5 Gyres was going to Iceland, I applied right away to join the expedition. And I'm in --- IF I can raise $8,500.

My goal is to raise $8500 for the 5 Gyres non-profit organization, and sail with them in June 2014. 

We will sail from Bermuda to the northern Atlantic's plastic pool, and then on to Iceland.  

A "gyre" is a large natural ocean current, and in the middle of each gyre is a dead zone where our plastic waste collects. This is where 5 Gyres gets its name from. Every hour, about 2 and a half million pounds of plastic --- over 1,000 metric tons --- drops into the ocean  (Source: http://bit.ly/1aGQwjn). 

On board the Viking Expedition, I will help take and study samples of oceanic plastic debris and see firsthand how the plastic breaks down over time by the sunlight and force of the ocean. I want to learn to identify the toxic industrial chemical compounds that have bonded to the plastic pollution -- such as DDT and PCB. 

I will be taking pictures from the boat, and from the water ---- and I hope to create a series of photographs that I can print and share with those who support my endeavor to join the 5 Gyres Viking Expedition. 

The issue of plastic pollution is both incredible and incredibly motivating to me, and I hope to inspire change and bring awareness to the state of the worlds oceans as a result of our consumerist culture. Here is a time-lapse video I made in 2011, of a mural we created in Costa Rica, depicting the ocean and our human connections to it:



All money raised in this campaign will go to the 5 Gyres Institute for our trip to the North Atlantic garbage patch.

PLEASE -- 

help the people who are trying to confront marine plastic pollution! 

Thank you for your contribution, be it $5 or $5,000 --- every bit helps.
story_txt:
My name is Aly Tharp. For years, I've been dreaming to sail on the open sea and research plastic pollution with the 5 Gyres. Now is my chance! When I saw that 5 Gyres was going to Iceland, I applied right away to join the expedition. And I'm in --- IF I can raise $8,500.My goal is to raise $8500 for the 5 Gyres non-profit organization, and sail with them in June 2014. We will sail from Bermuda to the northern Atlantic's plastic pool, and then on to Iceland.  A "gyre" is a large natural ocean current, and in the middle of each gyre is a dead zone where our plastic waste collects. This is where 5 Gyres gets its name from. Every hour, about 2 and a half million pounds of plastic --- over 1,000 metric tons --- drops into the ocean  (Source: http://bit.ly/1aGQwjn). On board the Viking Expedition, I will help take and study samples of oceanic plastic debris and see firsthand how the plastic breaks down over time by the sunlight and force of the ocean. I want to learn to identify the toxic industrial chemical compounds that have bonded to the plastic pollution -- such as DDT and PCB. I will be taking pictures from the boat, and from the water ---- and I hope to create a series of photographs that I can print and share with those who support my endeavor to join the 5 Gyres Viking Expedition. The issue of plastic pollution is both incredible and incredibly motivating to me, and I hope to inspire change and bring awareness to the state of the worlds oceans as a result of our consumerist culture. Here is a time-lapse video I made in 2011, of a mural we created in Costa Rica, depicting the ocean and our human connections to it:


All money raised in this campaign will go to the 5 Gyres Institute for our trip to the North Atlantic garbage patch.
PLEASE -- help the people who are trying to confront marine plastic pollution! Thank you for your contribution, be it $5 or $5,000 --- every bit helps.

story:
Super Typhoon Haiyan, the strongest storm recorded, displaced millions and destroyed critical water infrastructure. With your help, we have so far donated life saving water that.

  • Protect water from toxic particles such as phthalates and BPA leached by plastic bottles when exposed to heat and light under the equatorial sun
  • Preserve the pristine beaches, biodiverse jungles, & coral ecosystems of our planet from plastic bottle pollution (see TED Talk on oceanic gyres & how the US's plastic bottles end up in the Philippines)
  • Provide a modest recycling income to survivors, many of whom have lost everything

Now campaign proceeds go towards rebuilding. 

"Mobile Infrastructure" with TOHL Helicopter Deployed Pipeline

Each instance of pipeline providing water at 50,000 L/day (2.5L for 20,000 people). 

An operating partner for Blue Can's relief efforts Sisters of Mary in Cebu, a school that houses, feeds, and teaches 12,000 of children from the poorest areas, was damaged in the October earthquake and sent students and teachers to Tacloban. Now there are 1,000 missing children from Tacloban, Leyte, and Samar.


Who we are:      

STAC Silicon Valley is a 501c3 nonprofit that supports the creation and growth of Philippine based start ups. Blue Can, the California based "clean alternative to plastic bottles" was founded this spring and sponsored a Philippine Independence Day event. In the US, Blue Can's Foundation prepares individuals and communities for disasters with emergency water that resists spoilage and lasts for decades. The vision is to put a dent in the 63.4 billion plastic bottles dumped into landfills and oceans annually.

 

Our partners at LBC Express Inc shipped this water to Cebu, to be distributed by the Red Cross & The Sisters of Mary, of which 40% of the 12,000 students, who are from the poorest areas of the Philippines, are also from the devastated areas. 

 

Your generosity is crucial to Filipinos coping with the disaster, where water is scarce and lines for basic necessities are long.

  • FirstGiving will send you a tax-deductible receipt for your contribution.

  • Gifts go towards rebuilding water infrastructure. In the meanwhile, pass this along to others who can share in our vision.

Thank you, friends of the Philippines!

Salamat, kaibigans ng Pilipinas!

    

Join Blue Can's email newsletter to hear about events where a discount will be available to donors. Subscribers receive resources on emergency preparedness, plastic bottle pollution, and/or healthy hydration.


Note on US Tax Deductible Donations

501(c)(3) non-profit fund custodian: Science & Technology Advisory Council, TAX (ID 94-3161336), 447 Sutter Street, Suite 518, San Francisco, CA 94108.

*STAC is a partner of the Philippine Dept. of Foreign Affairs, Dept. of Trade & Industry and Dept. of Science & Technology in developing a start up ecosystem. STAC is a partner of the US Dept. of State's Global Entrepreneurship Program. These volunteer Filipinos host pitch competitions in Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao, where participants receive expert feedback on business strategy. Winners have received over $6m in investments and are hosted to attend accelerator programs.

In addition to this campaign, STAC is also supervising Bay Area aid efforts for first responders with the Philippine Aid Network. Angela has volunteered for Sisters of Mary for nine years and has helped children survivors.

story:
My KAPE | KAPE 2 ATACAMA

                                                         

                           Making Mountains Metaphors



What is KAPE 2 ATACAMA all about? 

KAPE 2 ATACAMA or K2A14 is next in the My KAPE series of environmentally and socially responsible climbing expeditions. 

In March 2014, the team cranks up their main sail for the 6100km (3800 miles) crossing of the unpredictable Atlantic Ocean. Once they touch land in Fortaleza, Brazil, they will travel by foot and public transport only, exploring some of the most beautiful and isolated areas that South America has to offer while promoting the ideals of sustainable living within communities and schools.

This route will take them to places where the air is thin, the climbing is strenuous and the conditions are unforgiving. It includes scaling the second highest peak in the Western Hemisphere, Ojos del Salado, which lies on the outskirts of the Atacama Desert.

#K2A14 in a nutshell

Sea to Summit

5 months;

Covering over 20 000kms;

A 6000m hat-trick;

Altitude gain will be equivalent to two Everest’s;

Summit Ojos del Salado; and a

3800 mile (6100km) Atlantic Ocean crossing


Social Responsibility & Research

Only eco-friendly travel;

Promoting epilepsy awareness; and

Hands-on programmes and fun and interactive activities to inspire and promote the ideal of sustainable living.


Contributing to a more sustainable future.

In partnership with The Percy Fitzpatrick Institute, the team will be researching  Southern Atlantic pollution during the Atlantic Ocean crossing.


                                         

Epilepsy awareness - "Just one step in front of the other" 

                                                     

                          

An example of the school programmes used during the KAPE 2 KENYA expedition in 2012: 

Who is the team behind K2A14?

         

What we need, and what you get!

An expedition like KAPE 2 ATACAMA 2014, quite simply, costs A LOT ...

Finding enough money to make sure the programmes and climbs are as successful as possible is thus a huge priority at the moment.

You may not have a penny BUT you may have something else to contribute ...

  • Contacts within one of the countries we'll be travelling;
  • Organisations that may want to get involved with the expedition;
  • Maybe you have a warm bed or bit of floor to lend us; or
  • There are bits of vital gear needed, such as a four season lightweight tent

Plus, check out the perks!!

The impact that we'll be making:

Actions always speak louder than words.

Over the past couple of years My KAPE and its expeditions have been gaining a reputation as a “Trustworthy and sincere operation”. 

Previous expedition: KAPE 2 KENYA 2012

We MADE Mountains Metaphors 

  • Summitted Mount Kenya's highest peak, Batian, which stands at 5199m, on 20 June 2012;
  • Met over 600 students at their schools;
  • Traveled over 14 000kms by public transport and sustainable transport only;
  • Kept the awareness up by talking to the press along the way;
  • Explored the wilder side of each country, including the Namib Desert and Malawi's Mount Mulanje; and
  • No gear was couriered for the mountain.

We're aiming to make sure our impact in creating awareness around epilepsy and environmental sustainability far surpasses what we've achieved in the past. 

Awards:

NightJar Adventure of 2013 Readers Choice.

                    



To think KAPE 2 KENYA 2012 achieved that ... one can only expect KAPE 2 ATACAMA 2014 to be even bigger and better.


We're Making Mountains Metaphors ...

               Come and join us!

                 


                        Thank you to our sponsor's for the incredible perks.

story:
A team of engineers wants to make a difference!

"The goal of this project is to bring technical knowledge of best water management and farming practices to the region of La Mixteca Alta. This will be accomplished through the implementation of simple and sustainable technologies that local farmers will be able to learn and replicate throughout the region. In this pilot project, some of the technologies introduced will be: Wind-pumps, rainwater catchment tanks, pedal pumps and drip irrigation.

For more pictures please visit our Facebook page

For a more in depth explanation of the project please continue to read."

Executive Summary

The agricultural potential of the region of La Mixteca Alta is limited by its arid climate. Agricultural practices in the region since the second half of the twentieth century have exacerbated this problem, leading to poor soil conditions and limited productivity. For this reason, few community members can fully support themselves through agriculture alone. Many must seek work as transient laborers in nearby cities.

This project delineates a sustainable agriculture and water management program to be implemented in the region. The project focuses on transfer of knowledge while working in cooperation with local communities to develop and build best water management and agricultural solutions. These solutions include simple technologies such as rainwater harvesting and drip irrigation, and more complex solutions, like bio-drainage and wind-powered water pumping. All systems and devices will be constructed locally, utilizing local materials and labor.


In the short term, the goal of this project is to develop solutions to current water management and agricultural issues and, through the implementation of these solutions to actively transfer practical knowledge to the communities. In the long term, the project aims to establish a platform where program members can continue to collaborate with the local community and NGOs, thereby cultivating rural water management and agriculture best practices in the region.


General Information and Current Conditions

 San Miguel Huautla is located in the Mixteca Alta region, in the state of Oaxaca, in Southern Mexico. It covers an area of about 36 square miles located at 17° 44’ latitude north and 97o 08’ longitude west. The community is 53 miles northeast of Oaxaca de Juárez and 20 miles northwest of Asunción Nochixtlán. The region is mountainous, with elevations ranging from 1800 to 2800 meters and characterized by steep slopes and escarpments. The landscape is marked by ridges, fissures, sinkholes and other features.

 At higher altitudes the climate is temperate sub-humid with an average temperature of 18 degrees Celsius and little seasonal variation. The climate at lower altitudes is temperate semiarid. Rainfall ranges from 600 to 800 mm annually, falling primarily in the summer, June through October. Less than 5% of the annual precipitation occurs in the winter, November through May.

 Two different agricultural practices are common in the region. During the summer months, rain-fed agriculture predominates. During the dry winter months, dry farming techniques are used to produce crops such as corn, wheat, and oats that have lower water requirements. Use of this technique enables communities in the region to maximize their production capacity by utilizing the moisture retained in the soil from the rainy months. When used, the most common irrigation method is flood irrigation.

 Current agricultural practices in the region are constrained by lack of resources and technology. Most members of the communities are subsistence farmers, with families managing their own land plots without modern equipment, sometimes relying on the assistance of neighbors. Most farming techniques are passed on generation to generation and community members do not have sufficient access to new techniques and methods.

 Income from activities within the community only partially covers the basic needs. During months of low agricultural productivity, heads of the household emigrate to look for jobs outside of the region, primarily to the cities of Oaxaca, Puebla, Nochixtlan, or Mexico City. This emigration brings most of the earnings into the community. Women stay in the community to take care of the household during this period.

 San Miguel Huautla is favorably located within the regional watershed. A number of springs exist in the area, and are largely used as sources of gravity-driven water system for household consumption and agriculture purposes. In 2010, approximately half of the homes had direct access to water.

 Approximately 80% of the homes currently have electrical energy through access to an energy distribution system. Current projects are expanding this network to include all of the homes in the community. Most homes have latrines or dry latrines, with a minority also having septic tanks. A health office is located in the center of town. Approximately 70% of the community is literate. Of the 30% of the community that is not literate, 70% are women and 30% are men.

 The region of La Mixteca Alta is currently served by CEDICAM (CENTRO DE DESAROLLO CAMPESINO),  a local non-profit organization. CEDICAM currently engages communities in the region in an effort to create a holistic program for municipal development through improvements in agriculture. This organization will be a participant in this project, and their role will be discussed further below.

 

Methodology

 The Sustainable Agriculture in Mexico (SAM) Project consists of three phases. In the first phase, technical and community assessments were made. Based on data collected during the assessment, a number of recommended measures were developed to quantifiably improve the agricultural output of the region. In the second phase, these measures are implemented as recommended in this report, with priority based on the results of the report and community interest. In the third phase, success of the various implementations is measured and verified, and next steps are determined. If necessary, this will lead back to the first phase of the project.

 The first phase of the project, currently in progress, consists of the following steps. Potential measures were evaluated after the site survey and related research. A physical survey conducted in January, 2013 included soil and water tests, as well as notation of topographical features, with locations of interest marked with a GPS system. Community focus groups were conducted to develop an understanding of cultural practices and community priorities.

 The site survey was supplemented and informed by the research conducted through two means. Most importantly, through direct interviews and discussions with local NGOs and educational centers, a solid understanding of the region was developed. In addition, previous documentation by and conversations with these individuals were used to provide a more well-rounded description of the state of the environment and current projects in development in the region.

 Additionally, general research was done on the various measures that was considered for the project. Current best practices in similar environments were considered, and all options that fit within the technological capacity of the region were investigated.

 Based on the information gathered through this system, a series of measures were developed to address specific issues within the community. These measures were evaluated in terms of the cost of installation, the ease of maintenance, the community’s interest, the projected improvement in crop output, and possible negative impacts.

 For each measure, feasibility and cost effectiveness were determined based on this evaluation. Measures were labeled either recommended or not recommended based on the results, and were prioritized.

 In addition to measuring the impact on the community and the feasibility of the measures, environmental impact was considered. Potential negative impacts of each measure were considered, and details on necessary preventative education were determined. In cases where the negative impact or risk of failure was considered too high, the measures were not recommended.

 A system to measure and verify the effectiveness of each measure is also described in the assessment report. Since it is essential to measure the impact and prove the sustainability of each measure after its implementation, a system for doing so was determined and was briefly described. These methods include environmental testing, technical functionality of systems and ongoing community assessments.

 The following assumptions were made in developing this report:

  • The local climate will remain the same into the near future.
  • Agricultural production needs will remain stable into the near future.
  • Community organizations will remain intact and available as resources.
  • Current costs provided by vendors are reasonable approximations

 

Objectives

 As described above, the ultimate objective of this project is to create agricultural conditions that will support the community into the foreseeable future through the implementation of a series of solutions to current water management and agricultural issues. The objectives outlined in this section describe the scope of the project in terms of short and long term goals.

 In the short term, rainwater catchment tanks will provide a source of water for community farms during the dry season. Drip irrigation systems will enable more efficient use of water, and increase productivity. Also, in the short term, small bio-drainage plots will alleviate water-logging issues in some parts of the community. Wind pumps will be used to bring water from natural sources to locations at higher elevations.

In the long term, better crop rotation and fertilization methods will lead to a gradual improvement of soil conditions. Targeted bio-drainage and crop selection will lead to a water table balance that is more conducive to agriculture and to improved soil conditions. And, most importantly, increased understanding of best agricultural and water management practices will enable the community to better manage their environment for health and productivity.

These objectives will allow crops to be produced year-round, bringing additional income to the region and reducing dependency on income from transient labor. This will allow families to stay together through the year and encourage the younger community members to stay in the region.

 

Plan of Action

As described above, the objectives of this project will be accomplished in a series of phases. As each phase is completed, the details of following phases will gain further detail. In January of 2013, an initial assessment trip to the region was completed. During this trip, a number of communities in the region of La Mixteca Alta were visited. Community members were interviewed, and local conditions were evaluated. Based on the results of this trip, it was decided that San Miguel Huautla was most eligible for the initial focus of the project. This decision was based on the need of the community, the potential of the measures described above to meet those needs, and the interest of the community in engaging in the project. Also during this trip, relationships with local NGOs and institutions were developed. The team worked with CEDICAM to plan and execute site visits, and developed contacts with the Technical University of Mixteca’s Hydrological Institute (UTM) to share research on the region and technological expertise.

Currently, a first phase implementation plan is under development. In addition to detailed descriptions of the information found during the assessment trip in January, this document will contain in-depth evaluations of the objectives described above. Based on these assessments, a schedule for implementations will be prepared. Simpler measures that fit into the cultural values of the community, will be slotted for immediate implementation. More complex measures will be recommended for further study before implementation is begun.

In advance of the implementation trip, scheduled for August, a number of additional targets will be reached. Parallel to the development of the project report, an informational film is in production. In April, these two items will be used together to promote the project. The team will share details of the project in an effort to obtain both funding and implementation partners.  Concurrent to this fundraising effort, detailed implementation planning and scheduling will begin. Input from local NGOs and community leaders will be solicited and these opinions, in conjunction with the information in the project report, will be used to select measures to be implemented in August. Design and material needed for these recommendations will be further researched, and an implementation schedule will be determined based on this.

By June, all details for the implementation will be determined. At this point, practicalities of the trip will be finalized. Team members will then work with local community members to create a plausible schedule for material acquisition and construction. By the end of the month, a full plan for the work in August will be developed. July will be dedicated to handling any unforeseen issues.

The August intervention will have a number of goals. Measures that were deemed ready for implementation will be constructed. At this stage, the construction of rain water catchment systems and the installation of drip irrigation systems are seen as the most likely measures, as they provide the most benefit with the least risk and lowest capital requirements. Additionally, further assessment will be done on more technically complex measures. Currently, the team expects to do a full evaluation of the water table and to procure additional wind level research during the implementation. These activities will enable the project to continue forward with additional implementations as the project moves forward.

Interaction with the community will be another essential part of the first phase of the intervention. Building a fully developed relationship with community members is essential to the success of a project of this nature. By working with community members on a number of small-scale implementations, it will be possible to both strengthen this relationship and make sure that community members understand the value of the implementations, and know how to use and maintain them into the future. Also, the trust built through this collaboration will assist in laying the ground work for more complicated implementations that will follow.

Upon return from the first phase intervention, the team will begin work in preparing for the second phase. Higher level measures will be researched and developed based on the additional information obtained during the implementation trip. The process above will then be repeated for the new measures.

A key focus of the project will be on the sustainability of the systems developed. Measurement and verification will continue through periodic team monitoring trips to the country, which will overlap future implementations. Additionally, local monitoring will continue weekly as part of CEDICAM’s existing community outreach and concurrent project monitoring schedule.

As these monitoring visits continue, the team will develop a platform for continued, ongoing interaction between students and professionals from SAM and community and NGO members in Mexico. Through this continuing collaboration, sustainability will be assured, continued improvements will be made possible and implementation results will be measured.

This platform will enable a continuous transfer of knowledge between SAM and community members. Ongoing monitoring and implementations will enable sharing of ideas and experience, providing enrichment for students and professionals as well as community members.

 Income from activities within the community only partially covers the basic needs. During months of low agricultural productivity, heads of the household emigrate to look for jobs outside of the region, primarily to the cities of Oaxaca, Puebla, Nochixtlan, or Mexico City. This emigration brings most of the earnings into the community. Women stay in the community to take care of the household during this period.
 San Miguel Huautla is favorably located within the regional watershed. A number of springs exist in the area, and are largely used as sources of gravity-driven water system for household consumption and agriculture purposes. In 2010, approximately half of the homes had direct access to water.
 Approximately 80% of the homes currently have electrical energy through access to an energy distribution system. Current projects are expanding this network to include all of the homes in the community. Most homes have latrines or dry latrines, with a minority also having septic tanks. A health office is located in the center of town. Approximately 70% of the community is literate. Of the 30% of the community that is not literate, 70% are women and 30% are men.
 The region of La Mixteca Alta is currently served by CEDICAM (CENTRO DE DESAROLLO CAMPESINO),  a local non-profit organization. CEDICAM currently engages communities in the region in an effort to create a holistic program for municipal development through improvements in agriculture. This organization will be a participant in this project, and their role will be discussed further below.
 
Methodology
 The Sustainable Agriculture in Mexico (SAM) Project consists of three phases. In the first phase, technical and community assessments were made. Based on data collected during the assessment, a number of recommended measures were developed to quantifiably improve the agricultural output of the region. In the second phase, these measures are implemented as recommended in this report, with priority based on the results of the report and community interest. In the third phase, success of the various implementations is measured and verified, and next steps are determined. If necessary, this will lead back to the first phase of the project.
 The first phase of the project, currently in progress, consists of the following steps. Potential measures were evaluated after the site survey and related research. A physical survey conducted in January, 2013 included soil and water tests, as well as notation of topographical features, with locations of interest marked with a GPS system. Community focus groups were conducted to develop an understanding of cultural practices and community priorities.
 The site survey was supplemented and informed by the research conducted through two means. Most importantly, through direct interviews and discussions with local NGOs and educational centers, a solid understanding of the region was developed. In addition, previous documentation by and conversations with these individuals were used to provide a more well-rounded description of the state of the environment and current projects in development in the region.
 Additionally, general research was done on the various measures that was considered for the project. Current best practices in similar environments were considered, and all options that fit within the technological capacity of the region were investigated.
 Based on the information gathered through this system, a series of measures were developed to address specific issues within the community. These measures were evaluated in terms of the cost of installation, the ease of maintenance, the community’s interest, the projected improvement in crop output, and possible negative impacts.
 For each measure, feasibility and cost effectiveness were determined based on this evaluation. Measures were labeled either recommended or not recommended based on the results, and were prioritized.
 In addition to measuring the impact on the community and the feasibility of the measures, environmental impact was considered. Potential negative impacts of each measure were considered, and details on necessary preventative education were determined. In cases where the negative impact or risk of failure was considered too high, the measures were not recommended.
 A system to measure and verify the effectiveness of each measure is also described in the assessment report. Since it is essential to measure the impact and prove the sustainability of each measure after its implementation, a system for doing so was determined and was briefly described. These methods include environmental testing, technical functionality of systems and ongoing community assessments.
 The following assumptions were made in developing this report:

The local climate will remain the same into the near future.
Agricultural production needs will remain stable into the near future.
Community organizations will remain intact and available as resources.
Current costs provided by vendors are reasonable approximations
 
Objectives
 As described above, the ultimate objective of this project is to create agricultural conditions that will support the community into the foreseeable future through the implementation of a series of solutions to current water management and agricultural issues. The objectives outlined in this section describe the scope of the project in terms of short and long term goals.
 In the short term, rainwater catchment tanks will provide a source of water for community farms during the dry season. Drip irrigation systems will enable more efficient use of water, and increase productivity. Also, in the short term, small bio-drainage plots will alleviate water-logging issues in some parts of the community. Wind pumps will be used to bring water from natural sources to locations at higher elevations.
In the long term, better crop rotation and fertilization methods will lead to a gradual improvement of soil conditions. Targeted bio-drainage and crop selection will lead to a water table balance that is more conducive to agriculture and to improved soil conditions. And, most importantly, increased understanding of best agricultural and water management practices will enable the community to better manage their environment for health and productivity.
These objectives will allow crops to be produced year-round, bringing additional income to the region and reducing dependency on income from transient labor. This will allow families to stay together through the year and encourage the younger community members to stay in the region.
 
Plan of Action
As described above, the objectives of this project will be accomplished in a series of phases. As each phase is completed, the details of following phases will gain further detail. In January of 2013, an initial assessment trip to the region was completed. During this trip, a number of communities in the region of La Mixteca Alta were visited. Community members were interviewed, and local conditions were evaluated. Based on the results of this trip, it was decided that San Miguel Huautla was most eligible for the initial focus of the project. This decision was based on the need of the community, the potential of the measures described above to meet those needs, and the interest of the community in engaging in the project. Also during this trip, relationships with local NGOs and institutions were developed. The team worked with CEDICAM to plan and execute site visits, and developed contacts with the Technical University of Mixteca’s Hydrological Institute (UTM) to share research on the region and technological expertise.
Currently, a first phase implementation plan is under development. In addition to detailed descriptions of the information found during the assessment trip in January, this document will contain in-depth evaluations of the objectives described above. Based on these assessments, a schedule for implementations will be prepared. Simpler measures that fit into the cultural values of the community, will be slotted for immediate implementation. More complex measures will be recommended for further study before implementation is begun.
In advance of the implementation trip, scheduled for August, a number of additional targets will be reached. Parallel to the development of the project report, an informational film is in production. In April, these two items will be used together to promote the project. The team will share details of the project in an effort to obtain both funding and implementation partners.  Concurrent to this fundraising effort, detailed implementation planning and scheduling will begin. Input from local NGOs and community leaders will be solicited and these opinions, in conjunction with the information in the project report, will be used to select measures to be implemented in August. Design and material needed for these recommendations will be further researched, and an implementation schedule will be determined based on this.
By June, all details for the implementation will be determined. At this point, practicalities of the trip will be finalized. Team members will then work with local community members to create a plausible schedule for material acquisition and construction. By the end of the month, a full plan for the work in August will be developed. July will be dedicated to handling any unforeseen issues.
The August intervention will have a number of goals. Measures that were deemed ready for implementation will be constructed. At this stage, the construction of rain water catchment systems and the installation of drip irrigation systems are seen as the most likely measures, as they provide the most benefit with the least risk and lowest capital requirements. Additionally, further assessment will be done on more technically complex measures. Currently, the team expects to do a full evaluation of the water table and to procure additional wind level research during the implementation. These activities will enable the project to continue forward with additional implementations as the project moves forward.
Interaction with the community will be another essential part of the first phase of the intervention. Building a fully developed relationship with community members is essential to the success of a project of this nature. By working with community members on a number of small-scale implementations, it will be possible to both strengthen this relationship and make sure that community members understand the value of the implementations, and know how to use and maintain them into the future. Also, the trust built through this collaboration will assist in laying the ground work for more complicated implementations that will follow.
Upon return from the first phase intervention, the team will begin work in preparing for the second phase. Higher level measures will be researched and developed based on the additional information obtained during the implementation trip. The process above will then be repeated for the new measures.
A key focus of the project will be on the sustainability of the systems developed. Measurement and verification will continue through periodic team monitoring trips to the country, which will overlap future implementations. Additionally, local monitoring will continue weekly as part of CEDICAM’s existing community outreach and concurrent project monitoring schedule.
As these monitoring visits continue, the team will develop a platform for continued, ongoing interaction between students and professionals from SAM and community and NGO members in Mexico. Through this continuing collaboration, sustainability will be assured, continued improvements will be made possible and implementation results will be measured.
This platform will enable a continuous transfer of knowledge between SAM and community members. Ongoing monitoring and implementations will enable sharing of ideas and experience, providing enrichment for students and professionals as well as community members.

story:
Short Summary

We've been trying to go camping with our awesome camper, but the cost to register it is very high (about $300!). As a public school teacher, that doesn't fit well into my limited budget.

Basically:

Any funding we recieve for this project will go directly toward registering our camper and taking our kids camping!

  • The cost to register my camper is $286. Any and all dollars collected will go to that purpose and that purpose only. If there is any leftover, those dollars will go toward our camping trip! (I only asked for $500 because that is the minimum amount you can ask for--it wouldn't let me put in $300.)

The Impact

This will make a difference for my family because we can use the camper we love! This will give us the opportunity to bond as a family, experience nature, and learn about how we can be stewards of the environment and the world!
